We were supposed to do this at Amazon but what happened happened. Despite everything I’m lucky to have read three drafts of this and a treatment of what would have been its structure were it a series, and came in to the theater just to marvel at how Jerrold would pull this off. He pulled this off wonderfully, of course, with humor and aplomb. The script wasn’t as funny as it turned out to be on the screen, and kudos to Jerrold for seeing our government for the farce it is. Seeing Jericho play Quezon initially felt put on, but by the end you believe he’s the living, breathing embodiment of the 50 peso bill. Cris Villanueva puts some weight and character into the everpresent Joven. Jorah Mormont is a great Leonard Wood despite the accent. Karylle is always great and is missed on the big screen (follow her on Letterboxd). I really love Romnick as Roxas. And our dear beloved Mon Confiado, the survivor of the trilogy, plays Emilio Aguinaldo as the same person with the fire behind his eyes fully extinguished. It’s a painful portrayal, and will make you feel bad about all his shenanigans from the prior two films. End of the day I’m just grateful that during this time, what feels like such a low point for Philippine cinema, Jerrold continues to create his films about our flawed history, filled with stories of deluded strongmen, inexperienced boy generals and manipulative power players. He holds a mirror to our society that most people in power, heroes’ grandchildren included, don’t want to see. But when Leonard Wood talks about politicians using diplomatic trips as an excuse for family vacations and Filipinos not ready for independence with their infighting and greed, everything feels so eerily timely. Then you realize that’s the way it’s always been. Me: Question: matatapos na yung trilogy mo. After all is said and done is there an overarching message for the… bayaniverse?Jerrold: *shrugs* Aguinaldo outlived them all?There’s probably something in there. I’ll be thinking about that for a while.

Unlike Heneral Luna and Goyo, Quezon did not show any form of physical violence; rather, it portrayed violence through the use of words. Storytelling-wise, it was quite okay for me, but I think there are a lot of areas that could be improved. As someone who doesn’t appreciate slow-paced movies, Quezon felt really boring to me at the beginning. Nadia’s role as a storyteller throughout the film also felt somewhat messy—but then again, it allows the audience to form their own opinions and perspectives on the narratives and realities she presented during Quezon’s term.In both Heneral Luna and Goyo, Joven served as a symbol of youth—the hopeful defender of our country’s future and independence. In Quezon, however, he symbolized how people might abandon their morals because of the selective facts presented to them—facts that politicians carefully curate for their own benefit. Joven still represented hope for the Philippines, because even though he strayed from the beliefs he once fought for, he eventually came to understand how manipulative and power-hungry politicians can be. This idea was further emphasized by Miguel Laureano’s retirement, which symbolized the shift in political climate and the changing perception of the masses.The movie reflected the bitter reality of our current political state—it mirrored how Filipinos tend to be selective about what kinds of change and movement they are willing to support. As we moved on from Quezon’s term, we should have experienced growth and improvement, yet we did not. The film illustrated how our political system remains trapped in a constant loop, where we continue to vote for and campaign for politicians who ultimately serve Western interests rather than our own.

The controversy over this film has been severely overblown. Yes, it is satire. And just because it is, doesn’t mean it’s a joke that we can’t take seriously. I thought it was pretty good, it’s very well made with a really good performance by Jericho Rosales. My main issue is the character of Joven and his daughter. The use of a fictional journalist is interesting but I feel like him being so involved in the story was too much. I would've preferred him being more like a fly on the wall than being directly a part of the story.

ok after collecting all of my thoughts, ang husay mong tunay, quezon (2025) ! ipinakita mo kung gaano kadumi ang eleksyon at pulitika sa bansa, kung gaano lapastanganin ng kapangyarihan ang pilipinas mula pa noon. sa paggamit ng pwesto para manlamang ng kapwa, mula sa pagpapasara ng isang kilalang publikasyong alerta, sa pagpapasara ng bukid ni aguinaldo, sa pang-iikot sa batas para magmukhang malinis sa madla, at kung paanong ipamukhang mangmang ang mga pilipino.it's scary how politicians acts like this until this day of 2025, hindi tayo natututo, hindi tayo umuusbong bilang bayan, hindi tayo umaangat bilang isang mamamayan–dahil sa mga katulad ni quezon. it's truly a masterpiece, salamat sa pagsasabuhay ng kwento ni quezon at magmumulat pa lalo sa mata ko at sa paninindigan ko. salamat bayaniverse, isa kang tunay na napakagaling na likha.

cinematography was on POINTTT i love the little symbolisms, especially during the scenes where they have to go up and down that one split staircase (the subtle smugness of quezon once he says that he'll be resigning from the position of senate president knowing damn well he won't and proceeding to take one step higher on the staircase than osmeña )i will say though, the dialogue itself was... strangely unnatural. the mouthful of historical references that they shove into some of the lines makes it very obvious that they only wanted to spoonfeed unknowing viewers with the needed context which sadly, cheapens the initial quality of the film..but overall, the portrayal of political figures and their messiness was beautifully done. it wasn't too broody that it disinterests the audience but it's grounded enough that it proves itself to have something substantial to say about mindless politics; what does it really mean to be free? and are we ready to take up that responsibility?

Now, gets ko na why people from Quezon, lalo na si Helen Tan haha, and even MLQ’s relatives were so uneasy about this film. Yung “Casey” ni Tarog kasi didn’t really fit the heroic, spotless image they wanted to protect. They didn’t want to see or have people see a Quezon na impulsive, demanding, ruthless, manipulative, petty... Pero ayun, ang ganda rin na naging way ‘tong film na ‘to para i-deconstruct kung ano nga ba talaga ang ibig sabihin ng “bayani.” People often forget kasi to be critical of the ones they admire... sobrang bilib, sobrang hanga, without realizing na binibilog na lang din tayo sa mga kwento nila. Ika nga, binilog na parang kulangot. Anyway, salamat din pala sa serbisyo mo, Joven!

Following Jerrold Tarog's film, this movie is as brilliant as Heneral Luna And Goyo. I love knowing history but skeptic when I read articles and sources about our hereos because it just comes off glorifying but not this film. Yes, MLQ done a lot for the country and same as for himself in holding the most powerful position in the country. Jerrold Tarog succeeded in making prominent figures like MLQ, an ambitious guy that gradually turned greedy and manipulative for higher position and power; We will get to that certain point but Q let it consumed him. quick fire thoughts,-movie could've been a tighter 1hr 40 min movie. cut out the first wife subplot-i love the early parts, it felt so wes anderson surpringly, not in his asthetics but more int he spirit of having charicatures and very stage like presentation. - i love how the poltical game is represented like chess, but the excution of using whatever editing software to zoom in, and 5x the footage was bad. good idea but the excution was not able to realise it-personally i would've liked the quirky exaggeration to be heighted further. quezon at times feels more like walt disney, a micky mouse figure that is not a person. this is a good thing it adds to the political satire. - the framing device of using old movie reels to lead into flashbacks was a bit sloppy, at times you'd forget this framing device it's inconsitent. even the 3 act structure feels like it's all put out too quickly. the film feels like it's torn between two tones. but at times it balances it well, espcially with the parade scene at the end with quezon and emillo's parades being contrasted espcially with it's color grading. could've been better but it's good.for this film i ate bottled ice tea, and drank sour cream popcorn with less butter added than i originally asked for. i brought with me a party size popcorn that we bought from the cementary during all souls day, i added my own clarified butter which was good. i wish the bottled ice tea was cold. but at least it didnt make me go to the CR 2x

I rarely see Jericho Rosales in films but I think he does a good job capturing Quezon and the way people talk back in the late 1920s-30s. Of course I have to applaud the production and costume design! It’s excellent and if I remember my fashion history well, I think they did a good job at depicting the way Filipinos & especially Filipino women dressed back then. I also LOVE the format they chose to tell the story to stay true to the times, thru the silent films and then the 1920s-30s visual aesthetics. That aspect was so fun I love it so much!!!!!!! Anyway, it’s interesting to see how they portrayed Quezon because I vaguely remember how he was portrayed as a good President back in my elementary Philippine History lessons, how we briefly touched upon his “achievements”. But since they say that this depiction was backed by historians, public facts and documents then I think they really did a good job of humanizing him. He wasn’t just a shallow historical figure from the recent past anymore, we get to see his flaws & his motivations. This is great!Leaving the cinema just made me kinda depressed tbh because it just reminded me of my PI 100 class. The fact that we have such a repetitive case of betrayal, corruption, greed for money & power . . . . lagi nalang nananalo yung mga taong nasa matataas na posisyon na inuuna ang kanilang sariling interes imbis na maglungkod para sa bansa at para sa mga Pilipino, pumpublikong serbisyo. hayss

i remember quezon being one of the many names i had to memorize for some 4th grade exam alongside his contributions to the jones act and the tydings-mcduffie act. it was only until i became invested in historical movies that i decided to watch the bayaniverse, and it was in this trilogy where i started to look back and revisit my perspective on our national heroes. when we look at history, the act of calling someone a hero or a villain is very reductive, as it ignores the nuances of their decisions and their distinct worldviews and beliefs. the philippines is not exempt from this at all. in the context of the bayaniverse, these people (luna, goyo, quezon) are inept and egotistical at best, and downright criminal at worst, but put them in a movement, and you have the spirit of the filipino revolution, proud and waving the flag. and despite their flaws, that does not erase the efforts they've done for an independent republic.tarog, with quezon, aimed to showcase both his flaws and his accomplishments in a way that piques our interest and to go to our local library and read up on our history. we are directly anchored in through joven and his family, and through him, we get to interact with the true nature of quezon, one that, just as tarog intended, is not displayed in bullet text or powerpoint. he is a con man who thrives in confidence and does whatever is necessary, because to him, politics is a game of chess. he anticipates, he strategizes, and takes advantage of weakness. he is thrust into a system that benefits those in power, and considering his eagerness to satiate his thirst for power, he uses that system to gain complete control of his circle and of the country.its use of satire and the bravado of 1920s silent film aesthetic at certain points complements the big personality of quezon, immediately making it the most unique out of the trilogy, where the prior films were conventional war epics, rather showcasing the action of politics than the action of bloodshed, but it remains as violent and intense as the previous films, but what makes quezon stand out is that despite its lens (not borrowed from nepomuceno!), the situations facing the country remain significantly relevant. the constant trips costing filipino taxpayers millions? the fact that we have more politicians than public servants? infighting between two major political players? i forgot who said it, but they mentioned that quezon became the blueprint for modern day trapos, and i can see it! he possesses many of the traits that make up most of our senate, he's a cheat, a liar, and an opportunist! and that's what makes our national heroes so much more interesting. in one way or another, they are not faultless, nor are they necessarily bad people. despite all my shit talk on quezon, the one thing i'll give him credit for was his love for the country, his means justify the ends and he DELIVERS, at the cost of his morality and friendships.the chameleon will always fit in with anyone, but in the end, it will end up with no one, and that is the price one shall pay to become the chameleon.i got a good deal though, it was 13 dollars for one ticket? good shit

Kaya pala nagalit si Gov. Helen Tan at kapamilya niya cause they didn’t show a single redeemable trait of Quezon here, which honestly I kind of liked. He’s always portrayed as this larger-than-life president who accomplished so much. And although his flaws are in the history books, they’re rarely emphasized in schools. This movie finally showed that side of him. Although they still showed his contributions for the Filipino people, it was overshadowed by the scheming, womanizing, manipulative traits, and that lowkey god complex side of him, at least with how he was depicted in the movie.He’s still undeniably a great president who did a lot for the country, but it’s good that we don’t over-romanticize or idolize political figures. I just wish they also covered his actions during his term and during the Japanese invasion. It would’ve made a stronger conclusion and could have highlighted more of his contributions.As a Quezonian, this movie slapped. It honestly validated all the shady things I’ve researched about him before for a contest about.... well, him. Gets ko din naman bakit madami na offend, but yun nga we should also be aware of his flaws, and not glorify him too much. Overall great cast and great performances.

i’m in absolute awe of this film. the pacing is just right; the acting and chemistry are incredible; and the showcase of wit and humor—with the right blend of severity and weight in presenting these important moments of our history.i’ve thought of aguinaldo and hernando as “always the side-characters, never the main characters,” for being present in all bayaniverse but never had the chance to have their own movie. however, in this last installment of the trilogy, it was established that aguinaldo and hernando are both the central characters of bayaniverse. it all revolves around them. so i wonder, are their connections the standard or the criteria to be considered?lastly, jerrold tarog’s name will definitely be remembered. as i watch the credits, it’s not an isolated event for a director to be taking more parts of the film, but to direct, edit, transcribe, and score musical elements beautifully?? INSANE!!quezon actually has chemistry with everyone, and even has terms of endearment with everyone, yet he only calls osmeña his “mi querido” SERGIO IS DEF THE ONE WHO SHOULD BE WATCHED BY HIS WIFElong live quezmeña! long live singkwenty!

I watched Quezon yesterday in the cinemas. The movie leans heavily on the negative aspects of Manuel L. Quezon’s character—some of which are based on conjecture and lack sufficient historical evidence to be accepted as truth. For example, there is a scene portraying voters booing Emilio Aguinaldo during his presidential campaign, supposedly orchestrated by Quezon. There is no record of this ever happening.The film presents an unbalanced portrayal of the Philippines’ first president, further complicated by a fictional subplot involving made-up characters: journalist Jevon Hernando and his filmmaker daughter, Nadia, who produce campaign videos for Quezon’s presidential run while secretly creating “more honest” versions of each one.I didn’t quite understand the purpose of this subplot, except perhaps to draw parallels with the current political climate. The campaign videos felt like an early version of a “troll farm.” In that sense, the film invites viewers to reflect on the prevalence of “fake news” and how even legitimate journalists can become complicit in the myth-making that surrounds political figures.The film puts forward the idea that “democracy” in the Philippines has never been the real deal because of problematic leaders such as Manuel Quezon, and that the system has always been broken from the start. I think it’s a motivating sentiment; however, the message becomes contrived when retroactively applying it to Quezon’s story.It presents what on the surface appears to be a compelling question: What does it mean when a historical film uses a 21st-century lens to moralize the past? However, I personally disagree with this treatment of history. I believe history should be explored as unfamiliar terrain—something distinct from our present time. Otherwise, how could we genuinely learn anything from it? Imposing a modern framework of social media–driven politics onto the past flattens historical complexity, especially when many Filipinos don’t have access to in-depth historical education or materials outside of school.The story—not just of Manuel Quezon’s life, but of all Filipinos involved in the journey toward Philippine independence, from the formation of the Senate and Congress to the election of the first president—could have offered an inspiring message. Instead, all of this is portrayed as nothing but a sham. The film minimizes the work that Filipino figures did to win our independence by focusing only on the unsavory details of Quezon’s life, such as his love-hate relationship with Osmeña and his ploy to get Governor-General Leonard Wood removed from office. One of the film’s early fictional chapters is titled Quezon vs. Hernando: A Noble Lie, in which Quezon and Hernando debate the concept of “noble lies” using a quote from Plato. Quezon “loses” the argument simply because Hernando can name-drop more philosophers. Many scenes like this follow, reducing Quezon to a caricature—an exaggeratedly naïve and shallow version of himself.Because our history is often told through the lens of our colonizers, mainly Americans, Filipinos have long had a weak sense of the value of freedom and independence. We have been taught to believe that we are not ready to govern ourselves—and perhaps never will be. The film includes Quezon’s famous line: “I would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans.” In a more balanced portrayal, this line could have carried real gravitas. But given the film’s cynical treatment of Quezon, it instead becomes further evidence of his supposed incompetence.This film could have offered audiences a meaningful, alternative way to engage with our history. Instead, it mimicked the very dynamics of social media, reducing historical events into digestible, sensationalized drama. Audiences should ask questions while watching the movie, such as: Is there any genuine historical basis for the scene in which Manuel Quezon asks Vicente Madrigal for a blank check to fund his presidential campaign? What was the purpose of showing a completely fabricated conversation between a drunk Leonard Wood and Manuel Quezon?I also took issue with the portrayal of Emilio Aguinaldo as Quezon’s more “credible” rival. The movie pits Quezon and Aguinaldo against each other, going so far as to fabricate or misrepresent events to exaggerate their rivalry—such as showing Quezon canceling Aguinaldo’s pension during his run against him and framing the loss of Aguinaldo’s farm as a personal attack. Neither of these are based on fact. It is well-documented that Aguinaldo ordered the executions of Andres Bonifacio and Antonio Luna. These are not Quezon’s political inventions—they are part of the historical record. Yet the movie invents an entirely fictional subplot involving Pedro Janolino, who reaches out to Joven Hernando to reveal that Aguinaldo ordered him to kill General Antonio Luna. He is later revealed to be Quezon’s sergeant-at-arms who planted the testimony to sabotage Aguinaldo. In truth, there really was a Pedro Janolino, and he did kill General Luna. He died before Quezon ran for president, and it was Panteleon Garcia who later revealed that Aguinaldo ordered Luna’s murder.Unfortunately, I didn’t find the film well-executed overall. The acting was uneven, with the exception of Jericho Rosales (Quezon) and Mon Confiado (Aguinaldo). The fictional film-within-a-film subplot featured unlikable, underdeveloped characters, and the “silent movie” aesthetic came across as contrived rather than clever. The production design was also disappointing. The U.S. colonial period was a stylish era—this is evident from the films and photographs of the time—yet the costumes, especially for the women, lacked both elegance and authenticity.In the end, I couldn’t understand the film’s motive in diminishing Quezon’s legacy. It seemed told through a distinctly pro-American lens: the Filipino masses are depicted as naïve and gullible, unable to grasp what “independence” truly means, while figures like Sergio Osmeña and Manuel Roxas are reduced to mere sidekicks without agency or depth—an unfair portrayal of these important historical figures.Ultimately, the film misses an important opportunity. Instead of offering a richer understanding of our nation’s early struggles for independence, it relies on cynicism, convenient narratives, and present-day parallels that oversimplify history—a treatment that is both disrespectful to Quezon and his descendants and intellectually irresponsible. That half the movie’s plot rests on a fabricated premise should be a sign for audiences to approach it critically. Quezon’s story deserves a more nuanced, intelligent retelling—one that trusts its audience to think deeply, not one that panders to the fleeting attention span of social media.

I can see why people would criticize this film for not representing the historical figures for all the actions they've done no matter how good or bad. But pieces of art, which this film is (regardless of quality), are meant to tell a thematic story.For what it is, a film and not a documentary, it uses historical figures as symbols to tell a story of political games and showmanship. They are not who they were in history but are instead used as a backdrop for the inner workings of politics still prevalent to this day. The addition of Joven Hernando as a fictional character, other than being a narrative device, is a clear intention of the story being fictional, not historical, even if his existence being too fantastical at times.Yes, it can be dangerous to represent a historical event/s and handwave all inaccuracies as necessary for drama. You can even call this film straight up propaganda since it aims to tell a certain message with regards to politics, but it still functions as a piece of art. There is a risk of audiences viewing this dramatization as historical fact. A risk that no amount of "fictionalized" disclaimers can make people believe it to be otherwise.Do I believe this film shouldn't have been made for the lack of historical context it portrays? No. Without this film, I don't think a lot of Filipinos would know who Leonard Wood is. It ignites interests about the historical figures and leads people to seek out the facts themselves. Not a lot of people, me included, were aware of all the shit Wood did as Governor-General prior to this film.I didn't rate this film 3.5/5 for its accuracy, but instead for its pacing and tendency to read between the lines for you. Otherwise, it has great cinematography and a huge improvement in production value compared to Jerrold Tarog's previous films.

This is very much a Bayaniverse entry without a single gunshot fired and the blood staining the chests of military men, its framework based on the idea of the camera being the real militant weapon of the times, and the truth is in the edit, despite Tarog rendering the device no weight. There is simply no richness to be dug from ur-text of Quezon—its notions on the gamification of governance blowing cobwebs off a tired and worn out thesis as its attempts to doll up the friction within his praxis end up flat (why the hell is Aguinaldo suddenly so scared of placards). And so it becomes all the more revealing when Tarog stayed silent during the meltdown of a Quezon descendant at their Powerplant Q&A: a silence that reveals a spinelessness unbecoming of a filmmaker who has made the Definitive Trilogy on behalf of the Filipino People™. A funny nugget of irony now when Quezon clocks Joven as a hypocrite: the witness who records, but never intervenes.

I did not care for the caricature of a caricature acting of Jericho and Romnick. I am not sold that that is good acting. I did not care for the kind of simplistic depiction of political backroom talks. Although it’s a scathing recounting of Quezon as a flawed man, it felt like they did not go deeper as to the extent of corruption, its cover up and the real intentions.I wonder now if my opinion on the acting would change if I were satisfied with how the story of Quezon was tackled.

Jerrold Tarrog has the magic of making you question history while still allowing you to remain enjoying the film. It makes you want to seek more information about it. It makes you see this people who we have always known since youth, in a new light. But having said that, I still think that Goyo, among the three is his best.

In hindsight, as much as dir. Tarog intends to paint Filipino heroes as grey characters in all his films, his leads end up being close to black and white anyway. Luna is a heroes hero, while Goyo and Quezon have little to no redeeming qualities in their portrayal. Important still that these “great men” of Philippine history are deconstructed and demystified in a trilogy of pretty decent (or maybe better yet, palateable) movies. This last one feels a bit too long, its titular Quezon a bit too villainous, but a watchable film nonetheless.

Politics in the Philippines has always been a cycle of promises, lies, and abuse of power. This movie shows that Filipino politicians of the past are no different from those we have today. It shows us how we are deceived by lies, how we often choose the worst option when making decisions, and how “utang na loob” continues to shape our choices. The film’s pacing feels unique, almost like an American movie. It focuses on exposing Quezon’s wrongdoings, which explains why his grandson reacted strongly, but as they say, history doesn’t lie. I did find it hard to separate fact from fiction, especially since the place where Emilio was cornered in the movie wasn’t the same as in real life. That can be misleading for viewers, especially students. Nonetheless, I really enjoyed the film; I didn’t even notice how quickly time passed while watching it.

It’s a pretty straightforward historical drama, chronicling the rise of a political leader and charting the path for independence for The Philippines. I’ll acknowledge that it doesn’t seem to be a shameless puff piece, and it acknowledges Quezon as a sort of leader without much personal integrity who focuses more on pragmatism, which perhaps may have been important for his goals, even if he was driven largely by ego. There is some interesting artistic flair with the silent film interpretations, which honestly should have been the entire film.Jericho Rosales is excellent at giving that Charlie Sheen vibe.It’s a solid film overall even if it does kind of drag with a bunch of political bullshit that’s admittedly all the same thing of constant backstabbing and alliances, which does sound cool, but it’s a pretty normal historical drama.

Just don’t compare Quezon to the first two films in the trilogy and you’ll find something to admire. It stands on its own as a portrait of power and pride, though at times unsure of which face to show. Jericho Rosales walks a tightrope between conviction and caricature, brilliant one moment, baffling the next. The production looks rich and patriotic, but the story doesn’t quite know what it’s fighting for. It wants to build a hero, but forgets to give him a clear battle. Still, if you let it be its own story, you’ll enjoy the echoes of history and the weight of what it tries to say.

The two sides of the same coin. The admired and the flawed. The good old fashioned politician and the staunch patriot."QUEZON" isn't particularly the film that one may expect from writer-director Jerrold Tarog's "Bayaniverse". The titular hero isn't glorified but examined - with all his strengths and imperfections. History, as rich as it gets, immortalizes the gripping and controversial facets of the beloved statesman that unsurprisingly still echo up to this day.Exceptionally played by Urian winner Jericho Rosales, we get to see the might, influence, charisma, narcissism, lies, and betrayals of Philippines' second president through his acting force and vulnerability. The penchant to roll the classic 4:3 movie aspect ratio in its short films and the interesting camera pans during the Congress election strategies a la chess moves are some of its strong suits. Art and production designs, although a good addition, can be improved to perfectly embody its era. Bearing its creative license, it dramatizes the calculated games and internal conflicts through (at times confusing) non-linear storytelling with hefty dialogues and politicking narratives that can be cut down in exchange for more warranted depictions of political effects to the society under the eight-year regime, apart from showcasing people's ignorance of the very notion of independence. Now that would be more compelling and cathartic. Rosales truly leads the pack but it's indubitable that every featured artist (Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Cris Villanueva, Benjamin Alves, Karylle, and even its import Iain Glen to name a few) pours their heart to the material. A call to action in these trying times, may this push us to demand for a better nation.Joven Hernando and Alerta. Plato and Kant. Casey and the Philippines. Heroes are still humans. 3.5/5, folks! "QUEZON" is still playing in Philippine cinemas. #MovieMadness

an aguinaldo propaganda in the guise of a quezon biopic? this film is really all about perception. how quezon weaponized perception. and most importantly on how this film presents aguinaldo in stark contrast to how he was presented in heneral luna. i hated that aguinaldo presented in the past film but i can’t help but sympathize with him in this one. but this is what this film wants it to be and that “aguinaldo propaganda” concludes not only the movie, but the franchise altogether. i kept thinking that maybe there remains in aguinaldo a semblance of heroism especially in that one specific scene where he chose not to introduce quezon’s alleged first wife and just use her as a pawn. or maybe it was the emphasis on how his candidacy for presidency was a mere heed of duty and not out of lust for power. or maybe i felt bad because he was gradually yet loudly stripped of power. or maybe just the culmination of every vengeful act of quezon against him. or maybe it’s just easier to accept him as a lesser evil. the idea of resonating and accepting someone merely because they are a lesser evil is just plain foolishness in theory. even the idea of a “lesser evil” just seems to transcend all bounds of rationality. did we bring that idea into conception as a cry for help? a cry for hope? it’s really easier to side with someone. as a country who remains deep in suffering, misery loves company i guess. but is this really all that we deserve? kailan kayo tayo tuluyang titigil magpakaalipin?

'The Noble Lie'. This is one of the lines that resonated with me after watching the film. The mere fact that these traditional politicians boil everything that they do down to this idea of doing questionable means towards a 'good end' is not only narcissistic but also dangerous at best. These people genuinely believe that a lie could be considered 'noble'. Meaning, what is ethically right for them is already skewed, and that conscience no longer plays a role in the crux of their actions. Rosales' Quezon, even at the very end of the film, embodied this rotten mentality, thoroughly absorbed in the idea of being the 'Great Savior' that the Philippines needed for its independence--even at the expense of losing the true meaning of the word.Truly a magnificent end to the 'bayaniverse' trilogy, showcasing a 'war' that is not fought in the front (compared to 'Heneral Luna' and 'Goyo'). A war that is played behind cunning speeches and charming smiles, but is dangerous all the same. Not gonna lie, I thoroughly enjoyed Quezon and Osmena's dynamics (iykyk). Will definitely be watching again.

came for the politics, stayed for the toxic yaoiquezon was a fun yet impactful movie about what it means to be a "bayani" and the dark side of it. it mostly showed quezon and his two sides: the charming hero of the masses and the dirty tactics opportunist that keeps him in the business. i liked the film felt like a play mirroring how quezon was like a showman and despite a lot of creative liberties, they don't miss with the emotional story beats. it is a shame we didnt get more screentime in his term in ww2 (the standardization of the filipino language kinda does deserve its own film) and the positive effect of his accomplishments on the filipino besides morale but with the scope of the movie being really large, im fine with what we have. i think the film is important as it gives younger people a more accessible way to learn about and cultivate an interest in history, myself included.

Quezon clan threatened and hurt by this film shows it is a DAMN GOOD FILM!Kung may halimbawa sa kapangyarihan ng pelikula, isa sa mga ito yun. Isa sa mga huli sa bayani trilogy ni Jerrold Tarog sums everything up. Imahe ni Quezon na akala natin na perpektong tao siya, ay malayo sa katotohanan. Ang mga itinuturing nating bayani ay meron at merong mga kamalian. Pakita sa pelikulang ito na ang pulitiko ay laro lamang ng mga ilan para sa sarili at di para sa tao, di para sa bayan. Ang satirang mapapaisip ka kung and independensya ay tunay o nakatanikala pa tayo sa mga banyaga. Ano nga ba ang independensya sa kasalukuyang panahon ngayon? Kung independensya ay di kalayaan, di tayo malaya. Isang kakaibang pelikula na dapat tuloy pa na pag-usapan ng tao at di lamang ipagbawalan dahil lamang sa pamilyang nakinabang sa imahe na ibinigay sa kanilang ninunong Quezon. Kahit nga si Quezon ay biktima dahil sa pananaw na sumabay at makilaro sa sistema upang sana matupad ang kalayaan. Ngunit nilubog siya hanggang hindi na siya kailangan ng mga banyaga. Patuloy sana ang mga pelikulang ganito. Pagpugay at padayon Jerrold Tarog!!!

I think the film has true promise. Quezon has always been quite a controversial figure of the early fight for true Philippine independence. He did as much good and as much bad if you really think deeply about it BUT the film is just presented in such a dense way.In posits there is true good in Politics.Even sections of actual criticism in the film is really hampered by Tarrog's insistence of the right 'governance'. The lack of a real alternative or an actual in depth conversations that does not really fall into this guise of moral grandstanding is prevalent that it was so eyeroll inducing. You can read philosophies and still be the worst person ever - a college with Liberal Arts make you learn that quickly. If Quezon did not win, what does Aguinaldo can offer in the table that he himself had not done too?Rather film, just villainizes Quezon's insistence to lead. One good example of the film's insistence for moralistic bent but lack of actual 'analysis' is the film's villainization of Quezon's use of his connection.That is what connections are for. To create this dynamic give and take but it oh no, that is bad - because he can make so much campaign materials. It never really delivered on the fact on what would become the Nacionalista Party lead to one of the biggest ultra-majority in the Philippine's History, a familiar sight if anyone has lived to tell in the Duterte era Congress. In fact, the film kinda glosses the fact that this same majority lead the changes in the constitution that inadvertently resulted to the Marcos Dictatorship. In fact, I do think the reason there are many rich families interested in Government is because how they were able to really to enter political spaces during this time. Like for a film that prides itself as critical, it always uses these weak arguments to posit the rather double face attitude of Quezon. I was grasping straws, because it uses the worst criticisms (ad hominems) rather than just actually pulling real punches that is still present in the current Philippine political space. It just bats this idea that Quezon wants the presidency is bad (not really bad), because he wants it no matter what. His machination is bad since he is not truthful about his intention. It literally is true facts. Quezon is a problematic and prolific muckraker, that most of what we hate about Aguinaldo is actually rooted towards his campaign against him. That is attested but a lot of actual paper trails sadly has been destroyed by the war of 45. The film posits that is bad. (not necessarily) but the problem here is that the film also plays out the same muckraking as noble against some of his 'enemies' since they it's not out there. Like come-on now film. That is just plain stupidity at this point. You cannot just make this two sides of the coin when it's practically the same side. I also hate how the film hates Quezon since he is sly about his approach on things but equally loves the American because of their you ready sine clearly the average filipino does not know the word for Independence. THIS SHOULD BE ABOUT THE LEADERS to begin with. Another instance of the film going for the soft analysis over real question of readiness with the leadership. And also, it really gives so much pass for the Americans and how they handled the Philippines, because they are well-meaning apparently. Suddenly, the atrocities is just a side comment here and there. Even Aguinaldo, who could have been more complex as a character himself is just plainly glorified. I just feel there is so much more here that could have been made to make this actually critical in a sense that in actually is talking about things that would still be prevalent in our life and all. On a lighter mode, Good performances though. Echo does well. I personally think certain actors looked closer to the very Hispanized Quezon but has character for it. He kinda performed really well and the cavalcade of supporting role was a welcome surprise. I personally think the film did well visually and editing wise, which is a lot for a local film. The costuming though is really bad - a lot of badly fitted suits. I will still recommend this BUT with a deep reading about Quezon's role in PHI history tbh. It is important to look at this with a more critical eyes since this takes a lot of true issues about Quezon but in a way that feels misguided tbh. (1) Hmmm. Surface level talks about Government leadership. I wish sana within true leaders dapat tbh. DDS sense is tingling.(2) Uy cinema scenes. Pero again this belief that there is only true good and true bad. And true good is not subtle . And by knowing western idealogy.(3) Konfirmed, half glass empty approach and very dds.(4) The American racism is played done here.(5) Also, Tarrog does hate Quezon here. Even a simple political function like Appointment is played against Quezon, because it is his literal job. He has a job to do, what do you mean he has to be true to some kind of moral logic.(6) Soft positive, great style from Tarrog.(7) Sa lahat ng oomff ko walang commentary about how American was never really into the Philippines, or the rather weird anti-independence belief in the film. but posits that murican cares about you and baddie quezon just want to be free.(8) Not the Aguinaldo advocacy in the film. I still have an hour left off this film and this awful and redeemable in my eyes.(9) Ang tanga na nung film. Literal na may political parties and donor ang isang politiko. Your unpopularity with donors/failing party is more of you problem.(10) There is credence on Aguinaldo vs Quezon. I do believe that Aguinaldo even tried to oust his presidency. (Incorrect it was much worst - collaboration with the Japanese). (11) But this feels like too critical to Quezon at all.(12) This is practically me trying to piece my history. Quezon is not the nicest man in all accounts - the film got that right but he pushed the buttons to where our country lead into. Successful or Not. The film is just too damn negative to the point That it rather be friendly to Americans and Aguinaldo and make them a densely woo is mee characters. (13) Aguinaldo being shocked that people hate after getting a bunch of KKK members death. Kkk is not the same klub from USA, btw.(14) This last section that heavily focuses on Quezon in his final days is so much better. It is a true character study that does not need grandstanding good or bad morality. Talaga namern.

echo ate so hard i forgot he wasn’t actually quezongrew up hearing quezon’s name in classrooms like we all did. told and retold as the dignified leader who fought for independence, blablabla. this film strips away that shiny layer of image and confronts us with the truths we were never taught to see. we often criticize figures like marcos sr, arroyo, duterte, etc etc yet we rarely examine how earlier leaders helped shape the very systems and machineries that later rulers would exploit.10/10 reminder that the oh so called heroes we idolize were never untouchable—they were human, ambitious, deeply—dare i say intentionally—flawed, and just as power hungry as fuck as those who came after them.also — leonard wood complaining of the undeveloped roads and illiteracy of the people — who set that system up??/?/?

Glad TBA had the budget to export Iain Glen to give an Off-Broadway theatre performance that only serves as a functional foil for a domineering Filipino icon. Speaking of, Rosales thankfully did not rely on the heroic gravitas of John Arcilla's General Luna and playful charm of Paulo Avelino's Goyo. Instead, he leans on the spiteful energy and conniving instincts of a Peter Sellers character, which fits on the pseudo-satirical bite that this Bayaniverse entry tries to achieve.It is not the best of the three. (In fact, it is the most eyebrow-raising but liberating of them.) Yet, if it spawns discussion of what is truth or fiction, satire or reality, heroism or populism, and identity or heritage, then it more than succeeds its intentions or un-intentions.2025 Movie Diary #81

I was surprised to see this at amc, although with only 10am or 10pm showings, so I showed up to the morning movie with breakfast and the other Filipinos of NYC.This is last of director Jerrod Tarog's trilogy exploring the mythology behind Filipino "national heroes," and while I haven't seen the first two, I plan to watch them soon. I am still a beginner in Filipino film, and this was the first time I have seen the American colonial period depicted onscreen. It was very interesting to me, as this time period is the topic of my dissertation. The film was really a character study of Quezon, and did not shy away from being critical.

The third installment of the Bayani-verse franchise yet again provides a compelling portrayal of another pivotal figure in Philippine history. Jericho and Karylle really stood out in their roles as President Manuel L. Quezon and First Lady Aurora Quezon. I particularly enjoyed the unraveling of the Aguinaldo vs. Quezon showdown in 1935, a satisfying karmic payback for the atrocities Aguinaldo did in the past. Understandably, the movie was not as action packed as its predecessors given that its events occurred post-Philippine revolution. But I found the movie’s exposition of the political drama at that time to have sufficiently made up for the lack of gunshots and wars as a backdropWhile the movie is set in the ‘20s-‘30s, “Quezon” poignantly mirrors the patronage and personality politics that continue to fester our country today. It ultimately makes one realize that our nation’s forefathers are as equally to be blamed, if not more, for the sorry state of our government today. Note: There is a post-credit scene!

Made me realize that even now we are still being played by the same machineries and tricks, how those in power can bend politics around their fingers and still call it leadership. At the same time, leaves me confused about which side holds the truth. Hayyyyyy, we can’t really say no.

This third bayaniverse installment is more creative and whimsical. It's fitting to the message that the movie is trying to make about powerful men's greed that shaped the beginning of our republic (characterized by choreography, a performance, and ultimately a game where Filipinos lose). We feel more directly the decision to make the film allude to our current political landscape where media becomes a tool in dividing the people. I don't think people should take this as autobiographies of our "bayani" because this film is not just about Quezon but equally the beginnings of a Philippine government that the people deal with today. It's a reflection of our current conditions and the reasons why independence is still a thing our politicians utter but the people never fully grasp. I wished they added Filipino translations to the film within this film though.

JACK EN POY HALE HALE HOY Okay but fr though, love how this film is as much about the common Filipino folk as it is about Quezon. It’s very ambitious. Though it made a valiant attempt, I think it got lost in trying to tell the 30+ year story of the most powerful Filipino 2nd only to Ferdie. Malakas yung opening niya, pero as the screentime went on, naging paulit ulit nlng yung character beat ni Quezon. I think eto talaga yung kahinaan ng “Bayaniverse”. Though deep and well acted, ultimately 2D lng yung mga main characters. The ending was disappointing. Rinush yung “tragedy” ni Quezon to a single scene. It felt less like a story and more just a chronology/ documentary, which is the danger nmn of all biopics. Still, it was a fun watch. The smallest attention to detail (like 48 stars lng yung US flag not 50) kept me hooked since it showed na it was made with passion, nde lng for the cheap jokes/ caricatures of history. If they ever make a Marcos biopic, i hope they learn from the shortcomings of Quezon.

I'm confident in the production's handling of historical accuracy, and one can only wish the production team well, hoping the highest sense of responsibility was employed to achieve that benchmark.Technically, this film is no joke—it's genuinely strong. Pulling off the production requirements for historical films is incredibly difficult, but what amazes me about director Jerrold Tarog is his profound sense of vision. It is creative, yet direct enough to clearly tell the narrative to a broad audience.Narrative-wise, the "film within a film" trope is a good idea, though it needs some polishing to make the 'buddy and soul' arc more impactful. Despite needing that refinement, it remains a highly creative approach to the story.While I struggle to engage during the very first few minutes, from my lens, this is a great film. It is strong enough to celebrate the Bayaniverse's impact and secure its future.

I love how the Bayaniverse trilogy depicts its main characters not as heroes, but as human beings. Quezon, despite having good intentions for the growth and development of the Phillipines, did not hold back from getting his hands dirty in playing the game of politics. Osmena, Wood, and Aguinaldo are promintent rivals who tested Quezon’s morals and capabilities, and this film did not fall short in showing his flaws as a leader being consumed for his thirst for power and what he is willing to do to achieve it. The quote “Being a hero is all about perception” really summarizes Quezon’s rise to power. A brilliant film nonetheless.

I think Jericho Rosales did such a compelling Quezon - and his chemistry with Romnick Sarmienta was on fire! This movie, contrary to the extreme reactions of some of Quezon’s descendants, actually deepens the former president’s characterization beyond merely being the ‘Commonwealth president’ and the ‘Father of the national language.’ The era Quezon lived in was unlike any other, and its politicians were complex, multifaceted characters navigating personal ambitions along with the demands of governing a fledgling nation. Jerrold Tarog must be commended for his continued examination of the nation’s founding fathers - and this is a fitting, albeit unofficial, conclusion to his ‘Bayaniverse’ trilogy.

All that for what, shits and giggles?I honestly am very disappointed by this movie. How was this movie PG, there were swear words every five seconds and smoking in every room?Film makers that continue to fumble when they have a book, a short story, a myth, or literally HISTORY, as reference material continues to baffle me. What a waste of resources and potential.These events happened already. Why the need to add fictional elements for thematic purposes? Was adding fictional character/s necessary, if their goal was to educate our generation of who Quezon really was? And why include flashbacks inside the movie, when we are already looking back into the past? It adds confusion as to where we are in the plot. I did not like the ugly art deco designs in the flashback scenes and as part of the office design. The over contoured faces. Using “Hallelujah Chorus” as background music during the signing of the Tydings-McDuffie Act was tasteless. Please try to be more imaginative next time.American characters (like Wood) being portrayed as morally upright in contrast with Quezon’s portrayal of character should be talked about more. It implies white supremacy and colonial mentality. Let’s not do that all over again :)There was a scene where they brought out Quezon’s first wife for five seconds, for what? Was the goal to empower women or to further impose traditional gender roles where women are pushed to the sidelines? She was dismissed, shrugged from the plot. Please do better next time.This movie had the potential to call out the dirty elections, spoils system, traditional politics, systematic corruption, and imperialism. The very same issues they faced (or should I say reinforced?) before that we still face today. While I do commend the morally stained portrayal of Quezon as it serves as a lesson to not idolize individuals (especially government officials). However, the public may be misled to believe this fictional plot points that are conveniently dramatic. We should not tolerate or promote historical distortion in media. It would be so much better to simply provide the public a historical film that adheres to historical documents and facts.Ps. These are just my opinions. This is a free and independent nation after all (see what I did there? hehe). Pps. I need someone to give me flowers and chocolates after each fight too.

gets ko na yung nagsabing oppenheimer tagalog to... HAHAHAHAH as far as mainstream pinoy cinema goes, this is a pretty great takedown of the idea of the "great man" as told in the history textbooks that we grew up with. the act of framing manuel quezon's shenanigans in his rise to power as one of the seeds that bore our nation's problems in the present is a pretty brave and bold move for a big budget, mainstream studio film to take, especially in the context of our local cinema. what i think makes quezon work so well is how, unlike the previous two films, it still plots out a clear narrative without losing sight of its unifying thread despite chronicling more than decade's worth of history.the unfortunate caveat to all of this is, of course, the loss of focus on other significant political and social players during this time, such as the sakdalista movement, as well as the downplaying of the strength and significance of the presidential campaign of gregorio aglipay, who himself won two provinces, despite the insignificance that the film portrays him with.despite all that, for what it is, jerrold tarog's quezon is still one of the most exciting filipino releases in recent memory, and the inevitable role it will play in the further reassessment of the way we've learned our history and the eventual reckoning with it will be one that i will be watching out for.

Out of all the films in this trilogy, I think Quezon captures the thesis Tarog's take on the filipino hero the best. Comparing it to Luna and especially Goyo, Quezon seems to be more overt with its critique on filipino politics and the filipino people as spectators of what goes on in our society. Though, seemingly with the other films in this trilogy, its message is served to its audience on a silver platter (some would say very preachy) but I guess it's a hard responsibility to take as a directior especially with how a lot of people took Luna's messaging. So in a way that proves the message of the movie? How could the filipino understand freedom if they are deprived of learning about it? also the performances were so good, Jericho Rosales' charisma and his ability to look so scary and eerie in the most tense situations *chefs kiss* in another note, teasing magsaysay in a post credit scene like the next solo movie in the marvel cinematic universe is so funny.

rewatched quezon with the fam and now i have a whole new thing to rant about HAKSJSSJkasi otw home, my dad was talking about how quezon was made out to be the villain when he technically didnt do anything illegal, he just called in some favors, compared to aguinaldo who was said to have killed luna and bonifaciobut bruhh thats not the point of the film... cuz who fucking cares if what quezon did was illegal, the point was that it was morally wrong and manipulative and untruthful in what he claimed himself to be to his voters and to the publicthe point is that the foundation of philippine politics is based on morally wrong and informal/unsound practices (patronage politics)i think its kinda stupid to be arguing about whos right and whos wrong, whos more evil than who... it doesnt fucking matter cuz that shit alr happened and those people are alr dead HAJSHSJSHSJwhat matters is how it reflects the framework of philippine politics todayif youre mad about the things the *actually dead* characters of the film did *in the actual past*, which were not even sure are true (historical accuracy) or illegal, then you should direct that anger to the exact same shit but worse thats factually happening right now, thats actually illegal, and by people who are still alive and will continue to commit these crime unless theyre prosecuted and revolted againsti hope people know na this isnt just historical beef na they can just argue about forda drama and the marites-ing of it all and na its still happening right now and that were actual characters in the exact same story but worsethese arent just scenes and characters from a drama that you can just debate about for entertainment, because we live and experience these exact same real life scenes and characters in the everyday modern philippines. you shouldnt be rooting for aguinaldo or quezon or whoever character in that film; While Quezon definitely has less action compared to Heneral Luna and Goyo, the other films in the “Bayaniverse,” I was not bored at all. The pacing might be gentler, but the storytelling and performances more than make up for it. The cast delivered strong portrayals that captured both the humanity and complexity of the historical figures, and the musical score complemented the drama beautifully. The production values were impressive as well. They may not be Hollywood-level in terms of scale, but they are undeniably Filipino in spirit and craftsmanship. You can really feel the trademark quality of TBA Studios throughout.As someone who’s a Filipino history nerd, I really appreciated how this film shed light on another side of Manuel L. Quezon, one that’s often overshadowed by his more famous political achievements. I also just learned that Quezon was a lawyer, and as a lawyer myself, it was fascinating to see how he was able to “play the game,” navigating from being a trial lawyer to eventually becoming the President of the Philippines. It added another layer of depth and respect for his intellect and political skill.Having just been to Bataan last week for a historical and heritage trip, I felt an even deeper connection to the story and the period it depicted.I was also fortunate enough to have seen Quezon’s Game a few years ago, and watching Quezon felt like seeing a grander, more expansive retelling of that same chapter in our history. The scope, emotion, and context were all heightened, giving a broader and richer perspective on Quezon’s legacy.Overall, Quezon might not rely on action or spectacle, but it delivers a story that deepens our understanding of one of the key figures in our nation’s history.

sinaunang yaoi is crazy bruh The first thing that really came to mind when I was watching this movie was the stylistic choice it decided to take on. The story-telling was incredible, following the movies made by Nadia with some scenes being her movie, while others being "real life". The way scenes were shot in "real life" in the style of a silent movie was genuinely so unique to me that it caught my eye. The merge of styles through out the entire movie all fit perfectly as well as contrasted each other well. Secondly, which is probably the most obvious, I enjoyed the perspective this movie gives towards not just Quezon but politics in general. I have heard the criticism about the fantasies this movie merges into what is the "truth", but I argue that is the point. The proper approach to movies like this is that after watching it, it should encourage you to research on your own. Be interested, be curious, and compare it to the life we live in. It brings Filipinos awareness back to the Philippines and our history. It may not all be true, but it sure is interesting. Of course, I have to mention the incredible acting of Jericho Rosales, Romnick Sarmenta, Mon Confiado, Therese Malvar, and the rest of the amazing cast. They brought these characters to life. There was a lot of debate about whether or not Jericho Rosales was the right fit for Quezon, but he did astoundingly well. I admire his efforts to be as true to life as he could be, accent and all. I am extremely attached to the style this movie had. Its use of colors, cinematography, and even sound were foundational to the narrative. The final scene, with quezon's quote of "I am the Filipino People, I am the Philippines!" brought chills all over my body. The envy in his voice when he questions why Osmeña was blessed with a healthy body and him not made me also question the irony of their story. It reminds me that sins are also reflected in the body. Wonderful movie, it brings about questions that we may never get answers to, and thoughts we may never complete. A beautiful and extravagantly painted picture of the past, that now leaves an impression on our present and the actions for our future.

As the third installment of Joven-verse, this film took a left turn in terms of its mood, less violent, but sharper and more stingy.Hearing about the protests among his descendants, I believe it is hitting its goal, so much that even Joven (we) are being interrogated on our views so far. The Questions of QuezonThroughout Jerold Tarog's trilogy, he raises important questions about heroism — and in Quezon (2025), he explores it not as an absolute truth but as a matter of perception. Sa dami ng na-trigger at nabuong kontrobersya, it begs the question: handa na nga ba tayo sa malayang diskusyon tungkol dito?“Independencia!” The very ideal that Quezon and his forerunners fought and died for is finally within reach — pero paano ito aabutin ng bagong magiging presidente? The film thrives in the space between conflicting morals, fitting for a morally obsessed country riddled with corruption. Alin nga ba ang mas epektibo? Idealismo or realidad?The film is generous in portraying the old man's charm, eloquence, and impeccable sense of style. But in true Tarog fashion, he wasn't safe from being questioned either. Beneath the charisma lies his vanity, a leader fully aware of his strength and uses it to advance his ambitions -- whether for his country or for himself, who knows?Tarog's meta approach, blending fiction and history is a tricky but effective device. Nadia's films-within-the-film reveal two sides of the story, the same way Tarog does throughout his trilogy. The film doesn’t just retell the past; it exposes how the narratives we accept as truth are constructed. Gaano nga ba kalaki ang papel ng media, pelikula, o ngayon, ng TikTok sa politika ng bansa?What remains unclear, however, is the role of the Americans in the narrative. I didn’t quite appreciate how Governor Wood sort of became a "father figure" to the away-bati childishness of Quezon and Osmeña. Wasn’t this separation engineered by the ’Kano themselves?In today's battle against fake news, sensationalism and historical accuracy, Quezon's creative licenses may be a double-edged sword. But honestly? To hell with it!It's a triumph of Filipino filmmaking. It provokes, divides, and gets us all talking. Quezon doesn’t claim to be the truth, but it forces us to question who gets to tell it. So really, what is there to lose?---------On a lighter note, as a tubong Quezon myself, I have to say — Echo nailed Quezon’s American English accent of that time, but not quite his Tayabasing Tagalog.

Quezon provides an unbiased but contentious retelling of the titular character’s rise and fall in Philippine politics, his undeniable influence and charm, and his lasting impact in the country’s bid for independence.Despite the title, the film was not a glorification, but a critique on the character that is Manuel L. Quezon, the second president of the Philippines. Because while it was he who sought for Philippine independence, history tells us he might have done it in the not so cleanest of ways. While charming and influential, he was also brutal, unrelenting, and felt like he was Thanos or Darth Vader at times.The storytelling was great. Using film to backtrack the history of Quezon from his humble beginnings to his rise to presidency was really a good touch. It also really helped in presenting the exposition and Philippine history without it seeming like it was forced. It was like watching an educational film within a film.It was really paced well, too, as it divided chapters of Quezon’s life based on his political enemies at the time – it was like watching him go up the political ranks as he beat one adversary after another. Each scene felt intentional and it didn’t feel like 2 hours have passed.Like any other historical account, this film took some big creative liberties as well. While it could be really good for dramatic effect and inducing a reaction, it could also spark controversy and be misconstrued as the truth. With this, I thought some of the choices could’ve stuck to the truth and just exaggerated them a bit.But all in all, Quezon is a great film for both the casual audience and history buffs. It’s a good critique on the character of Manuel Quezon and as well as on all the political figures surrounding him at the time. At the same time, it’s also a good way to learn about the history of the Philippines, its political landscape, and its journey to independence. STAY FOR THE MID-CREDITS SCENE.

i really wanted to love this film, i was looking forward to it. i did enjoy watching it, both as a film and for its historical subject. the performances were really good, i can see that the actors really enjoyed playing their roles. the story was a bit meta as well which i liked.but the film had a lot going for it that really held it back. the production felt rushed. the actor for wood was wasted with so few scenes showing him. the story also spanned too wide a period, leaving no room for additional context as to what was happening in the film. i knew the historical context behind those scenes, but i doubt the same can be said of the general public.then there's the narrative itself. one issue that really bothers me with this trilogy is how they portray the americans as reasonable. that scene where wood was talking to some locals and how they exclaimed that independence was good enough to eat was icky. what exactly is that scene supposed to mean. it feels patronizing. and how they felt quezon even more so. that he was manipulative, shrewd, was already known. the director said he wanted to humanize him. but quezon had no redeeming qualities in the film. he had no arc. actually, if you look at all three movies, all the leading characters had no arcs. they lived and ended their films with nothing about them having changed, nor something interesting shown about them. luna was a hothead, goyo was a womanizer, and quezon was conniving. luna being this unwavering patriot didnt make sense to me. he ratted out on the katipunan at first, and only joined the revolution when it was finally against the americans. goyo felt too small a figure that even in his own film, the focus wasnt on him, it was on aguinaldo and mabini (granted, that the trilogy was more of aguinaldo's arc, than the figures important to his story). and quezon, for all his and his colleagues' shrewdness, won ph independence from a country so reluctant to recognize it. that it played into their ambition shouldnt faze us from recognizing the monumental task ahead of them. these figures are not beyond reproach, nor are the films wrong from portraying them the way they were portrayed. there are just elements in these films, that quezon really amplify, that prevent them from reaching their potential. these movies have moved the discourse, both in history and in film far, but could not any further.

It’s a masterfully crafted yet morally complex film that dares to strip a national hero of sanctity and reveal him as flawed, strategic, and deeply human. Visually stunning and bold in its storytelling, it reimagines Quezon not as a savior, but as the architect of the very system that made such saviors necessary. Jericho Rosales delivers a remarkable performance—his Quezon feels layered, seamlessly shifting from statesman to tactician with effortless charm. You can sense the performance behind the persona, the fragility behind the power.For me, Quezon isn’t really a takedown of a hero; it’s a mirror. It forces us to see how the leaders we admire, and even the systems we live in, are built by people as fragile and flawed as we are. And maybe that’s what makes it sting—because it feels true.

Tarog’s bayaniverse trilogy ends in a more implicating interpretation of a hero than his two previous films. There is no ambiguity in Quezon’s machiavellian journey to power. Rosales treads close to a mere impersonation while Confiado shines through his restraint.Quezon’s portrayal is flat compared to Luna’s and Goyo’s because unlike the latter, the former is not portrayed as a human with flaws but simply a wretched opportunist fueled by greed and ego. Luna’s populist portrayal is balanced with his sincere desire to fight colonialism. Goyo’s naïveté is tempered by his youthful idealism. Quezon, on the other hand, shows no redeeming factor. All in all, the conclusion to the trilogy reiterates that meeting your heroes is less glamorous than it seems.

What a wonderfully nasty piece of work that portrays things in such a devilishly entertaining way. It was fun watching the politics in this movie portrayed in such a darkly comedic, performative, and theatrical way (especially the first half). The way everything seems so ultra rehearsed, the way they move, the way they’re blocked, etc. together with some lively camera work created for such a weirdly unserious yet engaging experience. Though its chronological sequencing was a bit confusing at the start, and it’s pretty easy to get lost in what point of time we’re in.It’s funny too because these people are determining the future and current state of the country, yet it’s just a game to them; a stupidly intricate, dangerous game for power on who yaps and complains the loudest, all while Americans meddle with everything (as they always have), so it was over when Quezon stated that he learned from them.The biggest compliment I’d give is how this movie lowkey had some balls. I did NOT expect it to paint characters the way they did. They imply a shocking amount of things, and just straight up show how disgusting and slimy people were, albeit really smart and strategic for the worse.The foundation of this country, and its current systems have always been stained by foreigners (particularly the Americans), and it continues to be. Deny it all you want, the worst country in the world has that much power because it convinced the world that it does. The same way the loudest people always have, or end up, with some level of power.That’s Philippine politics for y’all; a loud, nasty, slimy game where the occupiers are always somehow the winners despite what people want to believe. Where the nastiest ones always somehow win, and it’s because they know how to play this deranged, ugly game incredibly well.A game that sadly demands you surrender your morals for survival, and that survival turns into a disgusting lust for power. The worst guy you know won the game because the system favors them.Also, Ramon Magsaysay will appear in Avengers Doomsday

It’s been a while since we’ve seen a political film that brings us back to our senses and challenges what it means to be patriotic. (Maybe Gomburza tho) Quezon is a fresh film that introspects on the evils in both society and ourselves, and how we even play our role in corruption. I loved that Quezon is humanized as someone who had to play the game against bigger evils. Props to the super creative use of storytelling devices and other details, like Joven (journalist), newspapers, and films (all seemingly inspired from Citizen Kane). Much like Kane too, Quezon’s character reveals itself and his ambitions piece by piece, shifting our perception of him until his death.The film does quite have a spoonfed narrative though. The script tends to overexplain its themes and motivations. Great that it makes everything more digestible to the general public, but it also takes away some subtlety.The cast is solid and GOATEDD, and special shoutout to DOP Pong Ignacio. Lighting and cameras were crazy. The production design also makes everything feels so real!! Excited for the next Bayaniverse
campy, total 180 of typical 'Bayani' films and serves as like a formal apology to Aguinaldo

This film was indeed a pandora's box as how Mr. Avancena worded it. I came into the movie theater full of enthusiasm to watch it, but I came out full of questions, undecided if I was to believe the narrative, and unsatisfied. Upon going home, I had to research the next days about the veracity of this film. The film juxtaposed several elements of different timeframes such as colorized and non-colorized cinema to show the antagonist Quezon and the underdog Osmena narrative. It showed how Quezon tried to politick the Filipinos and Osmena (the Americans included)just to gain the seat for President. This also portrayed that patronage politics might have started in Quezon's time. However, just like the other Bayaniverse series, it is for the viewer to discern which part of the film was true or not because the disclaimer was only put in the beginning of the film. Thus, the viewers nee to read and research further. After watching the film, I also had the thought that publishing a book might not do so much after the trending phase of this film because in the era of social media, a book would not reach the same level of viewers that the film would reach especially if this will be released on online streaming platforms. On my part, it would be better if I would be able to read the researched part even on a blog online. The cast played well on their roles as Osmena, Quezon, and Aguinaldo. Other made up characters like Nadia and Joven, complemented the storyline . There was even a point where Nadia herself made fun of Quezon's traits. The main characters copied even the intonation of the politicians. Overall, it was a good film, but for a full length film, it feels incomplete. For a film just to end with "I am the Philippines", it feels unnatural. Well and good, Quezon died in America so there was really no good ending. But given that this was a mix of fiction and history, I hope they showed at least a memory of Quezon's memorial.

hindi na bago sa pilipinas ang konsepto ng isang “bayani” na magbibigay ng katarungan at pagbabago sa bansang sinilangan. hindi na bago ang pagbibitiw ng mga mahalimuyak na mga salita na may pagkukulang naman sa esensya, para lang linlangin ang taumbayan na sumapi at maniwala na may solusyon pa sa crisis na kanilang hinaharap. katulad nalang ng pagbibitiw ni quezon sa mga salitang “independencia” at “demokrasya,” na pinangako niyang maikakamit ng taumbayan kung makukuha niya ang kapangyarihan na kanyang inaasam. ngunit, hindi ang mga politikang ito ang magbibigay sa’tin ng tunay na independencia at demokrasya— tayo, bilang taumbayan, ang tunay na makakapagsulong ng karapatan natin sa demokrasya’t kasarinlan. hanggang ngayon, ramdam pa rin natin ang bakas ng imperyalismo sa bansa. ngunit, walang pagkakataon ang ordinaryong pilipino na pagtuunan ng pansin ang mga bagay na iyan dahil tayo’y nakakulong sa isang sistemang neoliberalismo na hindi nanghihikayat ng malayang pagsasalita at pagpupuna sa mga taong nakaupo sa trono ng sakim at korap na kapangyarihan. power should always emanate from the people and not from the politicians who swore to serve us. even if these “great” heroes have contributed to some important things in our country, we must always remember to never glorify them for simply doing their responsibilities. true heroism consists not in holding such power but in selflessly using it for the welfare of the people (rightfully so), and it is upon us to remind these “heroes” that real greatness pertains to the Filipino people who continue to fight, hope, and demand a better nation. maybe when we get to that point, we will be able to comprehend the full realization of our democracy. on a more unserious note tho.. kudos to the production team for that bomb ass set design + score ↕ tba studios never fails grabe !!! i just know philippine cinema will reach greater heights in the next few years & i’m also excited to be part of this field very soon !!! :~) mabuhay ang kasaysayan, ang mga artista ng bayan, at ang pelikulang pilipino <33
