I am leaving here my thoughts I made on my notepad, if it seems very essay-ish and inaccurate I am sorry I tried my best to write my thoughts 4 hours after watching the film. Here it is:“Hindi ka hari!”“Sigurado ka?”In this film we unravel the first President of the Philippines in a time where we never really knew what independence or being free meant. It was just simply a glittery word we acquainted with being free from Americans and establishing our own rule.As far as I am aware 1935 was an establishment of a commonwealth to transition to 1946 which was our genuine independence as a nation. We see this film through a sort of journalistic storytelling lenses of Joven Hernando (a fictional character), as he threads through what he went through prior to this film and the aftermath of Goyo towards the time he was reporting Quezon’s senatorial endeavors, his run for presidency, and unspooling the threads of who and what Quezon is. What is Politics? What is Patronage Politics?Politics has roots in Aristotle’s work, Politika, a Greek word which consequently means things concerning the polis (city). It is the ability by which one can use power, or direct influences to an individual, group, community, or a nation that a person “doing politics” busy themselves with. This occurs at all levels of a society.Now what is patronage politics? Associations, positions, promotions, and contracts are based on personal connections and friendships rather than pure merit. This is also what we call the padrino system or clientelism. Why am I highlighting this? You may think of our so called Bayanis as the glorified images they were portrayed as and made up to be by textbooks, anecdotes, and so on. But, they are just as horrid and grotesque as any 21st century politician can be. As Quezon believed it, it was a game, and the trick was to cheat it. Noble LiesIn the movie we see Joven and Quezon have a short argument about truth, their difference, and why it matters when they’ve attained a victory for independence or freedom. They reference many classic texts and philosophical concepts from which Quezon mentioned “mentira noble”, Spanish for a noble lie.This is a concept derived from Plato’s ‘The Republic’ in which Plato discusses that societies are built on such lies. If the masses believe in something (independence), then there is something to fight for. (Krause, 2019) Which in the film he utilizes as a way to earn power and along the way do some good for those who have placed his trust on him.Joven’s dialogue and realizations in contrast to this throughout the film reflects the audience’s gradual disposition over what can we believe from Quezon or in contemporary times, those who claim to have the nation’s best interests.Are Filipinos that fucking stupid?The humor in the film is great. Satire doesn’t necessarily mean a quality of being funny but just the moments that are spread sporadically throughout the film makes you smile and chuckle while also grappling with how twisted the butt of the jokes are. There is this moment when Leonard Wood who went on a trip around the Philippines to survey whether the Filipinos were truly capable of independence asked a few townspeople along with his translator if they knew what independence meant, to which one replied that: “They become full (their stomach) from the thought of it,” I couldn’t help but laugh and overhear a chuckle from 1 other watcher besides me. (Albeit what I quoted is not direct as I am struggling remembering the exact line. )So the question is are Filipinos stupid? No. We believe the propagandas, the persuasive anecdotes, what others say, and what we say because we hope for nothing but the best for all of us. It is not our fault that those we place our trust in chooses to betray us—the same way Quezon did to Joven, the same way Quezon did to Aguinaldo, and the same way Aguinaldo did to Luna and Bonifacio. I cannot stress how we’re stuck in this perpetual loop and how deep-rooted such issue is. Alas, human nature and greed is a mystical thing, it surpasses all reasoning and thought.But, in this day and age, if you cannot use history and the information at your disposal to think rationally—you are a stupid Filipino. Sorry.The WomenWhat is Aurora Quezon, Maria Agoncillo, and Carmen and Nadia Hernando’s role in all of this? Well, to show the intricacies and persistence of women who stand at the shadows of history. Aurora Quezon, behind the scenes is a woman who could stand her ground at the same level as Manuel Quezon.Maria Agoncillo, becomes Aguinaldo’s anchor as he goes through the loss and dirty tactics done by Quezon. Carmen and Nadia are smart women whose integrity and careers are supported by their husband in a time where women were otherwise discouraged. An article by the Lifestyle Inquirer goes into interviews with the respective actresses and provides valuable insight for these characters and how important they are. You can search for it. With that, I hope to soon see a movie about a female hero, as the director also hopes to do if given the chance.Quezon has a husband, OsmenaThey should get married, honestly. They bicker and make up like a husband and his wife would. The parallels run deep, friend or foe, tampuhan, the ancient and homosexual version of Bongbong and Sara. You will understand what I mean when you see the film, it sounds diabolical, I know.Their dynamic is like two academic rivals who do nothing but outdo each other and try to tolerate each other and when hurt make up for it. For instance, the Hare-Hawes-Cutting Act and the blatant copying of assignment but slightly changing the wording with the consequent Tydings-McDuffie Act all because Quezon wanted the credit when Hare-Hawes-Cutting was his idea. Finally…“Maybe it’s about proving what you can do, instead of proving what is right.” — Carmen HernandoShe’s right, at the end of the day why should these politicians never fulfill and serve their own interests? At this point it is an interplay of psychological warfare, scheming, power play, and gaining something out of their endeavors whether it be favors, money, or something to leverage themselves further. But how will we, as a country move on forward with confidence and trust towards those who govern us when betrayal is in the table? When the nation’s interests aren’t fulfilled? When they are the sole reason we can’t get ourselves out of this damning rut? Perhaps this 21st century we ask, if there is a 22nd century will the Filipinos then, be able to live a better life? Because I have seen enough to say that in my lifetime at least, it’s never going to get any better.Suffice to say, I loved this film. I availed of the ₱ 250.00 discount allowed for students and teachers, and I did not feel like I wasted money at all. If we talk about the technical aspects like: the direction, music, composition, casting, and wardrobe, they were all perfect. You’ll never think throughout watching that they chickened out with giving Quezon (2025) huge production value. In a time where corruption is rampant in Philippine politics, well in retrospect it has always been, this film could not be any more relevant and timely. I implore everyone to support Filipino film and cinema, as they are a treasure trove of bright and brimming ideas awaiting audiences to see them.

A fitting conclusion to Tarog's trilogy attempting to define the Filipino hero: Quezon combines the heat of Heneral Luna and the introspection of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral. The film holds firm to the trilogy's assertion that our national heroes are not without fault, and that, perhaps, we regained our independence partly because of those faults. Manuel Quezon—like Luna and Del Pilar—feels flesh and blood here, capable of both heroism and monstrosities.

Jerrold Tarog closes his Bayaniverse trilogy with Quezon, a sharp, ambitious political drama that trades the gunfire of Heneral Luna and Goyo for quieter battles fought through charm, rhetoric, and image.Jericho Rosales completely disappears into the role, giving a performance that’s both commanding and unsettling. He plays Quezon not as a spotless hero but as a man who understands how leadership relies on performance. The film doesn’t glorify him; it examines him. It shows how charisma can inspire and manipulate at the same time, and how power often hides behind elegance.The movie looks beautiful, with careful production design, steady pacing, and clean editing that keeps even long political exchanges engaging. Tarog’s direction is thoughtful and confident, peeling back Quezon’s myth not to tear it down but to reveal the man underneath that’s ambitious, flawed, and burdened by what it takes to lead.Seen at SM City Dasmariñas

I believe in the artistic direction of the crew behind Quezon. Tarog’s willingness to treat a towering historical figure such as Manuel L. Quezon not as a flawless hero, but as a complex, ambitious individual, gives the film a bracingly fresh tone. The production design, pacing and cinematography all feel meticulously crafted, it’s clear the team sought to challenge the idea of grand national myth and instead expose the power-games behind it. In doing so, Quezon invites us to see how legacy is manufactured, and how leadership is as much performance as service. I found the portrayal compelling and the moral ambiguity rich, making the film more than just a biopic. It becomes a meditation on nationhood, ambition and compromise.

will definitely watch this again, but with a research backup the second time. the first time, you get persuaded, the next, you start to critique.a solid 5/5 for me, out of the bayaniverse trilogy, this one stands a favorite. it makes you think and decipher Quezon’s game as a leader and as a follower—especially compared to the books taught in school. also so much to ponder about how the Philippines had been placed in the not-so-rightful hands from the very start leading us up to this day with the same power-greedy and so-called heroes of our nation. all in all, the cinematography, the setting, and even their wardrobe were so on point it made me feel immersed back in 1920s-1940s. also kudos to Jericho Rosales as an actor, a very timeless artist. ang pogi niya parin talaga hahahahahaamabuhay ang sining ng mga Pilipino!

While considered polarizing, I still do appreciate the storytelling. I have a lot of thoughts on this as well as it's parallels to the "Hamilton" Broadway Musical, but I shan't divulge further. The only thing I would change about this is the use of the silent film aesthetic. At first, I liked it because it brought something new to the table and did tie well to the artistic intent to the film but as it went on, I felt like it somehow lost the plot. I felt like it didn't capture well which parts were reflective of the "film" and which ones were the supposed "actual" occurences. It was only at the end where I felt it become harmonious with the other two films in the series because of the familiar feeling it invoked. Maybe what I really wanted to get from the film was to viscerally understand the history it focuses on. How does it's overall storytelling differ from how I would read it from a textbook? How will an unbiased journalist portray it without being propaganda-like?Nonetheless, I loved the movie! If it gets me raving or wanting to disect each artistic choice made for it, then it's a good film. Jerrold Tarog never disappoints!

The movie immediately brought to mind the political intrigue of the Netflix series House of Cards, but infused with the signature Tarog humor and quips. This is consistent with the entire "Bayaniverse" Trilogy.The deconstruction of our national heroes and figures is a perfect use of cinema in retelling history. By humanizing them into characters with their own beliefs, goals, egos, and flaws, the film makes them relatable. While creative and fictional liberties were certainly taken, the general gist, and hopefully the core message of the story will be received and resonate well with the audience.Also, on a final note: what the hell, Magsaysay next?

If the thought doesn’t make sense or all over the place, maybe because it is. Haha. Glad to have watched this in the theater! —Nung una I was quite disappointed sa unang part, na parang preamble, pero I guess that’s just how they make use of the time.I like how they portrayed Quezon: a politician through and through: knows how to play a game, used PR, used ads, used propaganda. Technically he has the charisma (mestizo), uniqueness (maybe because mestizo nga, not as Filipino, Filipino), nerve – because in the movie he portrays really going after what he wants, and talent — he rose above the ranks from lawyer to president. I didn’t see him as a bad person, but as a politician, so technically a bad person. Lol.We can see the portrayal and effect of media, and its relationship to politicians. The connections, the benefits might really impair the judgement, and of course, the want to survive life with a job that brings food to the table. But I like that at the end, the media is aware of its rile and at the same time, still aware of its principles once awakened to see whats happening.I like a quote about idolizing person that you may be blinded — ugh, I hope to capture the whole thing when it’s online. I can awfully relate because it’s also applicable to love.I like the movie overall and it’s worth watching for. Happy to have film makers who actually do these things and market it well.

Me and my friends were like seven minutes late to the cinema because of the ticket line which was. Devastating. I missed the first few scenes, which I think included JC Santos, and that just ruined the experience for me a little. You have no idea how sad that makes me. I kept thinking about it the whole time. Anyway. I really love the cinematography, the music, the production design, the pacing, everything. This movie felt so beautiful and put together. The colors and composition reminded me of Wes Anderson in a way and that was such a joy to look at. I always love a good non-linear story so that was extra fun to watch too, though I didn’t fully get it at first because I didn’t get to see the first few scenes. >:(I’ve always loved how Tarog uses Joven to tell the story so now, the use of Joven’s daughter’s film as a storytelling device really got me. The documentary (??) bits were one of my favorite parts. So Charlie Chaplin. I really loved that. The script was also really well written and the way the actors delivered them was so on-point. Most of them are some of my favorite actors too. Rusca got recast which made me sad for a minute because he was my favorite in Heneral Luna, but then I found out the old actor was actually a horrible person, so um. Sucks.The yaoification of Quezon and Osmeña is... interesting. They always find a way to make these movies seem a bit gay. Interesting. So. I think this movie is way better than Goyo because that one honestly bored me (I know the quiet aesthetic was intentional but I didn't like it okay). But Heneral Luna is still my favorite. Luna’s story just hits harder. But yh, this one still feels stronger in terms of the technical stuff. It's very neat and I can't wait to rewatch it. I think this would be 10x better after the 2nd watch.I don’t know much about history, so I really enjoy watching movies like this. So much stuff to learn. Still..... #BringBackJovente

​"Bakit siya ang pinagpala ng mabuting kalagayan? Hindi ba nila kilala kung sino ako? I am Manuel Luis Quezon! I am the Filipino People! I am the Philippines!"​The final lines of the film perfectly encapsulate the kind of person Manuel Luis Quezon was—a power-hungry, manipulative, all-knowing, chameleon king.​Tarog's portrayal of Quezon displayed him as a human being; a being with his own selfish greeds and desires. Books and documentaries would often portray Quezon as nothing but a "perfect president," so shedding light on him as a trapo will definitely have his relatives shaking their heads at the representation.​Heroes were often depicted as nothing but that—perfect, heroic, symbols of peace and protection. However, in Tarog's final installment of the Bayaniverse Trilogy, he portrayed Quezon under a different lens: he was portrayed as imperfect, flawed. Quezon was sick, twisted, and outwardly selfish—something that made him stand out from Goyo and Luna. (Btw, my memory could be serving me wrong.) Goyo and Luna were portrayed as these "sacrificial" heroes whose actions were driven by their patriotism and love for the country. Quezon, however, was not. His actions were driven by his need to have and stay in power. As mentioned, "Mauuna pang pumuti ang uwak kaysa mawalan ka ng kapangyarihan, Quezon" for he did anything and everything in his power to ensure that he was never in a position of no power.​Quezon was terrifying for how "real" he is in this day and time. He was able to manipulate the people by abusing the Filipino's belief of utang na loob—and he used that as ammunition in every political war, which ultimately led to his victory. Another factor was how Quezon curated his image of "perfection" by utilizing his connections to the fullest—even going as far as trampling over the livelihood and well-being of the people if it meant staying in power. He used people at his disposal, all the while maintaining a picture-perfect image to the media and the people.​Quezon is terrifying because while he may not have been fighting armies on the war zones, he was pulling the strings from the best seat in the house.

Watched Heneral Luna one time ago and never seen Goyo (but willing to watch after). Quezon is the final film from TBA's Bayniverse. It honestly feels like a satisfying conclusion to its said trilogy. I was never known to be interested in early Philippine history. I watched this because it's a film that's highly anticipated nationwide. I was really impressed by how the film goes from Manuel's early life through films, and how his life is in turmoil through the battle for independence. However, the film explores his desire for deception to gain much power to become the second president of the Philippines. Something so sinister that I understand that's how Jerrold interpreted it based on facts about Quezon's "game".Every aspect in every scene resembles the reality we still have. We're still in a developed country, which is not surprising to say the least. We're humans playing by the rules and laws. But for our country, it's what we live for.I adored how the film opens, but then I get a bit overwhelmed afterward. Thankfully, I was able to connect the dots on what's happening. I was blown away by the visuals, production set, and its ensemble cast of this film. It's truly amazing to see those in a Philippine film. Although, the sound mixing and camera work felt they needed to fill up on some scenes. Almost to make this film perfect.Now, the film Quezon became a national debate, thanks to one of Quezon's descendants at the Q&A post-screening. He stated that the film affected him, claiming it's a satire rather than a biopic. And he's not the only one; a few of Quezon's families are also affected by the film afterward. Many hated, many defend. It is very common to see this happening in every biopic film ever made. Filmmakers create a film based on a real-life figure, followed by credible sources available. Despite that, you will never escape from any person who knows a real-life figure because they don't provide you with any consideration before the film was made. To respond to that fiasco, I dare to say that this film is worth watching for everybody who's not interested in or complains about it. The disclaimer says it all, and yet they roared for a boycott. But as long as Quezon tells you exactly what the director and writers had envisioned, the film is the representation of our struggle to handle our country due to lies and deception.

"Being a hero, it's all about perception." It feels surreal that I was watching Quezon for the second time while, at the same moment, around 800 kilometers away from Cebu, one of Quezon’s grandsons was throwing a fit toward the cast and crew for what he felt was a disrespectful portrayal of his grandfather. It’s expected that his descendants would have mixed-to-negative feelings about this film, so I get where they’re coming from. I think what held me back from…

“How can you be a guardian of truth if you can only see one side?”what a way to end the Bayaniverse trilogy with a banger ender: being a hero is all about perception. three movies later, i hope it gets to be an exercise for everyone to critically think about how we view the heroes we look up to and see them in a new light—stripped of all their laurels, flawed and utterly humanized; not because we want to taint their names and contributions, but because it opens our eyes to blind fanaticism. to paraphrase Maria Ressa, it is only by knowing and having these facts will we have truth; truth that will build trust; all of which in pursuit of building a shared reality and thus democracy that will champion the country’s independence. but until this government is infested by politicians instead of public servants, and until this country forgets to study and learn from its past, one shouldn’t be surprised to see this country still run like hell. p.s. the emotions in that speech scene towards the end got me teary eyed! Mon Confiado was on a whole another level!

Just watched Quezon. I want to start by saying I think Filipino films are not quite my jam, unfortunately.I wanted to like this. It had its moments, and I get the idea it wanted to convey.Quezon is a depiction of how Americans influenced Philippine politics into what it is today—for better or worse (mostly worse). It was not a good painting of Manuel Quezon by any means.I grew up not really minding Philippine presidents. Quezon, for me, felt like a decent person, someone who was deeply connected with the US—President of the Commonwealth. The film depicted him as a sneaky politician who would do everything to stay in power. He was charismatic and had a way with his words and aura. Unfortunately, the whole time I felt like I missed much more nuance in him. I felt his characterization was too one-sided; it seemed like he was used as a plot point to get a point across. The film was actually confusing to follow at first due to the differing timelines.The problem with political films is that they tend to be biased from a certain point of view. This felt like one of those films. I wished I had seen a complex character—one who is a lion when he needs to be but perhaps also a person who genuinely believed in something.This was my first entry in the 'bayaniverse' by Tarog. Perhaps most of what was depicted was true, but I think it left out some of the important parts of what made Quezon a fascinating Filipino president.I did like the heart of what it wanted to depict. We live in a political regime where corporations are the boss and the leaders do things to stay in power—not for the people.The acting was not that good. They hired a 'for the money' American actor, and the leads did not feel authentically Filipino. Or maybe the writing was just mid.
There's a sense of liberation in seeing heroes being portrayed in an unflattering light. It does not make them dislikeable per se, it makes them human, pulling them back to their core essence.

If I'm being completely honest, my first few days back in Manila's included a lot of conversations centred around the gross ineptitude of the country's government leaders. So I guess it's kind of fitting that Quezon's the first film I got to see in the cinema with my parents and my sister since, like, forever. And I can't 100% speak to the factual accuracy in this picture (which makes sense because, at the end of the day, this is still just a movie). But I am glad that it's sparked even more conversations between my family and I about figures and events in Philippine history that are basically repeating themselves in the present. Also, it helps to have a huge movie star attached to an otherwise flawed but still pretty entertaining story at the heart of Jerrold Tarog's latest addition to the Bayani-verse. Definitely recommend that more people watch Quezon, double check the data, and talk about the stuff they know (or think they know) because it's certainly got a lot of interesting ideas that are worthy of extended thought or discussion.

I am the Philippines The third installment of Tarrogs' Bayaniverse explores on Manuel L Quezon as a four part film; The Hero, The Great Political Player, and the lobbyists towards the Philippines' Independence.Unlike the first two films which focus on the fight for a Revolutionary Government, Quezon, sets up a new story toward nation building translated to themes of power and play in the political arena(of which parallels to the existing political patterns of Philippine Politics). The good points of the film would be the idea of a film within a film; how media was an excellent medium to portray the two sides of Quezon as the Hero and the Trapo(traditional politician). Jericho Rosales did and excellent execution portraying someone who despite being narcissistic and intelligent gentleman you can't help but to love the guy.Another good point was the role Joven Hernando as the main protagonist guised as a side character which has been consistent on all three films. The role of Joven, a fictional character meant to symbolize the viewers but my interpretation would also be the youth who are seeking for truth. Joven meaning youth in Spanish is an excellent name for the character inviting the youth to critically think and discern for a more Independent Philippines.This last installment,while it stirs controversy on the portrayal of President Manuel L.Quezon, opens a fresh perspective how we can further improve our flawed system To quote the late President MLQ"I would rather have a government run like hell by Filipinos,than run like heaven by Americans, because no matter how bad a Filipino Government might be, we can always change it"

i believe this a good conclusion in bayaniverse. the movie keeps me questioning, how do we even define bayani? what concept do we make a stand point to have a bayani? well, yes totoo it's a perception. kasi we see our heroes in 'perfect' and full of glossified praises, but in reality (which is hard to swallow) they are humans that has flaws. Now it makes sense why the other movie has Quezon's Game. Basically and literally MLQ knows how to play his A-game. Madumi ang sistema ng politika. Kung gusto mo ng kapangyarihan, alyansa, at lakas — rurumihan mo at gagawa ka ng pangalan dahil nga ang sistema ng politiko sa ating bansa ay naghahangad tayo na mga leader na may 'messianic' dahil tayo ay lugmok sa mapang-alipustang sistema. Quezon's took that mindset kaya mabilis siya nakahanap ng propaganda. And during that time, iyon ang isinisigaw ng tao, kaya he took that chance to make name out of it and gain the power he has.This is also a good storytelling of how 'populism' is existing in our country. Politicians do not care majority for our well-being as a nation. As long as they get benefit out of it, they will seize the opportunity to create name para makatakbo sa mga mataaas na posisyon. + plus Joven Hernando's character is powerful and its rich. Ang metaphor lang sakin journalista siya, and basically i love how he represents all of us. Tayo ang mga mata at nakakakita sa realidas ng ating lipunan

Overall direction was commendable for the perceived budget but pales in comparison to its previous installments. Story Beats and writing was very good at keeping the attention of the audience from the time jumps to the volley between flashbacks and fast forwards. Production design could have been improved but was made up for by the stellar performances of the cast and ensemble, Capturing the nuances of our history book photos come to life. The character study done here (especially) by the lead was very spot on. Although wrapped in discourse and controversy I think the movie has done its job by pushing people to dig deeper and find out more about the historical figures we either praise or persecute. in the words of quezon "perception is everything".

I know my fair share of Philippine history, but every time I watch a film about anything related to it, my knowledge expands and I get to explore new perspectives. To be honest, Manuel L. Quezon was the president that I never really got to learn deeply about, hence the reason why I watched this film. It was an eye opener. The film was divided into different sections, each about someone Quezon was associated with, making me able to understand all point of views.

More than the moral dilemma of campaigns, Quezon was a deconstruction of our loyalists culture towards political actors, diverting us from their humane and flawed tendencies . And although it synthesizes fiction in narrating a political legacy, it continues to be a reflection of how the public has its influence on the politics we have today because of our blinded perception of the people we should only consider as public servants and not heroes.

Interesting, Insightful, and Innovative look at the rise of Former Philippine President Manuel L. Quezon (b. 1878 - d. 1944). Being an American Foreign-National (though coming from Philippine parentage) residing in the Philippines, I was amazed to have realized that I came into the movie with more than a rudimentary knowledge of modern Philippine History. This movie excelled in portraying President Quezon in a very "larger-than-life" person (who historically was very much so). Yet, at the same time, the movie seems to convey the impression that many artistic liberties were taken to make the movie more entertaining rather than to be a more historic portrayal of the real Quezon. Notwithstanding, the movie does not shy away from asking ground-breaking questions such as "How far will one go to ensure the independence of a nation?"

There are different entry points on how to read Quezon. Perhaps the most urgent for me to look at, is its distribution and promotion — how its coining of "Bayaniverse" has transmuted to multiple efforts of sustaining its captured audience from Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018). In these ongoing attempts of serving its captured audience, Quezon has both failed and served them at best. By constantly challenging and deconstructing our ideals of heroism, Quezon has to eventually hurt the Pinoy pride, which I personally found an achievement. Sometimes, to offend the audience is to serve them best. By structuring a film (or films) within the film, Quezon mirrors what many of us refuse to see and can't yet actively confront, that our eventual participation in the culture of patronage politics has built the Duterte - Marcosverse.Meanwhile, I couldn't help but realize that Goyo is actually my favorite of the 3. It renders a cinematic language mostly spoken in a spiritual context: deep diving in introspection of our personal and collective complexities.

an interesting film that doesn’t glorify a hero but instead reveals the ultimate truth, the other side of the coin. we’ve all read about quezon’s achievements and contributions to the philippines, as textbooks often portray him as an untouchable figure. but are we ready to see the other side of his story?i’ve always loved history since elementary school. it was one of my favorite subjects because it was easy for me to memorize important details. but that’s also the problem. we were taught to memorize history, not to understand it. we remember the names, dates, and events, but we rarely think critically about what they actually mean.that’s why this movie was so refreshing to watch. it connected all those historical terms and lessons i used to memorize, making them finally make sense in context. it’s no longer just information i learned to pass an exam, but a deeper understanding of the story behind it all.it’s sad to think that our government hasn’t changed even a bit from before until now. the same dirty political tactics, corruption, maneuvering, and patronage politics still exist today. it’s truly disappointing that the philippines hasn’t progressed at all under this kind of politics. i just hope that in the near future, our country will no longer be filled with politicians, but with genuine public servants who truly care for the people.

Jerrold Tarog’s Quezon is, quite frankly, a bold attempt to deconstruct a “national hero” long revered through the sanitized lens of our school textbooks. I appreciate its almost relentless flow of exposition, which, despite its weight, is presented with precision and clarity rather than coming off as tacky. Jericho Rosales’s portrayal of Manuel Quezon is, for the most part, spot-on and convincingly delivered—he truly understood the assignment. Moreover, regardless of any controversy the film may have sparked upon release (such as outrage among Quezon’s direct descendants), Tarog’s vision remains clear: to reveal what politicians are truly made of, how their facades unravel when stripped bare, and how they continue to pass down the same traits to future generations.

No wonder Quezon's grandson's nepo baby ass was so angry (kinda funny, though). Needless to say, the film highlights how crucial for us Filipinos to critically examine our leaders, their use of power, and political ambitions, especially during these trying times in our politics.

Obviously this film says a lot about how politicians operate in the Philippines, something that I had very little insight of until recently. It neither condemns nor glorify Quezon. You get to ask yourself if the risks and compromises were worth it. As you see how the man slowly corrodes his ideals because he plays the game too well. I hope that when the time comes for me to vote in any upcoming election, I can see the game being played in front of my eyes.Also, when the Ramon Magsaysay post-credit scene dropped I shed multiple tears.

I appreciate how this film challenges the notion of being a “Bayani” differently compared to Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018).The film isn’t afraid to show that Manuel L. Quezon was a deeply flawed and problematic person despite all his achievements and contributions in helping the Philippines understand and reach independencia.(Random funny side note: It tickles my brain every time they say “independencia,” and when they curse in Filipino with their thick accents.)It’s necessary to have narratives like this every once in a while because people tend to put others on pedestals and perceive them as flawless and ideal individuals. This is dangerous because idolatry leads to leniency, leniency leads to conformity, and conformity leads to collapse.Everything breaks down when we put the weight and responsibility of an entire country on one person alone, instead of recognizing that it also takes an entire nation’s worth of people to create change.This story is socially relevant not only because of our current political landscape here in the Philippines, but also as a reminder of the importance of looking back on our history to ensure we never repeat the mistakes of the past.The film is also masterfully crafted on a technical level and is arguably the best in the Bayaniverse so far. The direction, cinematography, editing, staging, musical score, and performances from the entire cast. They all shine here. Every single department that worked on this film fired on all cylinders, and it shows.There is also a level of playfulness present here (Mostly because of the score, staging, and performances) in the film that I really appreciate. It’s like a new flavor being introduced for the Bayaniverse and I welcome it very much.It was exceptionally made and definitely one of my favorite films of 2025. I hope to see more films like this from TBA Studios.Better stay for that mid-credits tease!

two words: revolutionary cinema. quezon, amidst multiple opinions stirred due to its ability to challenge main character norms of being picture-perfect or blatantly evil, has set the standard for philippine cinema to begin questioning the authenticity of our history and our roots. it obviously did a great job in personifying such a glorified figure like manuel quezon, who used to be seen as a national hero, but upon exiting the cinemas, its really got you asking what is real or not. is he really worth the praise he’s been receiving from the filipino nation?other than that, they successfully portrayed the flaws and beauty of philippine politics; how ugly it can get, and how it has always been up to the nation’s voices to determine whether or not they want to receive the treatment they deserve or not. it mirrors current reality without being too complex to understand, it embodies the philippines as a whole, kumbaga perfect fit talaga ang tagline ni quezon na “I am the Philippines.”jericho rosales was stellar, karylle was empathic, mon confiado was agitatingly pitiful, and jerrold tarog was superb. you can see the consistency of the arts in his craft, encapsulating every detail of quezon’s life into his bayaniverse vision that translates beautifully into the soul of philippine cinema. walang patumpik-tumpik in all movies of the bayaniverse, hence, the emergence of what i call revolutionary cinema. more films like this please! and more movie goers to encourage fellow filipinos to come see them. let’s utilize our homegrown talents to possibly bring upon the change our country needs.

Of all the Bayaniverse movies, Quezon (2025) is arguably the most polarizing. I'll try my best to condense my thoughts, organizing them based on meta analysis, historical truth, and social commentary.In its most meta, Quezon (2025) stands to subvert audience expectations with its characterization of Manuel L. Quezon. In Tarog's previous films, he sought to shed a more sympathetic light on misunderstood figures of Philippine history. Portraying Luna as a passionate and enlightened man, Goyo as misguided and young, and even Aguinaldo as complex and misunderstood. However, how could he showcase the story of a man who's well-beloved by a nation? It's in the best interest of many to concede that although polarizing, Quezon being characterized as the progenitor of patronage politics is on brand for Dir. Tarog. Luna and Goyo were already established by key aspects of their stories, either by being hot-headed or accomplished and young. Jerrold Tarog's brand has been to take what the audience may know and provide a different perspective, thus explaining Quezon's diva tantrums and arrogance. However, the question remains—Is it historically accurate? From my understanding of the film, Tarog already sought to answer those questions within the film itself. Accuracy and truth is greatly influenced by the filmmaker, her patron, and even preexistent ideas of who a person is. History is not my career, thus I can't provide a professional opinion on its accuracy. What I can say, however, is that if Tarog's own opus is be trusted—he, the director, is merely a man. He is not infallible and thus, the truth as he knows it, may not entirely be what it is. Historical accuracy cannot simply be based on its costuming and subtle details in props, but also the integrity of the story itself. Lastly, the movie is obviously a very nail-on-the-head commentary on politicians whose personal ambitions are hid thinly behind a persona of nationalism. It feels like a jab against growing populist sentiments, but antagonizes the greedy who sought to reap its benefits with little sincerity. It explores how the formula for gaining power as an ambitious, dynastic politician has never really changed in the past century or so. Unless the people themselves are willing to start questioning the integrity of the people they sought to empower with their votes, for every disgraced politician another corrupt politician will take his place. Perhaps I'm reading too much into this, but Quezon (2025) feels like some sort of cinematic social experiment that Jerrold Tarog gave us. He's seen the power of Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, perhaps this is just him leaving a movie that's on-purposely polarizing so that the people can be forced to think about the credibility of everything they see. Even if not his intention, it's great to see this play out.The movie was enjoyable and the stylistic difference definitely ties into how we're in a brand new era of Philippine history. I'm hoping to see a similar thing be done with any of his future works

I'll be honest, I didn't know much about Manuel Quezon outside the fact that he's considered a national hero—and a bit about the questionable land acquisition practices in the establishment of his namesake city.And not being a huge fan of biopics, I was just hoping for a nuanced look at a national hero.But holy shit, this pulled no punches. Quezon is portrayed to have learned the worst of the political game from the Americans. Effective? Incredibly so. Honorable? Nope.I had to pull up some recordings of him afterwards, Rosales absolutely nailed his cadence. The acting here was incredible. The cinematography some of the best I've seen from a Filipino movie. And best of all, it LOOKED like a movie. This was cinematic.And surprising for a political biopic, this was a blast. It was hilarious. It didn't take itself too seriously (or seriously at all, really).Maybe those more familiar with the story will be annoyed by the heavy use of exposition, but I found it to be helpful. I'm not here to shit on anyone else's national heroes—I've got plenty of American historical figures I can do that to. But, this does do a great job of depicting how Quezon's style of politicking, and selling off his country's resources to the highest bidders, seems to have led to the rampant levels of corruption seen today, 100 years later.Added to My Filipino Film Diary

A scathing and surprisingly humorous indictment of Quezon and his supposedly scummy character, so much so that it enters caricature territory, but I'm reminded of Tarrog's overarching project of interrogating what a bayani means. This is supported further by the dimension that the film adds to Aguinaldo who was a clear villain in "Heneral Luna." There's a dearth of (good) films about history and politics in mainstream contemporary Filipino film, so I was pleased to see some unconventional editing and cinematographic choices here that are more common in foreign biopics. The incorporation of the silent film was a clever device all around – a way to deepen the fictional Joven's story while beefing up the commentary on media as a tool of propaganda, a cost-cutting yet effective touch on the artificiality of celebrity politics, a self-aware reflection on how history is written by the victors. Rosales' transformation is a thrill to watch and a testament to the ripening of his craft but I was also really captivated by Sarmienta's performance. Sometimes the script sounds like it's lifted from a HEKASI textbook but it's forgivable for people like me who need the refresher course.

With memorable performances from the cast, compelling storytelling, and masterful direction, Quezon (2025) deserves to stand and be praised on its own. Still it’s best viewed as the final installment to the Bayaniverse trilogy. In this lens, we really see Jerrold Tarog’s thesis throughout the series: “Ang pagkabayani, it’s all about perception.”Heneral Luna (2015) showed a hero with unrivaled passion and patriotism. John Arcilla’s Luna is a hero people wanted to rally behind and emulate. He was branded as a leader who could have saved the Philippines, if not for the infighting between the revolutionaries. Yes, he was a flawed character, but you wanted to root for him. Never mind that he never won a battle – his profound love of country made up for it. The timing of the film also couldn’t be more perfect — it was released during an intense rise in populism. The film arguably contributed to Rodrigo Duterte winning the 2016 presidential elections, but that’s another story.Goyo: The Boy General (2018) was more subdued. There was no way to replicate Luna’s fiery personality and Arcilla’s performance as a cussing, temperamental general, so it was only natural to take another approach. Paulo Avelino gave life to the young, inexperienced boy general. In history classes, Goyo was often described as a martyr who died for his beloved country. The film portrayed his conflict – was he really loyal to his country or only to Aguinaldo? Was his sacrifice heroism or blind servitude?Quezon depicted a trapo’s rise to power. Jericho Rosales’ Quezon showed ability to pull all the tricks in the book: propaganda, lying, self-serving alliances, politicking, patronage politics. He wasn’t the first to do them (and we know from our daily experiences now that he’s not the last), but he no doubt mastered them. Describing him as a chameleon was an understatement. Always performing and projecting what the other side wants him to be.More importantly, Quezon brought the trilogy’s thesis full circle. The film, like the two before it, argues that heroism is not black and white. “Ang pagkabayani, it’s all about perception.”The film within a film device effectively blurred the lines between reality and fiction. The switching between different Quezons (the old version, the young version, the fictionalized young version), the nonlinear storytelling and changing perspectives, further served to confuse the audience about objective history and revisionist recollection.But the film’s biggest and most-rewarding bet is making Joven Hernando (the audience surrogate) an active participant to the story. By showing that he can be swayed by narratives, blinded by his own biases, be bought, but ultimately speak truth to power, the challenge is flipped back to the viewer. How should we view heroes? When we know that they “get their hands dirty” with politics; they forge convenient alliances; they stage publicity stunts; they do everything not for the greater good, but to push their own ambitions. How should we question our leaders and speak truth to power when we can also benefit from them if only we played our cards right?Looking at the trilogy as a whole, it is clear that our heroes, despite their contributions to the nation, are flawed individuals. Despite their larger-than-life personas, they are just people too. Like us. The whole time we were focused on the titular characters, on supposed saviors we have preconceived perceptions on. But this conclusion just reminded us we ought to look at ourselves and our relationship with these heroes too.

I didn't know what to expect when I first walked into the cinema, but I'm glad I went to see this film. It took me a beat to remember who Joven Fernando was because it's been so long since I saw the two earlier films, but once I remembered it made me appreciate the decision to insert an audience avatar into this remix of Philippine history. It's not a perfect film and it leans too heavily on exposition several times (e.g. one character notably sketches Quezon's pre-presidential career in the space of a minute, as if he were reading from a Wikipedia entry), but as a whole I enjoyed the creative decisions made and the liberties taken. The best thing about it, by far, is the performances by its cast. Jericho Rosales, Cris Villanueva, Romnick Sarmenta, and Mon Confiado in particular were wonderful to watch. (I also enjoyed Iain Glen as Leonard Wood, though at times the accent wasn't quite there.) I can already hear the arguments that are going to bubble up because of how politicians and the people are rendered in this film--but then aren't those arguments the point?

As someone who really enjoyed Araling Panlipunan in elementary and junior high school, and a huge Bayaniverse fan—watching this film was an absolute treat for me. (Not to mention the outstanding visuals, humor, and score in this film, absolute chef kiss!)I love how it went beyond the usual, surface-level lessons we get in school. I remember learning about the Tydings–McDuffie Act back in sixth grade and wishing we could explore it more deeply but was ultimately met with disappointment when we only touched on it briefly before moving on to another topic. That being said, hearing familiar names and events in this movie made me geek out so much. More than that, I truly appreciated how it gave a deeper look into Quezon’s life and not just his role in our history. I liked that the film showed his flaws and his “dark games,” making him feel more real and human.Without giving away any more spoilers, this film is both thought-provoking and relevant today. It leaves us with something important to reflect on: to question, to stay aware, and to take an active role in shaping our nation. The future is in our hands—we must act before it changes us.Lahat ng bagay ay lilipas din; darating ang panahon na ang mga pangulo at mga nasa kapangyarihan ay bababa rin. Nawa’y magsilbing paalala ang pelikulang ito na matutong mag-isip, maging mapagmatyag, at tumindig para sa tama. Huwag tayong maging uto-uto. Oo, the world isn’t simply black and white but I do hope that we try our best to choose what’s right. Overall, this is a good end to the bayaniverse trilogy. Concluding the Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon is a battle of wit and strategy, a game of outsmarting and outplaying in a race for political power that ultimately shaped the past, present, and future of the Philippines.I love how it incorporates a filmmaker’s perspective through Nadia, as well as the return of Joven, now older, and the reemergence of journalism at the forefront. This use of cinema itself as a device to propel the narrative forward makes it compelling, seamlessly blurring the lines between fact and fiction, much like how the main characters easily manipulate these concepts.Despite clearly steering away from the literal warfare of the previous two installments, the film still manages to grip audiences through a high-stakes chess match between the titular character and his rivals.

This is a sarcastic, disturbing, yet timely deconstruction of a well-loved president. The comedic score provides a striking contrast to the film’s portrayal of how the war for independence has shifted from the battlefield to closed-door deals and political maneuverings. Beyond the stellar performances, cinematography, and production design, what stands out most is how the film compels its audience to reflect on the fact that the “trapo” politicians we see today have existed long before.

Had a great time with this and it's a refreshing injection of optimism for the Philippine cinema scene. Love that our theater was packed and our audience was constantly engaged with every bit of dialogue, every Rosales enunciation, and every plot turn - the theater experience definitely amplified it. I cannot emphasize how lovely it is how this film ignited film discourse that I haven't felt about a local movie in a while since Heneral Luna.Jerrold Tarog's direction and screenplay with Rody Vera feel so ambitious in its approach to this type of film. The confidence seeps through every scene and how we're carried through scene by scene through its Hollywood level production design, editing, costume design, and unique biographical structure. Always been wowed at the idea of Joven Hernando and who he represents and this is all the more captivating as what transpires in this film. I felt like it may have some minor pacing issues that don't really tank the movie but it might've helped to have certain scenes/sequences a bit tighter.Jericho Rosales makes up for not looking like Casey through his fantastic line deliveries and not breaking a sweat while embodying this fascinating gray area of a man. Confiado (loved his presence very extra this time), Eusebio, and Villanueva also give fantastic turns as mostly returning cast members while Kris Villanueve takes over Joven easily. I missed you in this one, Epy as Mabini.As the emphatic period to TBA Studios' highly impressive Bayaniverse trilogy, it felt appropriate enough to lean more into the Oppenheimer-esque epic tale as opposed to just giving us another Luna story. This is not an action-packed war flick but rather a captivating portrait of political power plays, American colonial dynamics, and the roots of so many of our problems today. I'm sure there's more to take away from it and I'm going to continue browsing the internet to find out what else - that's what makes this movie-loving thing so much fun.

Aesthetics and design-wise, they definitely nailed it.Story, plot, and historical authenticity-wise, they flunked it. I think a majority of viewers, myself included, would expect a creative educational interpretation of Quezon's life, as opposed to a travesty of him through making half of the movie a glorified gossip show; conjectures right and left. This movie missed out so much, Quezon's childhood, career during the Philippine Revolution and the Philippine-American War, and his helping hand towards the fleeing Jews during the Holocaust. The story feels so inadequate and incomplete, so much missing puzzles.

WOW. WOW. WOW. WOW.Can't believe that's the conclusion of the Bayaniverse trilogy, a mere transition from the violent Revolution to the ego-driven politics.From the epic and fierceness of Heneral Luna, from the heartbreak and beautiful sights of Goyo, now to the perception of heroism through Quezon.Echo really killed this role, alongside Sarmenta, Villanueva, Confiado, and Sir Iain Glen.He really is one helluva egoist ngl. Love the callbacks to the previous films, the flashback scenes of our previous leads, the callback to the "Ang tao may damndamin ay hindi alipin." scene and the fierce energy and the tons of PI and PYTA based from Heneral Luna, the quotes from Pule (Mabini) and the beautiful color grading from Goyo, and notable characters from the respective films!I feel like theres gonna be fanfics about 70 (Quezon x Osmeña). They had such chemistry in this film more than their spouses.Throughout the Bayaniverse, this just shows that in history, there are no heroes and villains, just humans with flaws. From each film, we learn about each characters' traits and flaws that are something we can learn from them. Like our fav character throughout the trilogy, Joven Hernando, we are the observants, observing the two sides of a coin of each sides. Our voice may be silent as we watch, but the truth and the voice we yearn for is loud.What a nice conclusion to the trilogy, thank you TBA and Direk Jerrold Tarog for giving us great movies that we can go back and learn all about our country's history. Onto the new era...the Panguloverse."Our democracy will die...kung wala si Magsaysay..."

Quezon Thoughts:Production wise, medyo similar vibes siya sa Heneral Luna. Pero instead of war, dirty politics ang topic. May fave character since HL. Kaso dito for some reason parang di na siya yung eyes nating viewers, parang part na talaga siya ng current cast. Di ko makuha yung Joven vibes kahit nandito yung actor na gumanap sa last 2 movies. Isa pa, parang under utilized siya sa ending. Yung anak niyang si Nadia parang cutout from that era talaga. May vibes siyang ganon ang ganda ng pagkakacast. Di ko magets yung cameo ni Cong at Iza. Ang random. Yung kay Iza parang iisipin mo na may malaki siyang character sa past movies dahil sa reaction niya pero wala naman??? Si Cong akala mo di solid north eh. Medyo nakakaawa si Aguinaldo dito. Lalo na nung pinaalis siya sa farm at tinanggalan ng pension. Dumi ni Quezon. Pero katulad niya mga pulitiko ngayon. Medyo nakakamiss Mabini-Aguinaldo tandem sa movie na 'to. Sayang deads na si Mabini, nakakamiss presence niya. Galing ni Jericho Rosales. Biggest what if si TJ Trinidad eh pero galing din naman ni Echo. Grabe yung pagkadramatic niya, yung accent, yung vibes niya with Sergio(old man yaoi sabi sa twitter). Galing ni Echo i portray yung kahambugan at kabwisitan ni Quezon. PS I hate it nung sinabi ko sa tatay ko na nanood ako ng Quezon at ang reaction niya is "ay gawa gawa lang yan eh".

Akala ko noon, tanga ang mga Pilipino, gaya ko. Ngunit habang tumatagal ang buhay ko sa mundong ito, unti-unti kong napagtatanto na napakatalino pala ng mga Pilipino — sa maling paraan nga lang.Gaya nga sa pelikulang ito, ang mga matatalinong may kapangyarihan ang patuloy na nagpapabilog sa atin at sa ating bayan… na para nga ba tayong kulangot.Isang malaking kahihiyan sa hanay ng matatalinong tao, ng mga Pilipino, ang mga itinuturing bayani ng ating bansa. Simula noon hanggang ngayon, ang mga namumuno sa ating bansa ay itinuturing pa rin tayong mga “laruan.” Kapwa Pilipino nga talaga ang papatay sa ating bayan. Kailan kaya natin makakamit ang totoong independencia?Gusto ko lang ding sabihin na: MABUHAY ANG PELIKULANG PILIPINO!Salamat sa ating mga malikhain na kababayan; nang dahil sa inyo, patuloy pang mabubuksan ang isipan ng ating mga kababayan.Mahal ko ang Pilipinas, pero ang mga Pilipinong alagad ng sining ang nagpatibay ng aking pagmamahal sa ating inang bayan.

I can’t deny that the reactions and condemnations expressed by some of Quezon’s descendants are valid. No matter which angle you look at it, the film portrayed a negative and unflattering image of Quezon during his lifetime.From his beginnings as a lawyer, to his time as governor of Tayabas, Senate President, and eventually as President — the movie showed how deeply rooted traditional politics was, even back then. Maybe they were the ones who started it; the methods may have changed over time, but the goal remained the same — to gain and keep power.It’s hard to accept that our own ancestors might have been the ones who taught us how to become monsters in the world of politics — corrupt and power-hungry. But hopefully, this film serves as an eye-opener for all of us — a reminder not to repeat the same history. May it inspire the next generation of public servants to have a genuine love for the country and to serve with true integrity and sincerity.

“I got one more in me,” exclaimed Jerrold Tarrog as he laid the finishing touches of his 3rd film in this ironically-titled Bayaniverse.Wilfredo Garrido has this scathing accusation that Quezon in its entirety is a hackjob in itself. It's very easy to glean the bias from which his status update after watching the film errs on, and I feel the need to start from this note because by no means does the film really sit on the fence.In fact, and if I may declaratively highlight in all its fictional and non-fictional aspects, Quezon sits as one of Jerrold Tarog's best pieces for being able to angle this part of history in a way never really seen. The recurring clamor for a film that talks of the Philippine Commonwealth has been something desired of, and Quezon being able to position itself in this manner is a welcome one.At the end of the day, one is left sitting at Quezon and possibly thinking about how the Philippine government is fundamentally a government of demons of all shapes and sizes. If you come out of this film arguing that the film itself makes Aguinaldo look like a saint (someone on Twitter says this), you may want to rewatch Heneral Luna as the center of all this is a series of heroes who are profoundly individual at their core, espousing social values and claiming to be champions of the greater good.Addendun: Raymond Red during a talkback of his Bayani (1992) screening earlier recalls the uproar he faced from the academic community for being the first to depict Aguinaldo as a piece of shit. In a way, history corrects itself down the line and one could only glean that reception towards Quezon will face the same developments.

I had the chance to experience watching this film in the Cinemas. Jericho Rosales as Quezon didn't disappoint, as well as the other actors. I love cinematic scene shown at first, the silent film theme one made by Nadia where he was portrayed as a good guy for his campaign, even though the contents of it are far from truth and how we're watching from Joven's perspective because the contents of the film revisiting Quezon before entering politics and during it is all in a film made by Nadia, a second version with more truth contrasting what she had made for his Ninong for Presidential Campaign. My thoughts on this film is that they executed the film really well. It showed their flaws, not just their good side. I like Joven Hernando's character, he's a fictional character but represent us really well. All of his lines really aligns with what the audience thinks when watching the film. From supporting and believing Quezon to questioning him and eventually criticizing him. It also reminded me of how Schools always teach and portrayed them as great heroes, but never really show what's behind the door. Osmeña's character is someone easily swayed with sweet words and Quezon took advantage of that, leading, swaying him with his words even though they've had their own disputes—rivalry turned allies. Roxas's character is like a child, easy to be pawn. Quezon's character was portrayed as someone good at playing a game at politics, he knows how to play his cards very well; using every tactic and opportunities just like how he used Patriotism and Independence as a Propaganda. They also showed Quezon's side being a Womanizer and portrayed him as someone always concerned with good image in the public—although his bad side was shown, it still wouldn't erase the great things he did but it's refreshing to see that this film didn't glorify anyone. It instead showed that even these people in the end of the day are Humans. They're not perfect or saints, they have their own flaws. You can also see how our government back then still mirrors our present government. Corruption isn't new, it has always been there. There's a lot of things that you can realize watching this film, I wouldn't really rely on it for accuracy, after all it's mixed with fiction, myths and certain rumours for humour, that's why it's still better to research thoroughly. Overall this is a great film, Jerold Tarog and Tba Studios never disappoint! We need more films like this, tackling our own History.Truth is a great ideal, but you can't always use it to rule.I'm the Philippines I will lead this nation to Prosperity

VIVA FILIPINO CINEMA !Edit: OK REVIEW TIMEfirst of all wow, what a joy to watch. Nothing is amiss for me in this whole film. It's polished, clean, everything fits. I LOVEEEE THE PLOT DEVICES THEY WERE USING IN THIS WHOLE FILM.. first the film within a film and the COIN, oh the coin... THE SCORE... DAWG.. THE SCORE. Amazing, beautiful, sarap sa ears...Jericho Rosales... wao... i would say this is his best work yet. He's not jericho rosales at all here, he's just Mr. President Quezon yes yes ! This gave me so many laughs. It's so CLEVER.. I have never been so loud in a cinema before, THAT'S HOW GOOD IT IS. I must say, after learning about lighting in my internship, i gotta appreciate the lighting so much more.. SOBRANG SARAAAAAAAP. the colors, yes yes yum... THE SET DESIGN YUMYUMYUMThis whole thing is a MASTERPIECE. Although we must be careful of what it actually means. It does not try to cancel what Quezon has done or Quezon himself, rather show the other side of the coin (haha get it) of what it took for him to bring us to wherever he took us. And I must say, how Jerrold Tarog presented it, does indeed answer what it means to be a "Bayani".This is a favorite.. I have to watch this again... P.S. so this is the root of capitalism huh?

Body and soul?Jerold Tarog's "Quezon" narrates a period of our history that mirrors the current state of politics in the country. Men in power takes advantage of the other men in the circle and, when its not convenient anymore, easily, casually dropping them dead. History, almost 100 years ago, is repeating itself. The dirty tricks, power-hunger, and betrayal that happened under the Commonwealth government employed by President Quezon are not new to me. My history lessons, albeit shallow, have taught me that while we recognize the efforts of our forefathers, they were after all human and susceptible to corruption. It is politics afterall. What surprised me tho is how this part of the country's history was presented through this film. The cinematography, sound production, and set designs, and of course the acting (especially Jericho Rosales) were beautifully blended considering the theme of politics and history. Should you watch it on a big screen? YES-- its a no-brainer.
When Filipinos learn to accept that our politicians are not perfect, flawed, and should not be held in a higher regard than an ordinary person, then maybe we will see a true change in our society.

After watching Quezon, I wondered: what was the director’s goal in this movie?While discussions suggest that the intention was to reveal the flawed person behind someone most people consider a hero, I can’t help but ask—then what? What did it aim to achieve after that?For me, it merely opened up a controversy without offering any resolution. It’s similar to hearing endless news about corruption in the country without actually seeing justice served. Has anyone even been jailed yet?After tarnishing Quezon’s name and linking him to the culture of political patronage and under-the-table negotiations, what was the movie really calling for? This is one of the things I find lacking in the film.I was also confused about Jericho’s acting choices and the director’s decisions regarding narration. I understand that comedy can be an effective way to deliver a message in a relatable manner, but to me, the message—still unclear—was blurred by the slapstick. Tarog's disclaimer at the beginning and his response to Quezon's grandchild also did not help in his attempt to convey his message.And really, is that an attempt to give redemption to Aguinaldo?

Wrapping up a trilogy about the Philippines' revolutionary past with a relatively uneventful political biopic about some unremarkably corrupt politician really is a bold and interesting choice. Moreover, Quezon really is a rejection of the two films that came before.By no fault of its own, Heneral Luna is one of the most misunderstood and bastardized cautionary tales about patriotism and masculinity I've seen in my lifetime. Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral is a bitter demolition of the mindless jingoism and fascism that Heneral Luna became synonymous with. Finally, Quezon is a eulogy to the Philippines' revolutionary hopes and idealism; a resignation to a pathetic country's inescapable doom under so-called Great Men and self-proclaimed patriots.Problem is, Quezon is also the weakest of the trilogy from a structural level. Its transition from a winking mockery of the cosmic joke that is Filipino government to the bleak demystification of Quezon's self-made myth isn't as smooth as it could've been. The film's dragging length is impossible to deny by the midway point, though it's understandable given how long Quezon's story is. Worst of all, a literal half of Quezon's dialogue is a preachy lecture told at the audience. More than once, characters stop everything to become mouthpieces for the ideologies they represent and the timely commentary they embody. None of this is diegetic, and it's as awkward as it sounds. I also don't really jive with how the film ends by blaming the Filipinos for things and bastards they can't control. I too am disillusioned, but come on now with this ivory tower shit.Then again, after seeing how Heneral Luna's point was deliberately ignored, used to prop up a murderous shithead, then basically losing a decade in the process, I'm not too surprised by Quezon treating Filipino viewers like a bunch of gullible idiots who need everything to be spoon-fed at least twice.

2025 RankedTBA Studios RankedBACKGROUNDThis franchise is one of the most unique franchises out there by connecting Philippine historical films with each other into a singular cinematic universe, which is distinct from those that are fictional in nature. There are fictional elements in these films, but they are overall based on true events. It may not be as popular as other franchises that have existed for decades, but it does not have to be, considering that the number of movies are three so far. Regardless, it is still a franchise that I am going to look forward to for its next entry.POSITIVESThe gap between Quezon from the previous film, Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, is seven years, which could be a bit too long to wait, but it was worth it because I did not expect for the third installment to turn out to be the best in the franchise so far. The tone and style of filmmaking was different compared to its predecessors, which reflects how much Jerrold Tarog has grown as a filmmaker. The choice to use the early stages of film as a way to reflect and criticize him as a leader not only adds more creativity and style to the film but also reflects the phase of technology at the time, and how it can be used as a powerful tool to spread influence. The storytelling is not straightforward or linear, but it is organized into chapters based on who Manuel Quezon has to face or deal with in order to rise in power. It is an approach that I did not expect, but it is a success for being able to tell a cohesive story. Jericho Rosales's portrayal is one of the aspects that I was looking forward to seeing in the film, and he succeeded my expectations. He has so much command, control, and confidence in his performance. His enthusiasm and charisma match his goal to elevate his status by playing "mind games" with his opponents. This puts the audience in an unsettling position because it becomes clear the kind of leader Manuel Quezon was. There are moments that would make me feel the intensity and pressure as I am piecing out the next moves of each player and the events that could happen. The production design was impressive that made me wonder about how they were built or where they were located. I also admire the various use of cinematography like panning and tracking to make the film livelier and to set the tone.MIXEDI was really impressed by the editing of this film, but there is a particular scene where the editing did not work for me because I felt that it did not fit into its tone. This film has the most number of significant characters in the franchise and there are a lot of time jumps, which makes it a bit difficult to catch up with certain plotlines for me, but it is understandable because it reflects how complex and complicated the situations are.NEGATIVESDue to how plenty the characters are, some of them were not given enough depth. There are a few of lines of humor that did not work for me.CONCLUSIONIt is clear how the film wants Manuel Quezon to be portrayed, which they were able to accomplish. The tone and genre of this film may not be similar to the past films in the franchise like scenes involving gunshots, but its unique approach to the story makes it stand out from other Philippine historical films.

Gets ko si Joven. When you sit down and watch the film as it starts, highly likely you will suddenly be reminded of how Heneral Luna and Goyo went—the first two movies of Bayaniverse—and your expectation would somehow be related to those two. But Tarog did a different approach in Quezon, where satire is ultimately obvious, as much as it is also intended to be taken seriously. The fast-pace approach, the quick-changing of scenes, the conversations which aren't dragging, and riddles exchanged between the characters. These same characters delivered well and Tarog made sure the comedic stance are appropriately placed where necessary. It's just that for the majority of the time, I have this moment where the scenes are already at its peak, only to be steered in a different direction since, clearly, this film wants to tell more. I guess 2 hours will never be enough. I've always admired how he interpreted Luna and Goyo in a way that is culturally and politically provoking, yet easy to grasp, relate to, and branches out even more questions. Looking back at the Quezon film, it’s hard not to realize how little we’ve actually progressed as a country. We never truly learned. We forget too easily, and us being gullible, though partly not our fault, continues to hold us back. That's why it's vital that a fictional character like Joven Hernando comes in as a storyteller. We need a narrator that subtly contributes to the narrative, yet obviously part of it. He witnessed three generations of it all, with his perspective changing and honing, and revolving with the three personalities - Luna, Goyo, and now, Quezon. We are Joven. And would you ever disagree with Joven knowing that to our core, he is the representation of us all?Joven proved that as a nation, we want change. But individually? We really just wanted to survive, to focus on our families, to build our career around the things we love doing the most. At the same time, we want to see our country thrive, see it receive its deserved peace and rightful independence. We believe it's ours to begin with and no one should take that away from us. That's how us, Filipinos. We struggle to keep moving as a progressive nation because our minds are cut in half—in many pieces for some—because we have a lot to think about. Sa dulo ng bawat araw, karamihan sa atin gusto lang umuwi, magpahinga, at siguraduhing kinabukasan ay may pagkaing nakahain sa lamesa. Kaya gets ko si Joven. Kung nalinlang man siya, kung napaniwala man siya nila Luna, Goyo, at Quezon, at kung kumapit man siya sa kakarampot na pag-asa mula dun sa tatlo, hindi niya naman talaga kasalanan. Gaya ng karamihan, nagtiwala lang din siya. Kasi sino bang aayaw sa pangakong kalayaan para sa isang bansang inaabuso at kumakalam ang sikmura?As film goers, audience, and product of PH education, our role is to scrutinize and be doubtful, along with enjoying the film, because at the end of the day, a film remains a form of art, and art supposedly have its interpretation by whoever is looking at it. Truthfully, this is where the film draws the line—it cannot show everything. It's up to the audience to make their own research and form their opinions.

had the privilege to watch this last October 12 and let me just say that i enjoyed it very much.Manuel Quezon was the original politician of the Philippines. he knew how to control the people and how to get what he wants. i do believe he ran as a government official to help the Filipino people and gain independence from the Americans, but once you get a taste of fame, money, and power, those intentions can be easily forgotten. this movie came at the right time as it shows similarities on how our current government looks like. we are in the hands of fickle-minded politicians who only care about themselves. it's upsetting how even 90 years later we are still in the same mess. i always envy how other countries have better transportation systems, better work opportunities, and just better everything just because they were served by people who want real change in their country. still, i would never stop dreaming for real change in our country, and i feel that this movie gives hope to its viewers. amazing performances from everyone in the cast, the message/story was clear, and can't wait to support more Filipino-made movies!!

Source: www.reeladvice.net/2025/10/quezon-2025-movie-review.htmlThe war is over, and now the battle is set in the world of politics. Quezon takes us front and center into the seemingly heroic life of Manuel L. Quezon - a personality Filipinos look up to as a hero, a visionary, and one of the nation’s key founders. But much like its predecessors in the Bayaniverse franchise, the film tackles head-on the sheer humanity and fallibility of Quezon, questioning whether the ends justify the means in the battlefield of power and the making of a young nation.Manuel L. Quezon (Jericho Rosales) has just won the 1935 elections, becoming the first elected Filipino president and the second president of the Philippines. But the journey to win that coveted and historically significant seat wasn’t an easy one, and you don’t get to the top without getting your hands dirty and making a few enemies along the way.On its third outing, the Bayaniverse comes full circle by slowly shifting from the action-packed Heneral Luna to a somber drama in Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral and finally to a full blown political drama in Quezon. The literal battles here are replaced by heated confrontations between Quezon and his contemporaries, showing how he fought and negotiated his way through power by any means necessary. While we can’t say for sure if every revelation in the film is historically accurate, this is far from the textbook version of Quezon we grew up with. This is a human Manuel Quezon up front and center. One who is charming, cunning, and deeply flawed. The film hits hard, especially when viewed against the backdrop of today’s political landscape, reminding us that the people we idolize are often far more complicated than their public images suggests.The film’s chapter-based narrative structure was something we appreciated, breaking down Quezon’s political battles into distinct segments. However, the pacing felt uneven at times, with one chapter taking up a disproportionate part of the runtime. In terms of performances, though, everyone delivered. Mon Confiado stood out as a somber, grounded Emilio Aguinaldo, while Jericho Rosales embodied Quezon’s ambition and deceitful charm perfectly. We found ourselves surprisingly invested in Quezon, and by the time the credits rolled, it hit us hard much like the other Bayaniverse films. Like before, it left questioning whether the struggles we face today were shaped by the same heroes we’ve long revered. As a potential bookend to the franchise, Quezon closes the trilogy in the way we hoped it would which is powerful, reflective, and important for Filipinos.
