Strong messaging and great acting overall, but it still had to rely on lengthy dialogue and monologues to get the important message across instead of only letting the characters' actions speak. It's not hard to excuse, given how Heneral Luna was often used by DDS to draw positive parallels between Duterte and the general.My tiny nitpick: the lines sometimes sound too modern, especially Nadia's.

if history were a movie, Quezon would be the scene where the lights stay on too long where the glamour fades and all that’s left is the politics, the pride, and the people pretending not to notice the cracks.i went in expecting something noble, something textbook. but what i got felt… human. painfully human. quezon (jericho rosales, absolutely magnetic) isn’t painted as a saint here he’s ambitious, clever, exhausted, and aware that being “good” doesn’t always win you the game. it’s that messy, moral middle ground where idealism meets ego, and somehow that felt more honest than any patriotic speech ever could.and then there’s aguinaldo. he’s not the villain not really. he’s just another man trying to keep his version of the world alive. it’s poetic in this haunting way that the movie reminds us: he was supposed to die early, yet outlived everyone. quezon. roxas. the whole lineup. and that irony? it stings. like history laughing quietly in the background.but what hit me hardest was how quezon shows corruption not as an event, but as a tradition. it’s not a scandal that shows up one day it’s baked into the foundation. this movie doesn’t even need to say it outright; you just feel it in every handshake, every campaign promise, every smile that lasts one second too long.by the end, i wasn’t just watching a historical biopic it felt like a loop. like we’ve been here before. same speeches, different microphones. same dreams, slightly more polished lies.Quezon isn’t perfect, but maybe that’s what makes it hit. it’s hopeful and heavy at the same time like loving a country that keeps breaking your heart but you can’t walk away because it’s yours.

If there’s an alamat of the pagiging Pinoy TraPo, maybe this is it... the origin story of politics as performance... (just for show, performative politicians )."Masyadong maraming pulitiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan."I hate history classes, but I love revisiting history through travel, museums, and movies.  Quezon (2025) is exactly the kind of film that makes history come alive...even for those who never liked it.It’s funny, sharp, and feels like a political satire about the past that mirrors the present. The film follows former President Manuel L. Quezon’s political rise and how he played the game of politics brilliantly, but not always cleanly. If there’s an alamat of the Pinoy trapo, maybe this is it -- the origin story of politics as performance (just for show).Jericho Rosales nailed the role of Manuel L. Quezon. I’ve seen clips of the real Quezon before, and every time Rosales spoke, it felt like I was hearing the late president himself. They don’t even look alike, but he captured Quezon’s spirit perfectly. Benjamin Alves, who played the younger Quezon in the silent film sequences, also impressed me. Alves could easily carry the role in a full-length version too.Supporting actors also deserve credit. Romnick Sarmenta (as Osmeña) complements Rosales well. Karylle, as Aurora Quezon, was charming but underutilized, perhaps reflecting how women were sidelined back then. In contrast, Angeli Bayani, playing Aguinaldo’s wife, had limited screen time but left a strong impression. Mon Confiado’s take on Aguinaldo was refreshing, showing a more vulnerable side (though I still have to see the other movies in the Bayaniverse). Arron Villaflor and Cris Agustin, as Joven Hernando, were remarkable too,you almost forget they’re fictional characters.Though a biopic, the movie plays like a satire. It’s unserious but smartly so funny, biting, and painfully familiar. The humor lands because the parallels with today’s politics are impossible to ignore. Everything feels like "pang front lang" and the nation’s welfare often comes second to pride and image.As I said, it might just be the origin story of the Pinoy trapos. Maybe Quezon didn’t invent dirty politics but as Joven Hernando puts it, he perfected the game.By the end, you’ll find yourself asking: What does independence (independencia) really mean? Are we truly free, or have we simply learned to believe we are? Maybe it’s like Plato’s “noble lie”, a story told to keep people hopeful, obedient, and proud. Tayong mga Pilipino, ika nga ni Romnick Sarmenta bilang si Osmeña, “hindi naman tayo kulangot, pero bakit tayo binibilog?”Maybe it’s because we love beautiful stories, stories that let us escape, even when they blur the line between truth and illusion. Kailan kaya tayo tunay na lalaya mula sa mga politikong inuuna ang sarili bago ang sambayanan?at ’yun na nga... nabilog na kc tayo. Marahil, just like being a hero, independencia is often just a matter of perception.(i am just wondering how Quezon's descendants would react to this movie)

There were so many layers to this film but it did not feel overdone. I left the movie theatre feeling like i have a lot to unpack. But one thing's for sure: thr political climate in the PH js just one big production. Everything is curated. "Masyadong maraming politiko sa bansa, kaunti lang ang lingkod bayan." --- almost a century later and we still fall for the same old tricks.Among the 3 Bayaniverse movies, the storytelling format of Quezon is what I enjoyed the most. Since MLQ is more of a political figure rather than a wartime hero, there were more interior scenes rather than landscape wide shots (which I loved from its 2 predecessors -- Heneral Luna & Goyo). Still, it felt like they're in a battlefield where one must fight in order to survive.Kudos to all the creatives behind this, for always using their art to disturb us, the comfortable masses. Madaling makalimot tayong mga Pilipino, at napakadali nating maniwala sa pangako ng pag-asa. As painful as it may be, pero baka nga hindi pa tayo handa sa independencia -- until now most people don't even know what that word means. Or maybe, we were never really truly independent because we never had the chance. I didn't know one could feel hopeful and hopeless at the same time, but right now this is our reality, and the longer we let ourselves be run by the likes of Quezon, the further we are from having true independencia.

guys before i give my review i just wanna brag that jericho rosales came to our screening and literally spoke in front of my seat and i was able to give him a handshake.ok now to the actual review:Jerold Tarrog’s vision for the Bayaniverse is just commendable. this was by far my favorite from the franchise– from the storytelling down to the cinematography. the creative decision of telling the contrasting story of Quezon through the silent films was chef’s kiss– it was unique, entertaining, and well crafted. this was a good contrast to the benevolent portrayal of Quezon in Quezon’s Game. being a hero is all about perspective.i greatly enjoyed this film. hence, here are my footnotes:negatives:1. the "eh yung ____" "sa susunod po" sequencing became overly repetitive.2. wdym third and final installment??? DAGDAGAN. charpositives:1. the first thing i noticed was the characterization of quezon. i applaud the great effort and commitment it took to get the accent, speaking voice, and mannerisms in line. jericho rosales did a fantastic job. i think it's about time to give filipino actors a chance. 2. i appreciate the stance of joven in this movie. his character embodied what it meant to only see one side, to only want to see one side. it highlighted the importance of understanding bias and what it truly means to be a citizen—to weigh both sides and to pick the lesser evil.3. oh emilio aguinaldo you morally grey silly goose. i think the switch of aguinaldo's characterization here greatly emphasizes that things are not black and white. things are not simply good and bad, evil and pure. human as we are, our actions are multiple colors. aguinaldo is an example of that. i want to praise mon confiado for being exemplary. it takes incredible skill to have his character be hated on the first two movies, and be pitied in the next. bravo.4. great cinematography, music, and pacing. i love the use of colors and songs. also great use of creative and artistic freedom.5. what great mirroring. these series of events happened decades ago, yet still apply to our current politics. why do we never learn? why do we allow ourselves to keep being played over and over again? remember: politics is a game to the wealthy, but the lives of the poor. my god, wake up!6. fund the paper. fund the films. fund the art. i so so appreciate the film emphasizing the importance of art and how it can directly influence people's views and opinions about certain topics, nuances, and even people. art is the driving force. art is just as important. and in this modern world where we see art as less, let us be reminded that the beauty of art is the power of human race.history is important. we must continue to learn our past so that we are able to unlearn and re-learn.history is not just the past but the guide to our future.'wag na tayong pauulit-ulit. the present is also the history. today will be yesterday. kaya, now's the time to write the narrative that the future will live. ika nga nila, history repeats itself, diba? mamulat, makibahagi, makiboses!

A decade ago, Jerrold Tarog asked the Filipino audience what it really meant to be a hero. With his Bayaniverse, he aimed to deconstruct the heroes that we've come to know during our history lessons as kids. In Heneral Luna (2015), he showed us the fiery and passionate patriotism that is willing to do anything to protect our freedom. It introduces the idea of mythmaking, as it positions the entire Philippine–American War into the hands of its protagonist, and by killing off the only person who could have led us to victory, the government simply proved that our biggest enemy was not the Americans but our own Filipino countrymen—ourselves.Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2018) breaks this down further, showing us that the hero we glorified all this time was nothing more than a blind fanatic who died a futile death out of his arrogance and lack of experience—all this time, all he had to offer was this confidence and loyalty to his president, and nothing more. Then came 2025's Quezon. As he states in the film:"Ang pagkabayani—it's all about perception" (Being a hero—it's all about perception).Becoming the hero means you get to decide whose story gets to be told and how it is told.In this third and final installment of Tarog's Bayaniverse, we follow the life of Manuel L. Quezon (Jericho Rosales), who would go on and become the first Filipino elected to head a government of the entire Philippines after 34 years of being governed by American governor generals. All throughout the film, we see him in different stages of his life through different chapters, depicting how he manipulates his way from the bottom to the top, including his conflicted relationships with Sergio Osmeña (Romnick Sarmenta), governor-general Leonard Wood (Iain Glen), and even his former president, Emilio F. Aguinaldo (Mon Confiado).Penned by Tarog and Rody Vera, this concluding chapter of the Bayaniverse trilogy is a fun, engaging, yet biting and farcical take on its titular character's meteoric rise and eventual downfall. Intending to portray the historical figures in the film series often regarded as national heroes as "flawed characters," the film, while showing the achievements they accomplished, also shows their cunning and manipulative tactics to get where they wanted to be.The best comparison I could come up with for Quezon is Orson Welles' 1941 film, Citizen Kane, which also features the rise and fall of its main protagonist (Quezon even opens with a series of silent films, similar to how Citizen Kane introduces its main character through a series of newsreels). It's structured similarly too, told in a nonlinear narrative. Unlike Heneral Luna and Goyo, Quezon is divided into several chapters, with each of these beginning with Quezon headbutting with someone to achieve his goal, highlighting how he played many political games to secure his survival and to maintain his power. Another departure for the film is its setting—while the first two films are set during the Philippine-American War, this latest film explores the period of American political supervision that followed, eventually leading to the founding of the Philippine Commonwealth. It doesn't have the big battle scenes of his first two predecessors and instead focuses on the war they fought within their offices and desks. Unlike its predecessor, whose battles occur in sweeping landscapes and terrains complete with all the explosions and gunfights, Quezon is mostly confined in enclosed spaces and is more dialogue-driven.It's also the most visually imaginative film in the trilogy, as it incorporates a series of silent films to create the myth behind Quezon's heroism. The film creates different tones to emphasize the varying timeline and mood for several sequences: black-and-white color grading for the silent film sequences, a vintage palette look to depict the time of the young Quezon (played by Benjamin Alves), realistic and vibrant three-strip Technicolor for the old Quezon, and a dull and dreary tone for Aguinaldo. This also highlights the difference between the way the public embraced Quezon and Aguinaldo's candidacy—one with color and life, while the other was marred by the death of Andres Bonifacio and Heneral Luna. The film's production design managed to stay true to its milieu too, beautifully captured on camera by Pong Ignacio, who returns from the last two films.Most importantly, the film depicts the evolution of two of the trilogy's most important characters: Joven Hernando and Emilio Aguinaldo. In the film, Joven is played by Arron Villaflor as the young version, while Cris Villanueva is the older one. Unlike in the first two films, where he is depicted as merely an observer for the two titular heroes, here in the third film, he becomes an active participant in the story. However, he is no longer the reliable narrator that he once was, as we realize that he himself has turned a blind eye to Quezon's flaws as an individual and as a politician. On the other hand, the film looks at Aguinaldo with a gentler and softer view, portraying him as this weakened veteran who tries to fight against the giant that Quezon eventually turns out to be in the film, falling victim to his propaganda.And this is where the film's strength lies: with its powerful cast. Mon Confiado delivers a more nuanced turn here as the veteran Emilio Aguinaldo, perfectly complemented by an equally restrained yet compelling performance from Angeli Bayani playing his wife, Maria Agoncillo-Aguinaldo. Arron Villaflor is brilliant as always portraying Joven Hernando, but Cris Villanueva adds another layer of depth to his character. Benjamin Alves also has an interesting part in the film, as he portrays the young Manuel Quezon but also as the actor portraying Quezon within the silent film world, existing on two separate planes and blurring the lines between fiction and reality and between the revised history and actual memory. Of course, Scottish actor Iain Glen deserves a special shoutout for his portrayal of Governor-General Leonard Wood. Karylle also deserves some praise for her understated yet exquisite performance as Aurora Quezon. Romnick Sarmenta also impresses as Sergio Osmeña. But the one who really carries the film from start to finish is none other than Jericho Rosales, with his committed performance as the titular Quezon. Honestly, I was expecting Manuel L. Quezon to have a somewhat full and deep voice, but when I saw the videos of his actual speeches, Rosales nailed his pitch and tone. It's fun to see Rosales as Quezon manipulates his way through politics using one trick after another. He dazzles with his stirring and dedicated turn as the late president, warts and all.Rosales perfectly captures the cunning nature of his character—a two-faced Janus head who uses deception and whispers sweet nothings to charm and manipulate everyone around him like chess pieces. With Quezon, Tarog delivers his ultimate thesis statement: that heroism isn't black or white. We have to understand the grey areas in between. The heroes depicted in his trilogy did a lot of good things that led them to be celebrated as the heroes they are known as now. But like any other human being, they also did some pretty bad things—and Quezon, sadly, did a lot. He inadvertently paved the way for patronage politics, or the spoils system, to take over our government—one that is still prevalent today. His intentions started out as noble—he wants to give the Philippines the independence it has sought after for so many years. But along the way, he realizes that he has to play by the rules, bend some promises, and ultimately lie for what he believes is good for the country. Sadly, the things that he did led him to crave and hold on to his power for as long as he could.Later, Quezon exclaims:"I am the Filipino people. I am the Philippines." He spent the entire film creating this image of him as the only person who could bring independence to this country—by hook or by crook. But as we see his final image in the film, we all come to the very conclusion that Quezon is nothing but a megalomaniac. He is not the savior he thinks he is. He is but a man.Flawed. Fallible. Mortal.

I always had a keen interest in history. I think this started with my likes to learn about what happened before and knowing all these famous people that the cartoons and shows I watched as a kid that keep on referencing, such as Thomas Jerferson, Benjamin Franklin, etc. This was further cemented by the social studies classes we had that focused on historical events of the world and the like. Philippine history was one and this led me to be more appreciative of what we went through as a nation. Naturally, this pushed me to more interested with movies that portrayed this events, even tho they weren't as accurate to what they wanted to represented *Ahem* El Presidente *Ahem* Fast forward to the release of Heneral Luna and Goyo, I was blown by how the films tried to show these people with a degree of understanding that wasn't as seen in previous historical movies portraying Heroes. Luna and Goyo made me feel angry and surprised, respectively. And now with Quezon, rarely do I get to see Philippine cinema being continued like this. One that continues to show how the past can be a reflection of what we are today, especially when it comes to politics. Its dirty, bloody and downright a game to some. I was sceptical at first with the announcement of Jericho taking the role of Quezon. All those worries faded once he got lost into this performance as the convicing, and coniving, president. Past and new characters were also introduced, adding so much to the story and how they all relate to one another. They portrayed well the friendly banters, conversations, and even betrayals. This connectedness and being one in a shared universe is amazing and works well with this film and the films before, even if each one feels different and stands on their own. The Bayaniverse feels like a proper universe and one that I wish for more Filipino films. This is a culmination of trying to define and portray heroes in ways that don't treat them to be outright heroes. No, these are people who are both perpratrators and victims of their own aspirations, dreams, agendas, laurels and even mistakes. This further pushes us to question those who led us before, and even those who lead us in the present. I'm looking forward for more films like this. And judging from the movie, I have a good feeling that there will be more!

Hindi kasing emotionally charged ng Heneral Luna, o kasing tahimik at mapanuri ng Goyo, ngunit may sariling bigat at diin ang Quezon. Dito, ang digmaan ay wala na sa larangan ng putukan; nasa entablado na ng pulitika. At gaya ng lahat ng magagandang palabas, bawat ngiti, bawat pakikipagkamay, at bawat pangako ay may kasamang pinag-ensayuhang pananalita.Jericho Rosales delivers one of his best performances yet: charming, makinis, pero mapanganib. Bilang Manuel L. Quezon, hindi siya ipininta bilang bayani kundi bilang isang politiko na marunong maglaro ng sistema. Hindi niya winawasak ang istruktura ng katiwalian; siya mismo ang bumuo nito. Ang trapo sa katauhan ni Quezon ay isang masalimuot na larawan ng kapangyarihan. Nakakatawa siya sa kanyang karisma ngunit nakakikilabot sa likod ng ngiti, kung saan namamayani ang tuso at mapanlinlang na pag-iisip.Ang direksyon ni Jerrold Tarog ay mas pulido at teatrikal kumpara sa unang dalawang pelikula. Halata ang diin sa blocking, sa staging ng mga eksena, at sa simbolismo. Parang chess match na bawat galaw ay may kapalit. Ang cinematography ay malinis, kulay-aristokratiko, at puno ng simetrya, na tila ipinapakita kung paanong ginawang perpektong entablado ang politika. Ang musical scoring naman ay naglalaro sa pagitan ng dalamhati at panunukso, na tila tugtugin ng isang entablado kung saan ang kapangyarihan ay ginagawang palabas.Hindi ito kasing-sakit ng Heneral Luna o kasing-lalim ng Goyo, ngunit mararamdaman mo ang maruming realidad ng politika. Naroon ang mga kasinungalingang nakabalot sa magarang retorika, at kung paanong ang kalayaan ay maaaring gamitin bilang produkto ng kampanya. Dito mo makikita kung saan nagsimula ang mga siklong hindi pa rin tapos hanggang ngayon: utang na loob, padrino system, at ang walang katapusang pagbilog sa ulo ng taumbayan.Tarog closes the Bayaniverse not with a scream or a whisper but with a smirk. Isang paalala na ang ating bansa ay itinayo hindi lang sa dugo ng mga bayani kundi sa galing ng mga manlalarong marunong tumaya. Sa dulo, hindi mo alam kung matatawa ka o maiiyak, dahil ang pelikulang ito ay parehong kasaysayan at salamin: mapanlinlang, maganda, at masakit tanggapin.Hindi ito aral tungkol sa kabayanihan; ito ay babala tungkol sa kapangyarihan.Sa pagtatapos ng Quezon, tila tayo ay nanonood ng salamin na bumabalik sa ating paningin. Dito natin nakikita na ang politika ay matagal nang pagtatanghal, at ang mga aktor ay nagpapalit lang ng kasuotan. Ang palabas ay nabago na ng panahon, ngunit ang manuskrito ay ganoon pa rin.

Small kwento: We saw Mon Confiado before watching the film kasi may surprise talkback session siguro before our showtime. We asked for a photo, then ang sabi niya sa amin: “Please review the film. Bad or good, it’s okay.”I actually didn’t want to watch Quezon yet kasi gusto ko may talkback. I really wish every screening of Quezon had one. Somehow, it’s not enough that we just witnessed what happened on screen. It’s also important to have a discourse about it.I understand that would be difficult and probably impossible to do for every showing. But it's a nice to have. Jerrold and the cast spent months or even years researching these heroes, and it feels lacking if all that effort just ends in a two-hour movie. I’m sure there were stories cut short or ideas that couldn’t be fully explored. It would’ve been so nice to hear more about it directly from them.So we ended up dissecting the film among ourselves after watching. The first thing we all said was how Quezon made it so easy to understand Manuel Luis Quezon. The film is divided into chapters, and in each one, it’s clear who he’s up against and what they are fighting about. And in every chapter, he always comes out winning.Quezon is unafraid to exhaust all his resources and even resort to dirty tricks to gain the upper hand. He can come up with unorthodox ways to defeat his enemies, and sometimes, he even teams up with them to take down bigger and badder ones. Quezon is just good at what he does. But he also thinks so highly of himself as the savior of the Philippines that it eventually becomes his downfall.It’s all very interesting. Like Luna and Goyo, Quezon is deeply flawed. In our minds, he's a great president for bringing independence to the country. But we all agreed that we never really saw Quezon this way before. It’s also amazing how the old problems in the film mirror the issues we still see in Philippine politics today. Maybe even worse.I’d say Quezon is a must-watch. We had a blast watching it, and it’s even better when you get to talk about it afterward with friends or family.

The third and final film in the Bayaniverse film series, Quezon is an eye opener for every Filipino that only know Manuel L. Quezon in the history books. The film showed Quezon's true color and the tricks and machineries he used to gain political power. If history can tell, mud slinging during the election campaign season has been a part of Philippine politics since time immemorial. It is ingrained in our culture and it will never be removed.Tarog and Vera's screenplay is also impressive. The Bayaniverse is now completed and I hope this does not ends here. Tarog and TBA Studios should continue telling the Philippine history post-World War II. The Bayaniverse is a true testament that Filipinos will spend their hard-earned money in movie theaters if a local film is executed well with great storytelling and screenplay.

I love this movie because this isn't perfect.How these “heroic” figures are portrayed as flawed as they are and just paints the whole message of this Bayaniverse trilogy to look them up not as idols, but because of their principles.You will not root for Quezon because of his apparent manipulation to gain power and you will also not root for Aguinaldo because he is incompetent. “The Philippine Assembly is yours—body and soul.”#QUEZON felt pretty much of a movie closer to our present day than did Heneral Luna and Goyo. I suppose it could be because of the timeline, but the events in this movie mirrored the present more harrowingly and realistically.I must say that my favorite scene in the film has to be the scene when a hauntingly troubled Aguinaldo was climbing up the stage in what pretty much seemed to be a miting de avance some time before the 1935 elections. When it was Aguinaldo’s turn to speak, he rose from his seat and walked towards the stage as the charming Quezon climbed down parallel to him. The background music intensified. The room did not know of the weight of the moment for Aguinaldo—only he and his Vice Presidential running mate Raymundo Melliza knew of what seemed to be their greatest leverage in the elections and against Quezon for all we know. The living evidence was there, present in that one corner—Quezon’s alleged first wife—a seemingly powerful instrument that could determine Quezon’s reputation. Aguinaldo had a smoking gun. Even I sat in the audience wondering, “Would he drop the ball?” Though Melliza was right in saying that they had no formal proof that the woman and Quezon were indeed married, the positive assertion could spark reasonable doubt on the perceived savior of the Philippines that is Quezon. The visibly horrified, pale-faced Quezon was standing aghast—would Aguinaldo get his own hands dirty as well? Perhaps, Aguinaldo’s option not to pursue the scheme significantly supported the image he had throughout the film: a noble, self-redeeming character in the nation’s struggle for independence who played the bigger man and refused to revenge out of spite.Another interesting point that made me leave the theater with more questions than answers was the re-introduction of Capt. Janolino, the man who made the first blow on Hen. Luna upon alleged orders from Aguinaldo some three decades ago. History tells us that Ka Miong purportedly sent four telegrams to the general, instructing the general to meet with him in Cabanatuan. Janolino sent the first attack, striking the general in the face while the others followed suit. In the film, Janolino was brought to Joven, the fictional figure, in order to clear his own conscience and finally become the man who lived to tell the tale. Janolino told Joven that his conscience no longer could contain the guilt, and that Aguinaldo indeed ordered the Luna massacre while handing Joven one of the four telegrams.History is not just about going back to the past, or connecting it to the present; it, too, is about questioning the narratives that we have long grown up believing, and more importantly, questioning what really was the truest truth about the motives of the people that shaped our history, yes, even forty, sixty, or ninety years apart. There is no question that Janolino was a blessing that came to Quezon’s lap at the right place and in the right time. We know the man. Quezon was too old of a hand in politics, or rather, in the craftsmanship of political manipulation. Quezon had Janolino as his final act of ragebait against Aguinaldo, leading to the latter’s eventual loss in the elections. But the question that left me mentally running in circles was, was Janolino really sincere in coming forward? Or was he yet another opportunist who took the chance to clear his name before anything happens to his life? Worst, was he yet another strategist who switched sides when it was most convenient to feast at the banquet of Quezon’s Senate as his Sergeant-at-Arms? We never know. We could only do so much as cast a doubt on true intentions, no matter how impractical, to really arrive at the truth. Was Janolino’s coming forward an altruistic move, or was it a plot to be thyself’s own saving grace? If you know the reference, good for you.Anyhow, despite the complicated cable spaghetti of neophyte Philippine politics, one can deduce but a single, unfortunate fact that not even Quezon, in a hypothetical redemption moment of his, could deny, and it is this: that corruption is as old as time, and that much of what we see today is utterly of little to no difference with what the country suffered before. It’s all a real déjà vu, only worse. “The Philippine Assembly is yours—body and soul.” If, before, the yours Quezon “sold” the people to are the Americans, now, the ones who sold the Filipino people and the yours these people are sold to are our fellow Filipinos: politicians who connive among themselves to lay bare the people as mere commodities. I am not so sure for everybody else but to me, that sounds like holding up a mirror in the face of Philippine history, except this time, the canon events seem more horrid.May the lessons of history cease to remain as lessons. May we make them cease to remain as lessons. Vote wisely. Think critically. Fight courageously.———PS: Props to Echo! A brilliant artist in the last of Bayaniverse trilogy. Great portrayal

“ Independence is good enough to eat “Quezon stands out from the bayaniverse movies that came before it — whereas Heneral Luna and Goyo had themes of war, Quezon portrayed political dramas, intellectual battles, and the performance of Manuel Quezon as a political leader. Quezon goes beyond its purpose of entertainment, it is a reminder of all the wrongdoings of our leaders due the mind games these leaders have instilled into our political system. The film is very timely for our political milieu, it shows how politics is like a game of chess — you take as much as you can from your opponent until they have nothing left. Politics aside, this film knows how to tell a story creatively. I enjoyed the “film within a film” aspect without it falling flat or cliché, I found it extremely satisfying. Cinematography ? FUTANGINA ANG GANDA. Every scene feels so cohesive and proper, like a political debate of some sort. I loved the juxtaposition between Quezon and Aguinaldo’s scenes — the loud and blaring music and overbearing lighting for Quezon, and the almost quiet and dull lighting for Aguinaldo. Everything was so tight knit and well executed and truly added more to the story. This film is truly thought-provoking and is definitely a cinematic experience as a Filipino.HM : putangina/punyeta counter when ?

i adore how the film transitions between fiction and reality, much like how history and fact are always muddied in the game of politics. it almost breaks the fourth wall at times—the language of film nearly breaking at the seams by design. i loved how they integrated joven, nadia, and miguel as both audience surrogates and parts of political machinery (excluding miguel bc my man knew what was up)the film tends to overexplain itself at times, especially in the first half when it has to get the audience up to speed on historical events. things are spelled out for you in ways that should already be obvious by just...listening to the dialogue and watching the damn movie. tbh this really was the only aspect i was pretty annoyed at by the film.once it gets past this is when the film feels most electric—you could cut the tension with a knife in the cinema i was in during the candidates' election speeches. jericho rosales absolutely kills it, especially when delivering quezon's mannerisms, way of speech, and subtle tics. mon confiado returns as aguinaldo, showing so many facets to him that you'd almost think to root for him. i wish karylle had more to do as aurora quezon—i could say the same for pretty much the entire female cast atp, who all felt a bit underutilized.as with the other bayaniverse films, these are always worth the price of admission (especially with the student and teacher's discount!). a bit rough around the edges, but sometimes by design which i appreciated. i can only hope people pick up the right lessons when they walk out the cinema.(intentional or not, the fucking congtv cameo jumpscare might be the funniest thing in this movie. the irony is INSANE)

The movie Quezon was really nice because it showed a different side of President Manuel L. Quezon that we don’t usually see in our history lessons. In school, we just learn that he was the first president of the Commonwealth and made Tagalog the national language. But in the film, he was shown as a kind and brave person who truly cared for people. One scene that touched me was when he helped the Jewish refugees during World War II. It showed how he wanted to save lives even if it was hard for him and his government.If I compare Quezon’s time to politics now, I feel like there’s a big difference. Quezon really cared about people, while some politicians today care more about fame and power. The way Quezon stood up for what was right reminded me that leaders should have strong values like honesty, courage, and compassion.The movie made me realize that our country needs leaders like Quezon—people who think about others before themselves. If we all had those values, maybe our society would be a better place.

Quezon definitely still suffers from the over-explaining this type of movies can get. You can still feel Tarog’s hand writing the audience into a corner where the “message” lies. Who can blame him? Even Rizal talked to the people of Calamba directly in El Fili. Maybe it is a feature of the Filipino art form. A feature I don’t like. This made me appreciate the deft rendering of Luna in Heneral Luna.If not for that, I think this would’ve been my favorite entry in the Bayaniverse. You feel all the people involved having fun while doing their jobs. You get used to the out of place existence of the Joven character by now so you just accept the somehow modern Taglish way his daughter talks because the previous entries have utilized him well. I didn’t notice the over 120-minute runtime unlike in Goyo.I will forever bang the drum for more Romnick Sarmenta roles. It was also refreshing to see JC Santos being treated the way Nolan treated Rami Malek in Oppenheimer (which is definitely an influence here). I needed more of the talky genre here though. Arcilla still holds the belt in terms of the acting chops in this trilogy but I loved that you never see any semblance of Jericho Rosales in Quezon. He completely embodies the role.

The press releases brand Quezon as the third in Jerrold Tarog's "BAYANIverse" trilogy, but it's quite clear early into the film that Manuel L. Quezon, the second President of the Philippines, doesn't quite live up to the term "bayani" or hero. Yes, he was instrumental in taking the country through its first steps into independence from its colonial masters, but the film also unabashedly shows him as manipulative, petty, and spiteful. Worst of all, particularly in the context of today's incendiary socio-political climate, the film explicitly blames him for laying the foundations for the patronage politics that has plagued the country for decades. It's certainly not stress-free viewing for those among us who are already anxious over our current national situation.If his highly skilled work on the gem Sana Dati and the first two entries in the BAYANIverse films, Heneral Luna and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, did not manage to convince you that Tarrog is one of Pinoy cinema's most masterful directors, this film should. His direction of Quezon is superb. Sequences are creatively and tightly shot, producing a beautiful rhythm that belies the films runtime of over two hours. The [silent] film-within-a-film is a very nice touch, showcasing Tarrog's ability to balance pathos and humor, and also conveniently explaining why young Quezon is played by another actor (Benjamin Alves) in the first two films. Jericho Rosales is pitch-perfect as Quezon. His Quezon is cocky and assured, but also vulnerable and volatile. Cursory surveys of old video and audio clips of Quezon make it clear how well former matinee idol Rosales captures the Commonwealth President's vocal cadence, but the way he moves his body, a lot of which is presumably not visible in most existing videos, gives him ownership of the character. Rosales has proven his acting mettle in previous turns in both film and television, but this is probably the role that he was born to play. Among the supporting actors, the highlight is Mon Confiado as Emilio Aguinaldo, owning the role to the point that it's probably difficult to think of any other actor doing it as successfully. Confiado is often an uneven and divisive actor especially when it comes to loud, overtly physical characters, but here he shows how skilled he is with more quiet, introspective roles. The ever-reliable Romnick Sarmenta as Sergio Osmena, Bodjie Pascua as Raymundo Melliza, and Angeli Bayani as Maria Agoncillo also give laudable turns. Meanwhile, Karylle, who is no slouch in acting, is barely given anything to do as First Lady Aurora Quezon, which is a shame because of Mrs. Quezon's stature in Philippine history.The technical details are admirable, particularly the editing and the production design, which provides a genuine period look and feel to the film. The black-and-white scenes give lenser Pong Ignacio room to play with light, but it's rather unfortunate that the makeup on the actors during those sequences makes them look like the ghouls from Herk Harvey's Carnival of Souls. The true standout, however, is the score (by Tarrog himself), which propels the film's pace with alternating whimsy and somberness, and it never feels out of place or overly used (which is very common in local films).Quezon is a true cinematic achievement. For both its quality and its socio-political message, it is must-see Pinoy cinema. Sure, it takes liberties with historical accuracy (the filmmakers are quick to disabuse us of the notion that it's meant to be fully historically accurate), but it asks the right questions, just as Heneral Luna did (remember its iconic "Bayan o sarili?" challenge?). Hopefully, the film's message does not fall on deaf ears and will further drive the social movement for true accountability and patriotism in governance.

One of the poems I memorized back in elementary school was actually about him, but it never really introduced me to who Manuel L. Quezon truly was or what his role in our history meant. Growing up, I only knew few of his personal and political life from HEKASI and Sibika’t Kultura textbooks, so watching the film was full of surprises, every twist and turn caught my attention and kept me hooked.The reason why I love the Bayaniverse series is because it doesn’t just retell history, it shows the lives of our national heroes and questions what truly makes them a hero… or not. Take him, Quezon, for example. I found myself asking, Was he really a hero? Or could he also be a villain? Maybe Quezon was indeed a hero in governance and nationalism, but also a politician with many flaws. Through this film, we saw his strong will, pride, and even arrogance.Jericho Rosales, who played Quezon, did an amazing job. Honestly, if I had known that TJ Trinidad backed out of the role, I wouldn’t have thought of anyone else who could replace him. When it was announced that Echo would play Quezon, I was doubtful at first, mainly because they don’t look alike. But after watching the trailer and hearing him on Quezon’s accent, I said to myself, “Ayos 'to!” and I was right. His performance made Quezon feel real and relatable, showing not just the hero, but the man behind the title. His accent was consistent from start to finish, and the rest of the cast did great too, especially Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio. And for the first time, Joven Hernando’s role actually made sense to me, even though he doesn’t exist in real life.The music? I loved it. Just wow. It felt like a roller coaster of emotions, especially during the tense moments. Every background score matched perfectly with each shot. And the cinematography? Definitely a step up from Heneral Luna and Goyo. I didn’t expect the “film within a film” concept, but it worked beautifully.Overall, it was a great film, probably a fitting end to the Bayaniverse. Totally worth every peso spent and definitely a must watch Filipino historical film. And now, we’re all just waiting for the next multiverse to begin.PS: Pasilip naman sa death ni Miong next time, please. Masyado na mahaba screen time niya.

Isa rin pala sa problema ko sa Bayani-verse ay para bang background lang ang mga babae sa kwento nila Luna, Del Pilar, at ngayon, si Quezon. “Masyadong maraming pulitiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan.”A timely end to the Bayaniverse trilogy!Quezon (2025) asks the question Tarog has been exploring since Heneral Luna and Goyo: what makes a hero?The film-within-a-film framing was clever, but it can create emotional distance. Also, when watching someone “perform” or “manipulate”, the audience may subconsciously hold back emotionally. So maybe that’s why I felt less connected to Quezon compared to Heneral Luna and Goyo. The film also has a tendency to over-explain things that could’ve been a subtext.It couldn’t have come at a better time, when people are holding leaders accountable and seeing through the spectacle. It’s a reminder that history repeats itself when we stop paying attention.TBA Studios deserves credit for keeping these stories alive. Filipinos need and want films that challenge, provoke, and remind us who we are. Watch this on the big screen and see for yourself how much has changed, or hasn’t.

Jerrold Tarog delivers his third and final (maybe?) act of his Bayani-verse, and while it may not be the conventional trilogy that we expect where it gets bigger and more spectacular with each installment, Quezon is more gut-wrenching, diabolical and closely resembles the truth we have today in politics. It successfully and awkwardly shows us a mirror that continuously slaps us Filipinos in the face real hard with questions about fake independence and our failure as a nation, after Heneral Luna (2015) and Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral (2017).Jericho Rosales played the role to the tee, an opportunity of a lifetime, with enough force and conviction. Other cast who stood out were Iain Glenn who played Leonard Wood and Mon Confiado's Emilio Aguinaldo. So entertaining to see Manuel L Quezon, Emilio Aguinaldo, Sergio Osmeña and Manuel Roxas, who I only used to see in paper bills, got brilliantly fleshed out on screen. Jose Rizal wrote Noli and Fili to provoke the nation para magalit, because anger signifies that we've had enough and that we need to take action. National Artists for Film Lino Brocka and Ishmael Bernal also did during Martial Law. Now Tarog, Jadaone, and other current film makers are raising the same flags so it is our duty to ask ourselves as a society. Many times I felt being pinched through the heart, kasi thats how its supposed to feel. Masakit marinig ang totoo, masakit aminin na kapwa Pilipino ang nagpapalubog sa kapwa Pilipino. Matagal na natin itong alam at naririnig, pero bakit paulit-ulit?

I saw a post a few years back talking about how Heneral Luna and Goyo implanted further in the minds of Filipinos and basically became propaganda for the Great Man of History. That those movies supported the wrongheaded idea that all the Philippines needs is one strong leader to prosper. This movie says no.Tangent but it's very funny that this has a mid-credit tease for Ramon Magsaysay and that this has been called the Bayani-verse. Imagine your cinematic universe just being the Philippines.

hmmMmmMmmAlways had a soft spot for Quezon, if only because of that face. Heroism is all about perception! and he looked the part, was a veritable statesman in his tailored suits. Insidious as the joke about the judge was, I could believe it. But as one should, I reckon with history and necessarily position myself from within contestation — a place the Bayaniverse likewise occupies. What comes out is an interesting, if a little heavy-handed, depiction of hero-making as practice, and the complicity of media in its propagation. Rosales is a good actor, but I do feel the movie could have benefited from someone not quite aware of the performance. It’s part of the project, of course, but Rosales-as-Quezon seemed too aware of the duplicity to be believed. It was only at the end, sick and brought low literally, that one would think he’s bought into the fiction. A shame, since I think it would’ve added depth. Still, I appreciate the obvious staging of it—the choreography, the conceit of the film-within-the-film—and I especially love that it’s Quezon who gets this treatment. If only I got what I was promised.

Jerrold Tarog is quite consistent. This film has both the faults and the strengths of its predecessors despite the change in tone and characters here. This trilogy sensationalizes these historical figures and is over-acted by much of its cast (although let's face it, that's a common issue within Philippine cinema), but it is also intentional in creating a narrative about the Bayani that makes a lot of sense when you look at the trilogy as a whole. Like the first two movies, this movie has so many odd creative choices where the intention is in full display but doesn't really serve the overall narrative. Case in point for this film, while the writing is funny at times, it feels so hollow because it's so evidently trying to get a laugh from its audience but fails in its purpose because it detracts from the story rather than enriches it. Many other such choices can be pointed out all across the trilogy. Overall though, I have to give Tarog his flowers. The trilogy has inspired renewed national interest in our history and revisits our national heroes in a way that invites us to re-evaluate where the education we received about them might have been wrong.

what an insightful dissection of quezon and his unfortunate legacy to the ph nation. it opens up a discussion of how patronage politics exploits our filipino values and how quezon played such an integral role in embedding this toxic practice into our country. pinapakita rin ng quezon kung gaano kasura-sura ang sirko ng politika sa ating bansa. ang sistema ng pamahalaan na itinatag ng mga amerikano ay elitista, na siya namang inabuso at kinasiyahan nina quezon. with critique on how media can shape public perception not necessarily aligned with the truth, the film drives these points forward through the characters of joven and his family. i agree though with the other reviews that the characterization could be better, and a lot of its points can be less on-the-nose.

The original UNITEAM

Body and Soul.Finally got to witness the end of a saga that I can personally say I grew up on. As someone who loves history the “Bayaniverse” is franchise close to my heart. This time we got to do a character study on Manuel Luis Quezon. A man who is a prominent figure of our history. A political chameleon as to how others describe him. Heneral Luna was the “dagitab” that started it all, Goyo is fine film that dealt with the immediate aftermath of its predecessor and Quezon is this franchise’s final salvo. The pacing of the film is good. I liked how each scenes was able to give tension and stakes. My only nitpick was how the first hour of the film had a slower pace and then as we approach the end it felt rushed but maybe this was made so that it echoes Quezon’s desperate cling to power he built. Each scene felt like a game of chess and it is what kept me entertained. As a history fan I love it when I recognize people or events the people on the film talk about. Jericho Rosales as Manuel Quezon? Superb. How he speaks, his mannerisms, his quips were all spot-on. It was like I was really watching MLQ. Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio Osmeña shower how resolve and silence can both be a good and a bad thing. I wish JC Santos and Karylle had more screentime as I believe their performances were also so good. Mon Confiado as an older version of Emilio Aguinaldo was also a delight to watch. Ibang iba sa mga naunang Aguinaldo and I saw comments na they pity the old man but the way I saw it it, it was his karma that came to bite him.Quezon is a different film from the first two, it is not riddled with guns and canons, there is no physical war. Sabi nga ni Wood “We are fighting behind desks” and this political warfare is entertaining, riveting, and at most times fascinating. Nilatag sa atin kung paanong ang isang taong magaling sa manipulasyon at pamumulitika ay pinapaboran ng panahon. Ipinakita sa palabas kung hanggang saan ang kayang ibigay at kunin ng isang tao para sa kapangyarihan. Pero masayang panoorin ang mga ito dahil ito ay pelikula, nakakalungkot na ilang taon at pangulo na ang lumipas pero nakikita pa rin natin sa mundong ating ginagalawan ang mga pangyayaring ganito. Baka nga nasa Body and Soul na ng mga sisteman umiiral ang ganitong katotohanan.

The most consistent thing about the Bayaniverse is that the series features some really good acting, and Quezon is quite possibly the most well-acted among the three. It features a huge ensemble of actors giving their best impression of the historical figures they are portraying, with Jericho Rosales and Romnicak Sarmenta lightening up the screens everytime they show. Sarmenta, in particular, is a complete scene stealer. Other than the acting and the pacing, Quezon is mostly lackluster in terms of storytelling. The film doesn’t have an interesting visual style, and its look doesn’t fit the ambition and tone it wants to achieve. The script, while commendable on its structure, features some really underwhelming dialogue that feels less punchy than its predecessors. Which is a shame, cause the dark comedy approach of Quezon gives the Bayaniverse another layer of intrigue: elections, in retrospect, are comedy puppet shows being run by puppet masters who are also attached to strings controlled by bigger masters.

As the Bayaniverse trilogy comes to a close, Jerrold Tarrog delivers his best one yet. Simula pa nung una, ang ating gobyerno ay itinatag sa maliliit na pabor na lumaki bilang utang na loob. Utang na loob na di na mabayad-bayaran. Totoo bang nakamit na natin ang kalayaan? Ang independencia? O ipinahiram lang ito sa atin at balang araw ay babawiin ito kapalit ng tulong ng ibang bansa?Pinanood namin ng mga kaibigan ko ang Heneral Luna, Angelito, at Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral upang maalala ang mga pangyayari bago kami sumabak sa Quezon. Isa pang nangyari sa akin ay pinanood ko ang Pingkian: Isang Musikal na storya ni Emilio Jacinto haka noong siya ay nagdedeliryo sa tama ng baril noong panahon ng himagsikan. Isa sa unang linya ng musikal ay ang mga katagang,"Doon sa Biyak na Bato, pinatigil ang putukan. Isinuko ni Aguinaldo ang apoy ng himagsikan!" True to his style, ipinakita ni Direk Jerrold ang tao sa likod ng pagiging bayani. Na kahit isang matalinong heneral si Antonio, siya ay mainitin ang ulo at mapusok. Na kahit si Goyo ang paboritong Heneral ni Aguinaldo, siya ay nababalot ng takot kung ano ba talaga ang kanyang hinaharap, at bilang isang bata, hindi niya rin alam kung sino talaga siya. Sa dalawang pelikula ay makikilala mo rin si Aguinaldo, ang ating unang presidente, na nakadikit sa mga mayayamang miyembro ng kanyang gabinete. Unang tumatakbo pag parating na ang mga amerikano, at dala ang kanyang buong pamilya sa isang mahabang lakarin.May tatlong karakter akong hinihintay na makita; si Aguinaldo na kabado ako kung ano ang kanyang magiging storya. Siya ba ay bibigyan ng redemption arc? Si Quezon na tuso at naging batayan ng political warfare sa atin ngayon, At si Joven na tumanda na. Ginawa upang irepresent ang kabataan, ngunit ano na kaya ang kinahantungan niya ngayon? Masaya akong malaman na lahat ng teorya ko sa palabas na ito ay mali, and it has exceeded ALL my expectations. Panoorin mo nalang kung gusto mong malaman kung bakit. Pero masasabi ko na sinasalamin nga ni Joven ang kabataan, lalo na ang mga kabataang ipinaglaban ang bayan noong bata pa, ngunit noong tumanda ay nahumaling sa mga taong ipinangako ang kalayaang kanyang tinatamasa, kaya nagbulag-bulagan sa mga maling gawain kapalit ng mabuti. The end justifies the means ika nga nila.Napakahusay ng pelikula na ito, sa direksyon, cinematography, sa acting (hindi si Jericho ang makikita mo kundi si Quezon), costume, at production. Halatang tumaas ang budget hahaha. Well versed kami ng kaibigan ko sa kasaysayan, dala ng guro namin noong highschool na napakagaling magturo ng AP st World History. Parehas naming minahal ang kasaysayan dahil sa isang guro na itinuro ang lahat samin nang buong pagmamahal. Pero hindi pa rin itinuturo sa mga kabataan ang lahat. Marami pa ring mga accounts na kung gusto mong makita at marinig upang mapagaralan ay kailangan mong saliksikin ang mga ito. Sana ma-engganyo ang mga kabataan na saliksikin pa ang ating kasaysayan, sa labas ng mga petsa, sa labas ng exams at quizzes. Dahil paulit-ulit lang ang mga nangyayari sa ating bansa. Habang buhay na ata tayong naka tanikala sa mga posteng gawa natin. Masisisi pa rin ba natin ang ilang siglo ng pananakop, o nasa dugo na talaga natin noon pa man ang sumpa ng kahirapan at kasakiman?

Quezon (2025): Jerrold Tarog At His Very Best.At its core, it positions the power of art and storytelling, both in good and in bad. Pure ragebait masterclass. Very entertaining. Almost blinding. With the gentlest reminder: History is dynamic. History permeates.

Politics is just a gameQuezon strips away the textbook hero and shows Manuel Luis Quezon as a cunning, manipulative politician. He uses friends, secrets, and dirty tactics to rise to power, hiding ambition behind a public image of virtue.The film forces us to ask, if independence required deception, selfishness, and manipulation, is that the only way to achieve freedom? Should history be judged by outcomes, even if the means were morally gray?Politics, Quezon suggests, is a game — to win, one must be ruthless. To lose, one may remain virtuous. Quezon embodies both faces: public heroism and private ambition.He did what we think he will, but we didn't how he did it. He is not portrayed here as a hero, but a man playing the game of politics. We achieve what we dreamt but the price, corruption and power hunger is the payment.So Is it wrong to be selfish? Or is it right for independence? Quezon answered both.

Quezon is a historical biopic of the Philippines’ 2nd President - Manuel Luis Quezon. Look what you can do with a big budget! Great cast! Jericho Rosales was a gem in portraying Quezon. Cris Villanueva did so well, with his very natural portrayal of his character, and of course - Mon Confiado as Hen. Emilio Aguinaldo, bravo!Jerrold Tarog’s direction and screenplay came out very strong and powerful in his 3rd “Bayaniverse” installment. Can’t wait for his fourth! This film, just like his previous ones - Heneral Luna and Goyo, mirrors the present through our past, showing how painful that we have not yet learned from the mistakes of the men of our history. This is a film that we should all watch. Every year, we should be able to tell this kind of story.Cast: Jericho Rosales, Benjamin Alves, Mon Confiado, Arron Villaflor, Cris Villanueva, Romnick Sarmenta, Iain Glen, Karylle, Jake MacapagalDirector: Jerrold TarogWriters: Jerrold Tarog, Rody VeraProduction Company: TBA Studios

We are genuinely fucked. It is heartbreaking that we are still in the same hell since the 1930s. As Quezon has said, “I would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by the Americans, because however a bad Filipino government might be, we can always change it.”And there we have, the seeds were planted and 90 years after, the seed had grown in a full blown tree and continues to spread in the years that was and will be. Unpopular opinion: We were never ready to be free. We can never be free until we understand the true meaning of freedom and independence. Up until now, we are still seeking for it but in a different context. Freedom from the seeds of politics and politicians whose intentions are for political survival but in the mask of public service. As I watch the film, it dawned in me that good governance will never materialize in my generation. I now know how it feels when we say, “Ang Kabataan ang Pag-Asa ng Bayan.” God bless the Philippines

Coming from the unbridled fury of Heneral Luna and the reflective nature of Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral, this installment takes us to the performance of nation-building, set not in battlefields but at podiums and facing cameras. Quezon, as the third larger-than-life figure, enjoys high production value as well, even if the centerpieces are explosive conversations and political machinations rather than fight scenes.Rosales as Quezon is a spectacle, with his high-pitched Tagalog-accented voice that mimics the gravitas of a transatlantic declamatory statesman. It matches, too, with the crux of his character being that of a man who learned from the Americans’ game of politics, and brought it back home. His performance and chemistry with the rest of the cast (namely his hilarious toxic yaoi push-and-pull with Sarmenta’s Osmeña and his dogged face-off with Confiado’s Aguinaldo) make a strong case for this film being the most entertaining of the three.Unfortunately, it may also be the one with the least heart in it. The senseless politicking and pandering to the promise of independence at any cost includes a pessimistic, self-referential plot point for the journalist character and his filmmaker daughter. The two fall prey to making propaganda for Quezon but ultimately can't make any definitive, concrete stand. It succeeds at holding up a mirror to the audience members watching, who decry corruption and bad governance, but cannot suggest or invoke any alternative. Quezon is a strong biopic and historical drama that satirizes politics through sensational slapstick moments starring some of the Philippines’ most known figures from the American period. For a dialogue-heavy film, it’s thrilling to follow thanks to its playful structure, making it stand out from its two predecessors which were mainly linear and battle-focused.What it didn’t really account for was the impact of Quezon’s actions. It only focused on the political spectacle that worsens the state of the nation and makes the dream of independence unreachable, even laughable. There’s a small scene where a farmer reveals that most people don’t understand what independence means. The film doesn’t explore beyond that — how the Filipino politicians and the American occupiers take advantage of this ignorance, what the average Filipino’s life is like, and why independence is such a pipe dream. Perhaps there we could have found the film’s heart.Full review here.

Manuel Quezon was an interesting politician, yet this film’s narrative structure managed to make him feel like anything but.We were told who Quezon is, but we were not shown who he is. For someone who was meant to be a charming snake, his character felt very flat. Which is a result of many factors: the narrative structure of reflecting on the past through the lens of one journalist, Jericho’s portrayal of Quezon lacking depth, and the dialogue missing any kind of subscript. Overall the film felt like a caricature of what it wanted to achieve. Did we really deconstruct the bayani, or did we throw Filipinos under the bus while Americans become the heroes?Not a bad film, definitely had the most beautiful cinematography in the trilogy. Wasted potential.

“utang na loob”a filipino value that still lingers the filipino society to this day, may it be in its smallest form or one that murks around the walls within our government: patronage politics. in the movie, it highlights how Manuel Quezon essentially gave birth to patronage politics in our nation’s government with how he deliberately moves around the walls of politics to set himself as the one with the most decorated achievements among his peers and foes. politics is a game for him. and in the end, he will use all his power to remain at the podium. all this to feed his ego. i believe that the release of this movie is relevant to the current issues Philippines is battling with today. just like Manuel Quezon, many politicians use “utang na loob” to their advantage, for their self-interest, which cost the lives of many ordinary Filipino people who are struggling everyday to make a living. moreso, this movie serves as a wake-up call to Filipinos that we must no longer be tolerant of how damaging patronage politics is to our society, especially on the topic of nepotism. i hope that one day, the concept of “utang na loob” will be redefined by generations to come. i hope that we open our eyes to see how this Filipino value has taken the route of submission to the one who has given you generosity. i hope that us, Filipinos, will one day, fully understand how “utang na loob” has impacted us in the grand scheme of things.

As the Bayaniverse concludes with the film Quezon, we are left to ponder: Who are truly considered heroes? Does Heneral Luna—who, despite his temperamental and tactless nature, led his men to fight for the country at the cost of their own lives—fit the mold of a hero? How about the composed and charismatic Heneral del Pilar, known for his loyalty to President Emilio Aguinaldo? Or is it Manuel Luis Quezon, the first President of the Philippine Commonwealth, who relentlessly championed the nation’s independence?Unlike the tension-driven Heneral Luna or the meditative Goyo, Quezon leans toward diplomacy and vision—the making of a statesman rather than a soldier. Mon Confiado, reprising his role as El Presidente Aguinaldo, provides a strong emotional bridge across the trilogy. His nuanced performance ties the films together with quiet power—a fitting irony, given how Aguinaldo outlived these three who once served under him. Jericho Rosales, meanwhile, delivers a commanding portrayal of Quezon—a politician who knows how to play the game of politics, both as one of the chess pieces and as the one who moves them. This may well be the most compelling performance of Rosales’ career. Rosales and Romnick Sarmenta, who plays Sergio Osmeña, show an undeniable chemistry that is utterly entertaining. This dynamic between Quezon and Osmeña is refreshing to see, and is something that I just discovered from the film.While the cast performed well and Tarog's vaudeville-inspired storytelling was interesting, there was no singular standout in the film. The attempt to encapsulate Quezon's life after reading through 50 reference books made the narrative feel dense and uneven. The intent to inform and educate was there, but it came at the expense of smooth transitions and richer character development. A minor subtitle error ("kada buwan" translated as "per year") is forgivable, but the lack of emotional buildup for the audience was a missed opportunity.Many historical moments were highlighted, yet the film fell short in conveying their emotional and moral implications. Still, the complicated feelings I had after watching it are proof that the filmmakers succeeded in presenting a layered, complex figure in Quezon.In the end, the Bayaniverse is more than a trilogy of historical films—it is a mirror reflecting who we were, who we are, and who we hope to become as Filipinos. Through Luna's fury, Goyo's doubt, and Quezon's ambition, we are reminded that heroism is not born from perfection or victory, but from conviction and purpose. Perhaps instead of searching for a hero to emulate or a leader to inspire today's generation, it may be far better to embrace a collective effort—despite our differences—to build the change we have long yearned for across generations. Tarog's decade-long storytelling, with all its flaws and brilliance, draws us back to the past that shaped us and rekindles our desire to strive for a nation better than the one we inherited.

The last entry in the Bayaniverse trilogy which aims to deconstruct historical figures. Kudos to the production design and the cast which was of high quality ever since Heneral Luna 10 years ago.Jericho Rosales did very well in acting especially on his accent. The film showed Quezon as this political figure who was great in playing the politics game. I liked how Aguinaldo mentioned the difference between being a public servant and being a politician. It was interesting to see the dynamics of Casey and Serging (Quezon and Osmena) and I found their conversations amusing. In my interpretation, the coin that Quezon gave to Joven is a form of utang na loob which is kind of rooted in our politics relating to the padrino system.I wish that the patronage politics was explored a bit more though.Personally, I would have liked this film even more if it had more runtime because a part of me felt they condensed all that they could into the movie runtime. I hope TBA studios gets to have miniseries for more comprehensive storytelling. All in all, congrats to the Quezon team and TBA studios for pulling off a wonderful Bayaniverse trilogy which I hope would just be the start of many more films to come.

The last of the Bayaniverse trilogy unfolds almost in tension with the first. While Heneral Luna (2015) almost glorifies nationalism and patriotism as the purest routes to independence, Quezon exposes a more unsettling truth: that nation-building, too, can be an enterprise of deception, politicking, and personal ambition.What struck me just as deeply was the film’s portrayal of the media. In the same way we inherited American politics and governance, we also inherited their media system. In the film, the two are almost indistinguishable. For Quezon, media is political machinery; politics, in turn, is media spectacle.To its credit, Quezon is an unforgiving dissection of a cunning man long revered in Philippine history as the architect of constitutional democracy. The film spares no illusions: it renders him not as a flawless hero, but as an American lackey who wielded independence as a political instrument for self-fulfillment. In the buildup to his presidential campaign, he is almost canonized as a saint, a portrayal that feels eerily symmetrical to the myth-making that defines our politics of today.I also think about Joven, how in Luna he was the youth whose fire needed to be fanned. Now, in Quezon, he was the people, blamed for falling victim to — and almost being complicit for having benefitted from — the very system of patronage. But the film offers more than this bobotante framing, as we observe Joven quite literally see through blind faith. Although the film had the tendency to slip into a romanticized treatment of Aguinaldo, it compels reflection on our country’s institutional memory. Why do we not know this Quezon: the ambitious, calculating politician beneath the marble statue? Why have patronage and our reverence for the West endured as the constants that anchor our political imagination? And why, almost a century later, do we find ourselves in the same predicament, still circling the same myths of power and nationhood?

ON THE THIN LINE BETWEEN THE PLAYER AND THE GAME Politics—a word that replaced guns and ships in a war that’s been raging in our motherland, the Philippines, since the 19th century. This film explores it with uncolored lenses—free of romanticism, yet filled with quiet truth. Let’s dig into the visual cues Jerrold Tarog, the director, orchestrated with precision and purpose:  THE BLOCKINGTarog uses blocking as a mirror of Quezon’s state of mind.When he believes…

“I am the Philippines”The clashing philosophy is the undercurrent that carries this movie. It isn't explicitly delivered; it's not visible on the surface, but it is deeply embedded for those who look closely enough. We witness the vivid interpretation of the rise and fall of a truly great figure, supported by compelling storytelling. The cinematography is strong, the acting is excellent, and the production design is surely top-notch.However, I can recognize that the movie's portrayal was somewhat tempered. We move from a brutal Luna and the edginess of Goyo to a Quezon who feels more approachable, child friendly, fun, and bright. Perhaps this interpretation reflects an intentional focus on Quezon’s charisma, or maybe it’s simply how the filmmakers intended for us to view his specific burden.I deeply admire the film's message—the political philosophy—and how acutely it mirrors our current government. It forces us to confront the question of how we arrived at this point. The answer, the film suggests, is woven into our history; the seeds were planted long before we were born. This system is so profoundly rooted that it cannot be simply plucked out. This, right here, is absolute storytelling. The core concept isn't forcefully presented to the audience; instead, the film allows us to arrive at the message through our own contemplation.There is much more to discuss, but the direction and storytelling are what I loved most. I can confidently say that those who see this as the least installment in the trilogy are missing the point. Each movie is a unique and great piece on its own. But Quezon—it delivers a sense of euphoria, emerging as a brilliant work of art that demands appreciation.

Ang lahat ng ito ay politika lamang, walang personalan.Just watched Quezon, and it awakened that history buff inside of me. Like Heneral Luna and Goyo, this was well done. It does complete the trilogy of what truly defines a political figure in the Philippine context. Its narrative and screenplay are peak, I adore the score, editing and art direction, and the production design was so good. Very interesting to see the early days of pork barrel, patronage politics, media "envelopes", and dirty tricks. Power play and mind game at its finest.Quezon, in its very core, is a film that presents itself as satirical, perhaps offering a timely commentary on the Philippines’ current political landscape and the ongoing struggle with personality politics. Themes including power and ambition just resonate with contemporary issues in the Philippines, sparking important conversations about governance and nation-building. I do commend Quezon’s portrayal here, as if he were a challenged hero who is worshipped. Jericho Rosales’ portrayal of Quezon was commanding; he brought depth and nuance to the role, capturing the former president’s complexities and leadership style. His performance conveyed the character’s passion, conviction, charisma, and flaws, making Quezon relatable and human. In addition, Mon Confiado was quietly powerful as Aguinaldo. While the film doesn't glorify Quezon, it reveals the cracks and how ambition can stain even the purest intentions until history decides whether you're an ideal or a sinner. There is more to be discussed in the historical events depicted. Politics is a game of thrones, mula noon hanggang ngayon.Quirky, silly and indeed a good game. It is a must-watch. Pagbati sa buong Quezon team.

Waited for this movie for maybe 8 years and I was not left disappointed. This is the historical drama I was waiting for and the depiction I never knew I wanted. This trilogy has proven and show that our heroes weren't perfect people. They've done bad things, got their hands dirty, and burned bridges but they were also instrumental in building our nation. Sometimes, these heroes are also reflective of our nation and who we can be. The Philippines has its share of problems but it's still a beautiful country and has the potential to be something great. We might be just as imperfect as the heroes in Jerrold Tarog's trilogy were but just like them, we still have the capability to bring the country somewhere great. I hope that one day, we bring this country away from where it is right now and beat the corruption that plagues it.Besides that important lesson and theme I got from the movie, I think the movie is an amazing piece of Philippine cinema from its acting to the cinematography to the editing. It's truly amazing. There were a few creative choices that I feel like could've been edited or shot better but I still think this movie is a masterpiece just like the other two in the trilogy.

Quezon isn’t perfect, but it’s a meaningful addition to Filipino cinema’s take on its heroes. It’ll appeal most to viewers who like their history w/ nuance & aren’t looking for a straightforward hero-story.It doesn’t shy away from showing Quezon’s contradictions: idealism vs self-interest, leadership vs authoritarian streaks. The film invites reflection rather than worship.Heneral Luna started the fire. Goyo showed the cost. Quezon’s the anti hero master stroke that perfectly wraps up the Bayaniverse trilogy. One small gripe: Iain Glen does his best as Leonard Wood, but the accent keeps playing hide & seek w/ the dialogue. He’s commanding, sure, but his Scottish accent slips through just enough to break the illusion. For a film committed to period accuracy, it’s funny how the one thing they didn’t localize was his vowels. Maybe next time, just cast an American & spare Glen the vocal gymnastics.

I have nitpicks with this that I don’t know if it’s a good thing or a bad thing:1. The execution of this was disorienting at first. Because all of a sudden it was theatrical, vaudeville, and full-on period. But when the plot thickens, it suddenly makes sense — On how the politics at the time (let’s face it, until today), is just one big show and performance at stake of actual lives.2. The timejumps was a bit confusing at first. When it jumped from film to life and back out again with no immediately understandable visual cues, it was snapping me out of the world. But again, when the plot thickens, you kinda get the point. This may be my personal issue, but it took me sometime to get to that point.And my most major thing with this:I BOTH LOVE AND HATE, I AM BOTH AMAZED AND DISAPPOINTED, ALL AT THE SAME TIME - On how this reflects to until today. This was basically the birth of a trapo. It says so in the film that this was the game of politics, showcased at large on how it was played, and how it evolved into the game of today. What I hate most is that the main messaging of political idolatry is still a rampant and relevant message that still needs to be relayed to today. And mind you, this was more or less than 80 years ago. How far we’ve gotten yet how slow our progress be.Also, I watched this one alone. And I kinda regret that, which is a RARE reaction I get from watching a film (because I love watching films alone). But this is a discussion me and my friends had before that we may dive deeper into after this film: “Was the Philippines premature to be independent before? Should we have taken more time to be colonized?”. No ill-intent in that question, it is purely a curious question. And one that was once again, sparked by this film.A thinktank, a conversation-igniter, which is how historical films should be. Especially in a country like the Philippines.

an illuminating way to end the trilogy!!!from luna and goyo challenging/questioning the very idea of a hero, the idea now hangs over the viewers with the cunning quezon like a full teacher-student-application cycle. they truly couldnt have problematized a character more positioned inconspicuously than quezon because he’s a walking contradiction of the nationalista party. the party name itself lends him the suspicion, honestly (and as it should be for everyone in a political party). but it’s really his pork barrel, patronage, and gross abuse of power all the more delayed ph independence.i loved studying quezon (admittedly more than rizal) back then and i love now that the film enjoys a layer of experimentation and harkens back to current events. again, quezon was the perfect final man for the trilogy because we see the semblances of his political manipulation and we still feel the context of colonial forces’ strong hold upon us, it’s just wildly more discreet. the film was a transgression in both content and form, which is strikingly reflexive of how history (insofar as it’s PH history involved) ebbs and flows.it’s truly a must watch and i hope this becomes more accessible for Filipinos nationwide.

Kung ang pulitika ay isang laro ng mga opisyal, bakit ang mga mamamayan ang madalas natatalo?Marami akong gustong sabihin tungkol sa Quezon ni direk Jerrold Tarog pero siguro pagpo-pokusan ko nalang ang matalinong pagkakasulat at paggamit ng mga laro sa pelikulang ito. Ang pinaka obvious ay ang Chess, kung saan ang naglalaban ay ang panig ni Quezon para sa puti, at si Osmeña naman ang sa itim. Isa sa mga paborito kong scene yung nasa isang malaking kwarto sila at tila naglalaro ng Chess para masukat kung sino ba ang mas ma-impluwensiya sa kanila. Sa huli, na checkmate si Osmeña. Talo siya.Pangalawa naman ay ang tila paglalaro nila ng Snakes and Ladders. Maraming scene ang nagaakyat-baba ang mga karakter sa hagdan, madalas ay kapag nabibigo silang makuha ang nais nila, galit silang bumababa, parang natuklaw ng ahas— tingin nila, ipinagkanulo sila ng panahon o ng mga kasamahan. Lahat gustong umakyat ng hagdan, lahat gustong manalo.Huli ang poker. Kanya-kanyang laro ng kani-kanilang mga baraha. Kung sino ang may mas maaalam na baho ng kalaban, siya ang panalo. Sa scene kung saan nagtatalumpati ang mga kandidato, para silang nagpo-poker. Panalo ang kung sinumang may hawak ng pinakamagandang baraha. O hindi kaya, kung sino ang pinakamarunong mang-bluff. Sa huli, kahit hawak ni Miong ang isang magandang alas, pinili niyang hindi ito gamitin. Fold.Sa paglalaro nila ng pulitika, tagasubaybay tayo tulad ni Joven. Mahirap tantsahin kung kanino tayo papanig. Sila-sila rin lang naman ang naglalaro. Hanggang ngayon, tau-tauhan lamang tayo sa bulok na laro ng pulitika. Walang tunay na demokrasya.
