On the critique that Quezon (the film) is vague in its idea of independence:That's exactly part of MLQ's politics: the wielding of power is being the origin or source of a great idea, the new republic as a goal only Cassey can achieve. That is how political campaigns are inspired. That's how devotion to political figures has taken its root. Whatever concept of freedom there is should appear like it's going to come directly from the politician. Independence being perceived as food conveys the idea that it's constantly asked, not fought for, by the masses that wait for 'ayuda' rather than the affirmation of their capacity to hold freedom in their hands. And why is 'independence' or 'new republic' mentioned in the film like a byword? It's because Quezon wears it like a badge. But it serves a more important purpose: It floats as a concept that's never really understood. It remains to be a hollow idea associated with patriotism. So it continues to be talked about because it's never truly experienced. Valid pa rin ang tanong na "What is a new republic?" hanggang ngayon. So it's odd to expect the film to define independence for us when what it does is actually more essential.We define it. I trust that we know how to.

Sabi ni Cinemaster Nadz Amata:Simply an amazing film to end Tarog’s Bayani Trilogy. Quezon harnessed the strengths of its predecessors Heneral Luna and Goyo, producing a film with strong storytelling, great actors, and awesome cinematography. Although he did not physically look like the mestizo Casey, Jericho Rosales delivered an enigmatic performance well-deserving of acting awards. But among its merits, perhaps my favorite thing about Quezon is its pointed delivery of political critique not only towards the current administration but to the long history of corrupted, patronizing, and self-serving Philippine politics.I know for sure that it is not only me who feared that Quezon would end up sanitizing the former president’s image, as films about politicians and heroes tended to do so. But alas, Quezon was not usual biopic that mythologized the man — instead, it demystified him, reintroducing the former President that plastered his and his wife’s name all over his home province and the biggest city in Metro Manila. It was able to effectively deliver Manuel Luis Quezon as the cunning politician, borderline dictator that he is.Alongside his intelligent spiels and populist rhetoric, the film revealed the unapologetic and manipulative character of the 2nd President of the Philippine Republic — the man who laid the formula of political maneuvering for the politicians and would-be presidents after him, proving Alfred McCoy’s view that Quezon’s Commonwealth paved the way for Philippine authoritarianism.I do hope that Tarog continues to develop new historical fiction films in the future. More than ever, we need more films that tackle and communicate our history in interesting ways that provoke the audience to revisit our past and reexamine our stances on our ‘great’ men.

Another great interpretation of MLQ’s political life. It has a jumpy storyline, jumping from different timelines in Quezon’s life. Imo it’s not up to par with its prior bayaniverse movies (Heneral Luna goat), but the cinematography, theatrics, and plot delivery are surely Jerrold Tarog’s forte. Hindi na ata talaga bago ang ang pagiging ganid sa kapangyarihan at pagiging kurakot ng mga pulitiko sa Pilipinas. Ika nga ay one politician after another — and nothing has changed.

What a way to close out the Bayaniverse trilogy. From the ultraviolent chaos of Heneral Luna, to the somber introspection of Goyo, Quezon rounds things off as a psychological thriller-slash-political comedy-slash-drama that’s as ambitious as it is sharp.What I’ve always admired about Jerrold Tarog’s depiction of these historical figures is how human they are. There are no pure heroes here—only flawed men navigating ambition, ego, and nationhood. Quezon, played brilliantly by Jericho Rosales, is a political gamemaster: part statesman, part showman, and wholly cunning. I love that the film doesn’t dwell on textbook achievements, but rather on the intricate dance of manipulation, charm, and power that defined his leadership.Like the best Filipino historical films of recent memory, Quezon reflects its own era back at us—the politics of then echoing the politics of now, for better or worse.And while it’s billed as the end of the Bayaniverse, I hope this isn’t an exclamation point, but a comma—especially after that tantalizing post-credits tease.

Here we begin with a shapeshifting exploiter on one hand and a docile, equally ambitious prowler on the other, juggled and brandished to trade barbs and heave vitriol at each other, both would later dismiss as mere politics to justify a much-needed partnership, then finding a common enemy in a chagrined former revolutionary leader and president. The ping-pong exchange of politicking and smear campaigns is its most coruscating part—electrifying to me, actually—a protracted look at our current politics' saddening origin. Quezon—now that there is no need for battle pieces, as that is not Tarog's turf—is the most polished in the entire trilogy, only slightly tarnished by its caricature bits and overreliance on fictional characters. The decision to minimize young Joven's speaking lines saves the entire cast's immaculate efforts from futility.

It was so fascinating to see the things I've learned in history books be dramatized in film.What a time to be alive to witness a trilogy of films that tells a story of heroes, but also deconstruct them, showcase them as three-dimensional characters, as people and not as good guys up on pedestals.The change of tone from the seriousness and war setting of Heneral Luna and Goyo to the more modern setting of Quezon threw me off, but also had me engaged. Especially with the way they make a meta-commentary of the power of film and media to portray these stories. Jericho Rosales is wonderful to see on screen as MLQ, and Romnick Sarmienta as Sergio Osmeña showed a fun dynamic--almost like a romantic couple--between Quezon and Osmeña.The non-linear storytelling was also a change that I had to adjust after re-watching the first two in preparation for this. Thankfully, there are title cards and chapters that serve as good guide posts for the pacing of the story.Speaking of story, as this film spanned a longer timeframe compared to the two, it's written to showcase more vignette-type and montage-style of events rather than the more straightforward storytelling in Luna and Goyo. While it's not a bad thing, it can be difficult to keep track of while watching. Also, pacing is an issue as some parts dragged and other moments could've used more time to absorb its messaging.The showcase of Quezon's con artistry and showcasing him as a chameleon is done very well. This movie was really a battle of wits instead of arms--and it truly showcased the Filipino political culture.The production and set design were done incredibly well. A lot of effort was put to make this a period piece. While some seams and cracks can be seen here-and-there, those can be mostly ignored and do not hinder my enjoyment of the film. There isn't that much bloodshed and prosthetic wounds to be seen here, but more on CG buildings, vehicles, and recreation of period appropriate settings and props.---SPOILER THOUGHTS---I think they could've had a Mabini scene somewhere as having Aguinaldo, Joven, Rusca, and Janolino weren't enough connective tissue for me to fully connect this movie with the previous two.The Alerta storyline and Nadia filmmaking storyline could've been tighter as these were the parts that dragged the most. Though I do appreciate having this fictional plot point to give commentary on the importance of film, media, journalism, and media literacy--I do think this could be polished more and make less preachy. In the previous films, I didn't feel like I was being banged with the head with all of its messaging because of how beautiful the writing is and how its themes weave together with its characters. In here, that magic was kinda muddled a bit. But there were still some scenes and lines that made such a good impact on me.His abrupt death and shouting into the abyss, left me dissatisfied to be honest. Both Luna and Goyo's death were shown on-screen while here, it's just implied and presented to us through text. I would've loved to see him actually die in his sleep or something or maybe have Osmeña receive the news and take his place and then have the epilogue of the movie there.Lastly, all three films had some sort of subplot of the protagonist having some sort of affair. I think Aurora Quezon was underutilized here. Luna's affair with Isabel makes sense as the character was an amalgamation of various women in Luna's life. Goyo's love affairs with Felicidad and Dolores were the most poetic and beautifully done juxtaposed with the sacrifices of war. Quezon's love for Aurora and the affair with Ana Ricardo was so tense but not as strong as I would like it to be as both women were more plot device than actual characters.---END OF SPOILER THOUGHTS---Quezon is a great film and I am thankful to have watched it on the big screen. I think it is the weakest of the trilogy, but it still has its redeeming qualities. It can be frustrating in a negative sense with some of the complaints I have, but this film and the entire Bayani-verse trilogy of movies are frustrating in the positive sense--as ALL three were well-written to present themes, lessons, and events that are still relevant to this day. These films show history but as so well-crafted to mirror the political issues we have at present.I don't want this to be the last film. I do hope there are more stories to tell and themes to explore in our history.

I really enjoyed this movie! Jericho Rosales doesn't really look like Quezon, I was really hesitant at his casting first especially as the original Quezon TJ Trinidad (and even the younger Quezon Benjamin Alves as well as Apolinario Mabini actor from previous Bayaniverse films Epy Quizon) looks more similar to the real Quezon, but Jericho did really make up for his acting. I love how the political tactics and intrigue are made with comedic timing, keeping audiences interested in the screen. I thought Mon Confiado was really perfect as Quezon and Iain Glen's special appearance as Governor General Leonard Wood was fantastic. I thought Karylle's Aurora Quezon doesn't have much to do in the movie, but I was really impressed with her acting especially when she realized Quezon's first "wife" was in the same event as her and Quezon.The movie seems to be based strongly on facts, but I couldn't find from my research information about this so called first "wife" of Quezon before Aurora. But I do think she was used very well in the plot of this movie. The fictional characters Joven Hernando and his daughter Nadia are well used in this movie as well. They are intended to represent the audiences (especially Filipino audiences as their Filipino history shown in this movie is still relevant today). Overall a great third movie in Jerrold Tarrog's Bayaniverse movie films (along with 2015's Heneral Luna and 2018's Goyo: Ang Batang Heneral).

“Maraming politiko sa bansa, ngunit kakaunti lamang ang tunay na lingkod-bayan.”This movie reveals the harsh reality behind politics in the Philippines—how cheating and greed have embedded into the country’s system, and how these practices have been normalized until now. It shows how our government fight for independence, only to end up imprisoning its own people under self-serving leadership. This film should also serves as an eye-opener to every Filipino— to remind that today’s news about our government is merely a repetition of what has already happened in the past.Ang tunay na kalayaan ay hindi natin makakamtan sa mga kamay ng dayuhan, kundi sa paglaya sa mga politikong patuloy na pinaiikot ang mga Pilipino sa bulok at madumi nilang sistema.(minus 1 bakit may taga solid north dyan hahaha)

the writing, visual production, and sound design were so, so sharp; it was impossible to be bored, even for a film that centered around talking politicians. ang galing! maybe not my favorite out of the three in the bayaniverse, but i do believe it to be the most relevant as its closest to our present reality today. it very effectively punctures our lack of regard for some of the earliest developments of our current republic. it then became a great illustration of how the governance and systems we face today doesn’t fall far from the tree (unfortunately). in that sense, the film is a lot less emotionally moving compared to its counterparts in the trilogy. instead, it was moreso unsettling: and maybe that’s the point!! history is not merely the study of the past, but it is also how the present came to be and continues to evolve as we speak. moreover, heroes are but names we give to very much real people with a human capacity for malice and fault. much credit to jerrold tarog for the bayaniverse trilogy. had it not been for general luna, i’d not have gone on history deep dives in my free time (because unfortunately the last time we had proper philippine history as a class was in grade 6). we’re often apprehensive to approach history as the mere thought of the many big names and events intimidate us — especially when we think that history is just dead people and shit that went down years ago. but what if we just don’t realize that history is actually, very much as well, the now? quezon (2025) is a great ender to the trilogy because it cements such idea. it’s chilling to think about how time has passed and how much has stayed the same. thinking about it all has made me unsettled (which, again, i think is the point).

a detail that im fixated on about this movie is quezon’s use of the word “independence”. he uses the idea of it as a bluff and it’s almost like a tell in his strategy for the game that people somehow fall for time and time again. it almost becomes a kind of semantic satiation, with the amount of times he promises it, it starts losing its meaning –said meaning already being completely misunderstood, or at least, understood without the weight and depths and nuances of it.another side of his promise for independence of the philippines is how the film rounds the statement up by the end with quezon screaming “i am the philippines” –the implication of his life’s work only being dedicated to a kind of independence for Himself and not for the country….manjesus christ the amount of times i wanted to pull my hair out at anytime i am reminded this shit is still happening Right Now watching this film feels like being shot 47498 timespota ang ganda nakakagalitfjfjfalso: quezon calling osmeña mi querido and osmeña replying with barely contained lust….jerrold tarog WILL have historical yaoi in every movie in the bayaniverse

marami ang politiko, ngunit kakaunti lamang ang lingkod bayan.there are numerous reasons in which individuals desire to enter politics, but not everyone is really a public servant. you have to possess tremendous power to influence in order to become such a powerful individual. my opinion is that many who become so influential are not exercising this power for good governance, rather for personal interests. this thinking can bring about patronage politics, corruption, and insensitivity to the needs of the people(which is actually happening rn).It's sad to see people put personal interest ahead of the common good.this film sheds some light on this aspect by depicting the shrewd personality of Manuel Quezon, our first president commonwealth president(that’s why andaming palang proposed constitution, and yung transition about tydings-mcduffie act hindi tinuro sa’min kung what was the real story behind those numerous revisions and amendments). It depicts how his calculated and shrewd politics influenced the country's history, but at the same time points out the ambiguity between heroism and manipulation. the film instigates us to challenge our understanding of historical icons and what it actually means to be a hero. It gives us inspiration to think critically on leadership and governance, and to aim for a system where power is utilized for the common good, not for a chosen few. while reflecting on Quezon's legacy, we are reminded that genuine public servants are those who put the greater good first, not personal interests.

Quezon, in terms of storytelling, is different from the approach of Heneral Luna and Goyo. Not that the previous films were set during the war for independence and Quezon was more about words, but Tarog’s treatment here was somewhat different.What I appreciate about this new approach is its new perspective. In this film, we see Quezon through the lens of Nadia’s works, portrayed as both a hero and a shrewd politician — a duality reflected by the people around him like Joven, who seem like spectators to his life. The storytelling feels more playful yet sharp, much like the mind games shown in the film, which perfectly capture his wit and sly character. I also liked the use of the title card inspired by the silent era in the sequence that introduces Quezon — a clever way to bridge the past and the present.The scenes of love-hate tension between him and Osmeña, his attempts to outsmart Leonard Wood, and his feud with Aguinaldo make us, as viewers, feel like spectators in this grand game of politics. Despite the seriousness of the subject, the humor and comedic tone remain, giving the film a lighter touch — something I truly appreciate. It also highlights the absurdity of politics, showing how politicians can sometimes be clowns themselves. Quezon is definitely a film worth watching in cinemas. I also appreciate its cinematography and sound design, which add so much to the overall narrative.

Quezon is less about defining a hero and more about what a hero isn't. With no guns and battles this time, Tarog's final film in the trilogy relied on a well-written screenplay and a brilliant direction and editing. This felt polished and grand.Jericho Rosales plays Quezon masterfully with his unmatched charisma and mischievous persona. Every department of this production brought their A-game (except the makeup which was at times distracting). The writing here is particularly good, in my opinion the best of the trilogy.Quite an experience going home from the cinema in a motorcycle, seeing his name in every corner of every street in this city named after him. His legacy indeed lived on. Scary to think that the unprincipled legacy of the people running this country today might live on too just like his.

Quezon is not your typical biopic. It doesn’t simply glorify the titular figure, nor does it aim to reduce him to a villain. It’s a sharp, unsettling mirror. The cinematography is well-executed, every shot deliberate and meaningful. I loved how the film plays with style: the silent movie and noir sequences are such clever touches. There’s a bit of camp, even excess, but it works. Politics has always been a performance in the Philippines anyway, and this film leans right into that.It’s not afraid to show Quezon as both idealist and egotist, leader and manipulator. The movie calls out how he perfected the art of political spectacle, something we’re still drowning in today. At times, it gets too caught up in that same spectacle, focusing on power plays more than the people affected by them, but maybe that’s part of the point.What stings most is how familiar it all feels. The greed, the posturing, the foreign meddling: it’s the same game, just with new players. Quezon isn’t perfect, but it’s sharp, stylish, and painfully relevant. It doesn’t just revisit history; it forces us to realize we’ve never really left it.(P.S. Give Jericho Rosales his well-deserved FAMAS now!! that perforamance was spectacular!!)
BANAL-BANALAN KANG BURAT KA

Nakakatuwang isipin na kahit medyo natagalan bago nasundan at dumaan sa maraming hamon, ngayon ay mapapanood na rin natin ang “final installment” ng Bayaniverse. This time, nakatutok ang pelikula kay Manuel L. Quezon, upang ipakita sa mga Pilipino kung ano nga ba ang tunay na kahulugan ng pagiging bayani. So, was it worth the wait?One thing’s very clear: this movie is made with passion and love. Every aspect, production design, costume, music, sound design, acting, and screenplay, everything feels precise and deliberate. Walang sayang. Busog ang mata mo, at napakasarap sa pandinig ng bawat linya at tugtugin.I also appreciate that the film didn’t contradict anything from the previous installments. There’s no unnecessary retcon, and even smaller roles were reprised by the same actors (except for Joross Gamboa as Eduardo Rusca, previously played by Archie Alemania). Hindi ko nga agad napansin na siya pala iyon until I checked online, still, I appreciate his inclusion.What leaves me conflicted, however, is how the narrative perspective centers on Joven. He’s a good character, pero minsan nawawala ang connection natin kay Quezon. Unlike the first two films where we clearly see the world through the minds of Luna and Goyo, dito parang ikinukuwento lang sa atin ang nararamdaman ni Quezon. That sometimes creates a bit of emotional distance. I get that the film wants to show that our heroes are just as flawed and human as we are, and I love that message, but I wish we could’ve seen more of Quezon’s inner struggle.The non-linear structure works surprisingly well. Kahit medyo gimmicky, it adds flavor to the storytelling, especially since we already know where the story is headed.Jericho Rosales delivers a powerful and charismatic performance as Quezon. Mon Confiado also brings his A-game, while Cris Villanueva, Arron Villaflor, and Rominick Sarmenta shine in their respective roles. For Iain Glen, I honestly feel another actor could’ve played the part, but it’s still commendable that they brought in a respected Hollywood actor for the role.Overall, Quezon is a strong and passionate film. It may be overly ambitious at times, occasionally losing sight of its identity, but its heart is in the right place. The message remains powerful: kahit ilang taon na ang lumipas, tila hindi pa rin nagbabago ang mga Pilipino.And if ever this isn’t truly “the end,” I hope we still get to see more stories from the Bayaniverse, especially with that mid-credit scene tease.

I'm not just talking about the character, but this actually reflects our society today and how we struggle and fight against corrupt politicians. It's also great…

Independence: Good enough to eat.127 years of Philippine independence, but are we truly free? Do our statesmen really know how to operate this country with 'freedom' in their hands? Do we even deserve this freedom? Will we ever learn?​This is what Quezon leaves you with. This movie is enjoyable and, as always, provoking.​It brings to mind that known quote from him: "I'd rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by Americans." Hearing that again, with what's happening to our country, made me laugh. I like how Tarog thinks, always aiming for relevance by connecting his historical movies to what's happening right now.​As someone who didn't know much about Quezon, I learned a lot and was reminded of the things he did. But it's also a movie about politics. We are introduced to their games, how they operated, and how they think. Today, it might seem obvious. But to think that this has been happening long before our independence has me worried. I was sitting in the cinema literally not knowing exactly how I feel, other than discomfort.​Technically, I appreciated the writing. Despite being dialogue-heavy, the lines are witty and written with a style similar to the Bayaniverse. I also like the aesthetic; it reminds me of Wes Anderson (very subtle) and the likes with its use of symmetry, colors, and scores.​Ultimately, we are shown the humane side of our celebrated heroes. While we appreciate what they've done for our country, we should not be blind to consider them human—not idols, not kings, not gods.​Maraming magagandang salita sa pelikula, pero siguro ang mainam na panapos ay:Maraming politiko, kakaunti ang lingkod-bayan.

“Body and soul?”Our answer to an Armando Ianucci political satire. Dare I say well shot, exquisitely paced, with nail-biting dialogue that speaks from a century ago to our time. Quezon is a political animal that knew no satisfaction but perhaps was a mere reflection of the period where America (his puppet masters) were too first learning the prizes of Empire. Rosales gives perhaps his defining performance in this stage of his career. Just verve and energy radiating off the screen! Like any of history’s narcissists, it was a downfall well portrayed and a rise to power that echoes DiCaprio’s Jordan Belfort. (Where to mention the crispness of a Scorsese film’s editing is also possibly a clear inspiration for this film). Mon Confiado’s Aguinaldo was humanized well away from the El Presidente’s mythic stature. The birth of patronage politics and its attacks on journalism and truth was impeccably presented. Never to the point of celebrating it but dangles its dangers for people to discover and hopefully decry. 4/5

I think this one might be the Bayaniverse trilogy's "Before Midnight." Comparing this to Goyo and Heneral Luna, this one is not making you root for our main character but simply interested to see his downfall. Its not some big patriotic piece that sets your heart ablaze but rather shows you where all of "this" began and by "this" I mean the system that we live in today and how politicians run this country with ego and gluttony for money and power. (3/3 bayaniverse) MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS (but then again, this is our history lol)key takeaways:- si sergio osmeña pala ang OG backburner- ang quezon ay sinaunang friends to enemies to lovers and again trope - naabutan pa pala ng nanay at tatay ko si aguinaldo wth :-)on a more serious note:- my bayaniverse ranking as of now is: quezon, goyo, luna. i liked goyo better than luna because of its more introspective direction and for me, was a better deconstruction of our "heroes". i liked quezon better than goyo because of its fresh direction and it's a different kind of war, political mind games.- regarding the fresh direction, i was so fond of the grand budapest-esque style in the initial parts of the movie and how it kind of pulled a moulin rouge route (a story within a story).- tbh, mentally nasuka ako after finishing the film. the realization that before marcos sr., we had quezon :---) parang as if sa kanya nagmula ang formula ng pagiging trapo: more of a showman, less of a public servant. - also, as much as aguinaldo was villainized in the first film, in here, he was portrayed as some sort of "lesser evil"- lastly, the highlight of it all and what i was waiting for ever since i learned about it in KAS 1, as much as quezon played us, he, too, is just a piece from a much bigger game being played by the US. that despite it all, have we truly been independent from them?

Director Jerrod Tarog delivers another masterpiece in the Bayaniverse with a showcase in filmmaking excellence in acting, cinematography, editing, production and costume design. I was initially thrown off by Jericho Rosales and Romnick Sarmienta's accents (never bothered to check if that's how Quezon and Osmena sounded in real life) but they're 2 of today's best actors that I eventually appreciated how they fully embodied their respective roles. Ditto Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, Karylle as Doña Aurora, JC Santos as Roxas, and even Cris Villanueva as fictional character journalist Joven Hernando. It was also nice to see Iain Glen (Jorah Mormont in Game of Thrones) play Governor-General Wood. Quezon's bantering/arguments with both Osmena and Wood were quite amusing/entertaining. Also commend the shift in tone which was like a breath of fresh air in telling a Pinoy historical drama (sort of reminded me of Mike de Leon's 'Bayaning 3rd World' which also starred Villanueva). But if I were to nitpick, I'd note that if Luna and del Pilar were humanized in their respective biographical war dramas, Quezon was villainized here as the idealistic patriot fighting for Philippine independence turned scheming, power hungry politician. Yes, this film showed that the country has been (prodominantly) run by politicians, not public servants.

“Masyadong maraming politiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan.” What a fun watch. The most notable thing about this trilogy is how many times I’ve admittedly said “Hindi ko alam na ganito pala sila…” which makes the storytelling even more compelling. I am in pure awe of TBA’s works. Mahusay kayo!

Love Jericho Rosales and Mon Confiado in this, and I particularly like what the film has to say about (the origins of) patronage politics and strongman politics in the Philippines and their intertwined history with colonialism, and when the film is actively trying to make us think what constitutes heroism (is a strongman un-photographed in his weaker moments the same strongman captured on magazine covers?). But lord, also the very definition of maingay, chicharon, bungangera. Exposition as dialogue, and not even doing the subtlest job at hiding it. Hate it when Rody just goes ahead and shoves everything down our throats like he's breeding geese for foie gras (sorry, Rody); counterpoint: the PETA play Under My Skin, for instance. At some point, I was like, get a move on, we've been saying the same exact thing over and over again for like 10 minutes already. And the whole watching the daughter's work in the empty cinema device just so we can have the flashback scenes--ugh.

YOU CAN’T LOSE WITH QUEZONAfter three watches, I can safely say one thing: I have so many thoughts about the Quezon movie, and yet so little words to convey it in. I wrote so many passages down in my notebooks. All of them half-finished or just me arguing with myself trying to make sense of what I was feeling. I’ll try my best to write them here.The Bayaniverse, one of my favorite Filipino movie series, has finally come to a close with (arguably) one of their best movies yet. Quezon veers away from the usual historical biopic formula and moves into the territory of being a social commentary.Instead of the “event A happened, so event B follows” format, Quezon asks us to sit with discomfort. Rather than simply glorifying its subject, the movie presents a national hero who reflects the leaders we have now. A visionary who fought for Filipino independence, yet, a calculating statesman who mastered the performance of politics. Charming when needed, ruthless when required, and deeply aware of optics.I see the movie as something that doesn’t necessarily paint Quezon in a necessarily evil nor corrupt light, but as a pragmatic who knew that idealism alone could not dismantle a colonial-imperialism system built on inequality. That pragmatism, however, is exactly what built the foundations of our current political structure.What does that say about our national heroes? What does that say about the kinds of people we choose to enshrine and remember? Most importantly, what does that say about us?The Quezon we see in the movie is not simply Quezon–he’s also the collective psyche of the nation that produced him and the time that he lived in. He lived under an imperialist, racist U.S. government! As the movie perfectly states, “Quezon may not have made the game, but he sure did play it.”I think Quezon challenges the comfort that we have in hero worship. It dares us to look at power. Not as a moral test or a path to self-actualization, but as a mirror to who we are as a nation going through growing pains. Is it worth acknowledging that building a road to greatness often comes with destroying whatever comes ahead?The real message of the Bayaniverse, in my opinion, is that the nation was not built by perfect saints. It was also built by people who have the tendency to be selfish, flawed, ambitious, and painfully human. The series tells us that our understanding of heroism must mature as we continue to mature as a nation.On a more personal note, I will never forget the feeling of watching it on the big screen. What an amazing movie. The dialogue is witty, suspenseful, and human. Another thing I love about it is the casting. Everyone is so perfect! I knew that Jericho Rosales was a good actor, but he was PHENOMENAL as MLQ! I didn’t expect it at all.The music and cinematography are top-notch too. What a movie! I’d love to be part of something like this one day.I’ve been told that I have the tendency to go insane about the things I love. I’m not a movie person, but I’d love to go to the theater to watch it again, but that’d require me to open my commissions (and so, I’m opening my commissions to watch it again).

It is undeniable that Quezon was depicted as a power-hungry egoistical person in this film. If you think about it, the film unfolds based on the journalist’s perspective. Both on different sides of the coin, but then again, it was the same coin.. talagang morality bends if ikaw ang nakikinabang. Every scene felt like a chess move, a power move even. The Quezon-Osmeña dynamic is so compelling to watch, I am definitely moved.Now about the movie, the cinematography is noticeably visibly great. Even the details tell a story and are so hard not to miss.. the color grade, the camera movement, the aesthetics, and the pacing, all on point !!! Jerrold Tarog showed me a fresh new perspective that makes me want to go down the rabbit hole and watch all his films. hehe I think I just fell in love with history? Quezon is definitely a film worth watching, I am even considering rewatching it now.
toxic doomed yaoi aside, i really do love how they made this. SS classes taught us on wrong lies… Glad to see and recognize that ever since may mga kurakot sa gubyerno natin.

Quezon feels like a well-crafted film that Jerrold Tarog put a lot of effort into, both in writing and directing. Rosales’s performance as the lead really stands out and carries the movie. Visually, it’s a treat with a unique old-school style and great production design that captures the early 1900s vibe perfectly.The story also creates a good amount of intrigue, even if some parts aren’t perfectly executed. Despite its flaws, it’s an interesting watch because of its strong visuals and engaging narrative. Overall, Quezon is a solid film that shows real craftsmanship and is worth a watch.-flickswithmigs

Citizen Quezon

painful irony of a nation striving for independence while simultaneously being undermined by internal disunity and dependence on external influence.the film offers a sharp critique of the deeply rooted filipino concept of utang na loob and exposes how it can distort the ideals of governance and public service. what once began as a moral virtue, a sign of respect and loyalty, becomes a political instrument that undermines integrity, opening the door to corruption, favoritism, and blind allegiance. it challenges viewers to reflect on how certain filipino values, while culturally meaningful, can be misused to sustain systems of power that work against true progress.at the same time, the film also confronts a difficult truth: it’s not easy to question or turn away from this cycle, especially when one is personally benefiting from those in power. comfort and convenience can blur one’s moral vision, making it hard to see the injustice hidden behind acts of generosity. it takes courage and self-awareness to break free from that dependence, to open one’s eyes and choose integrity over personal gain.

It depicts how, even long before, politicians have always been performative when it comes to their propaganda just to appear pleasing to the people. Human as we are, Filipinos as we are, we tend to be easily blinded by whatever “truth” is presented to us, especially when it aligns with our values and principles. What struck me most (in the worst way possible) and I was genuinely flabbergasted was the case with his first wife and how he defended himself in court, saying something along the lines of, “Does this face really need to rape someone?” It shows how contradicting his principles already were. You cannot fight for your country if you are struggling to be humane yourself. Quezon took Filipinos as nothing but mere tools for him to gain power. In reality, isa pa rin siyang tuta ng mga Amerikano by adhering to the same vicious practices as those American people.“Independence is just a word.” – QuezonWhat really is independence? Have we truly achieved it if we remain enslaved by poor governance and corruption? After all, he said it himself that he would rather have a country run like hell by Filipinos than a country run like heaven by Americans. Perhaps Hobbes was right, man is selfish in nature, and he will do anything through voluntary acts if the object serves some good to himself.Is it the lesser evil for the Philippines to barely progress under Filipino rule, rather than to thrive under an American one? This isn’t to claim that the latter would be preferable, rather, it’s to assert that we deserve a government that upholds both, a competent leadership and a genuinely Filipino sense of governance.
I liked the comedic touch they added to this movie, it mirrors the current state of the Philippine politics today—a comedy show.

I entered the cinema expecting a crashcourse on history, yet I've been dished with a more nuanced understanding on our collective perception of history as a whole. The movie itself is the statement. Heneral Luna and Goyo have already fixed our expectation/s on how this will turn out: a valorous exhibit on the lives of "national heroes" that shaped Philippines as we know it; setting a preliminary idea that it will follow the same pattern about building Quezon as a major contributor of our independence. Yet, as it turns out, the movie stitches reflective points gauging on what these historical acts truly mean to us and the manner as to how these information precipitated through our minds. A magnified look into Quezon as an individual, almost overshadowing the historical context within them opens up a rare opportunity for critiqe against our national heroes. Oftentimes, we are trained to consume knowledge as quick as light, yet there is lesser existential emphasis that allow us to reject passivity in learning. I am too drowsy to add more (i will edit this soon tho), but I really enjoyed thinking about a lot of things such as the state of Philippine politics, statehood, and the lingering wonder as to what truly constitus a hero and power as recursive influence on the trajectory of history and how its viewed.

How painful it is to see this film validate one of my biggest fears about trying to make it in this country: that the only real way to succeed is by taking advantage of an unjust and cruel system, one that requires you to bring down others to bring yourself up. It’s more than just “crab mentality”; it’s systemic and rooted deep within, right into this country’s body and soul. So when the character of Quezon, an ambitious man who benefitted from (and allegedly originated) the country’s rotten practices, shouted “I am the Philippines”, I was inclined to believe him. On a side note, I’ve always wanted to see more Filipino movies about politicking — which is why the feature scripts I’ve written tackle it extensively — and so this was such a feast for me.

what's amazing about this film is how it handles pacing. everything here is just political drama. no war, no action, no theatrics. but they made it so entertaining to watch. there was no single dull moment. the direction was very clear and precise, the cinematography is very creative, the production design was stellar, and the performances are just chefs kiss especially jericho rosales as quezon. i was hesitant about his casting when it was first announced but im glad to be proved wrong. he just oozes with this charm that slowly blura the line between him and his character. and the writing supporting it and the story as a whole is amazing. the language and those political banters are quite like music. kinda like sorkin's writing style. and the music is as fun as the film itself. whats even crazier is that those two things are behind one person. and despite its greatness, this film is still far from a documentary or a biography. its a character study of a fictional character based from a real person. if you look at it as a history lesson, its not that. it greatly shows us how flawed a person is and it now our job to do the research over the real thing. the bayaniverse is a great trilogy and i hope it doesnt stop. looking forward to magsaysay.and also, just a funny thought, i cant help but give it similarities to hamilton. this whole film just gives off that loud energy of hamilton's 2nd act.

The film’s most intriguing throughline lies in Manuel Quezon’s (Jericho Rosales) exchanges with Joven Hernando (Arron Villaflor as the young journalist, Cris Villanueva as the older one). Joven, who once idolized Quezon, becomes his conscience and later his accuser, returning a coin once given to him as a symbol of principle. Their relationship encapsulates writer-director Jerrold Tarog’s grand question: can integrity survive intimacy with power? It’s through Joven’s eyes that we watch the statesman’s transformation into strongman, his lofty rhetoric curdling into patronage politics. When Quezon shuts down Joven’s newspaper for publishing an exposé, the betrayal stings not only as political allegory but as personal tragedy—the loss of faith in leadership itself.What I found most striking here (and which I strongly feel is the film’s strongest aspect) is how Tarog, through Joven’s eyes, frames Quezon as the unwitting architect of a system that still defines us. Joven suggests that while Quezon didn’t invent patronage politics, he definitely perfected its choreography: every favor disguised as friendship, every handshake turned into hierarchy. The film doesn’t condemn him outright for this; it simply watches how such pragmatism metastasizes into a national reflex that still nags at us today.In one exchange, Quezon insists that principle must bend to survival, a line that feels less like justification than prophecy. Tarog lets that sentiment resonate across the film like a curse. We see it in the way Quezon rewards loyalty with access, in the quiet humiliation of those who refuse to play along, and in the hollow triumph of independence negotiated rather than fought for. The movie’s politics are cyclical, almost fatalistic: power breeds corruption, corruption demands compromise, and compromise becomes governance. Tarog doesn’t spell this out; he lets it unfold in the pauses between alliances and betrayals, in the small intimate silences that follow Quezon’s public victories.Joven’s arc, meanwhile, becomes our moral compass—a journalist who believes truth can coexist with patronage, only to learn that one always consumes the other. His disillusionment is as national as it is personal. By the time he returns the coin Quezon once gave him, the gesture feels both intimate and historical, like a nation finally returning the debt of false ideals. Tarog’s “Bayaniverse” has always traced this erosion, but here it feels complete: Quezon may have built the country’s first Republic, but he also built the template for its recurring undoing.What the film ultimately suggests is that corruption in the Philippines isn’t an aberration—it’s an inheritance. Quezon’s genius wasn’t that he corrupted the system, but that he understood how to make corruption look like leadership. His brand of “opportunistic nationalism,” as historians have called it, didn’t die with him; it evolved, refined by each successor who learned the same survivalist grace. Tarog’s gaze isn’t accusatory, though. It’s almost elegiac, as if recognizing that Quezon’s contradictions—his brilliance, his vanity, his compromises—are also ours.

The little things - facial movements, cadence of speech, tone of voice - made his portrayal of his character a lot more human. On the other hand, mon confiado, his VP (this guy can’t act for shit), the movie girl, etc. acted like they were in an amateur theatre play with them classic Philippine movie acting accents n quirks.The blocking and acting of the extras make it even worse; they’re always like robots on a set. As the final chapter of Jerrold Tarog’s Bayaniverse trilogy, Quezon wraps things up in a way that’s both bold and refreshing. I went into this with zero expectations since it didn’t get much buzz, but honestly, it’s a must-watch even if you haven’t seen Heneral Luna or Goyo. It may not be as explosive or emotionally charged as Heneral Luna, nor as poetic as Goyo, but its quirky, satirical tone gives it a distinct identity that stands strong alongside the first two films.Seeing Quezon’s story unfold beyond the pages of history books is fascinating. Tarog leans into dark humor and sharp political satire, exposing the manipulative, chaotic world of power struggles — Quezon versus fellow politicians and the Americans. This isn’t your typical biopic; it’s a political farce where Jericho Rosales’ Quezon treats nationhood like a rigged game only he can win. He lies when needed, bends the truth to his advantage, and embodies both heroism and hypocrisy.What makes this film stand out is its honesty. It doesn’t glorify Quezon... it exposes his flaws, ambition, and contradictions. The inclusion of media’s role in shaping narratives adds another layer, reminding us that there are always two sides to every story. The line “heroism is just a perception” sums it up perfectly.Jericho Rosales is phenomenal here that you forget you’re watching him, he is Quezon. Mon Confiado as Aguinaldo, and the actors portraying Osmeña and Roxas, all deliver sharp, grounded performances that complement the film’s tone.The ending hits hard with its satirical bite, when Quezon declares, “I am the Philippines.” Tarog leaves it open to interpretation, but to me, it’s a powerful commentary on power, ego, and politics — on how even noble intentions can rot when corrupted by greed. A hero proclaiming that he is the country becomes the same figure consumed by its flaws. It’s ironic, timely, and uncomfortably reflective of the state of our nation today.Quezon isn’t just a political film — it’s a mirror held up to our nation, to our leaders, and to ourselves. It’s raw, funny, unsettling, and deeply Filipino. A brilliant, unflinching finale to Tarog’s Bayaniverse.

Masyadong maraming pulitiko sa bansa, kakaunti lamang ang mga lingkod-bayan.Sa loob ng siyamnapung taon, wala pa ring pinagbago sa gawi at sirkumstansiya ng mga taong tumatayo at namumuno sa gobyerno. Patuloy lamang na naiipon ang mga maruruming dokumento sa loob ng kongreso, mga dugong umaagos sa bawat eskenita’t kalsada, at ang mga bahid ng nakaraan na nananatiling nakatago sa bawat sulok ng bodega ng mga pulitiko. Mangangampanya at papasok ng pulitiko na punong-puno ng pangako’t layunin, ngunit uunahin naman ang paglilinis ng pampublikong imahe at pagbuo ng ugnayan sa mga makapangyarihan kaysa ayusin ang problema ng bansa. Narito ka bilang lingkod-bayan ng mamamayan, hindi ka hari! Nawa’y marami pang umusbong na ganitong uri ng pelikula na hindi lamang magtataguyod ng industriya ng pelikula, kundi patuloy na magpapaalala sa atin ng tunay na kasaysayan ng Pilipinas—nang walang halong labis na papuri na magtatakip ng katotohanan.

"madaming pulitiko pero kakaunti lamang ang lingkod-bayan"the last installment to the bayaniverse of tba studios takes a 180 turn in terms of offering its narrative to a hero that this movie is supposed to glorify. While Manuel Quezon remains as a polarizing figure in Philippine history what Quezon offers is trying to show both sides of the coin. That Manuel Quezon has his fair share of contribution to the independence of the country while also not turning a blind eye to his ill deeds. While the film is historically accurate and strong with its references to past events what drags it down is the fictional dramatization for story build-up purposes. My personal fave in this movie hihi that I loved how they told the narrative of the movie within a movie itself (this may make or break the viewing experience depends on the audience preference however in my case it worked!). What confused me, though, was how the film tried to paint Emilio Aguinaldo as a noble hero despite the long-standing accusations against him. Still, as a self-proclaimed history nerd, this film was a feast for my brain and how it challenged, debunked, and reanalyzed so much of what I thought I knew. The sharp dialogues also double as timely social commentary that still hits hard today.

A bit better than Heneral Luna and ties together all the themes established from the first two movies. Siyempre andiyan pa rin yung mga "audience surrogate" scenes in which the characters engage in dialogue that's artificial instead of letting the audience figure it out for themselves. Case in point: yung kumakain sina Joven, Rusca, Carmen at Nadia while mansplaining that being educated doesn't mean you cannot be fooled. Also, I don't understand getting miffed by Quezon's portrayal in a negative light — deconstruction is the whole shtick of the "Bayaniverse". It's intended to serve as counterpoints to the textbooks that mythologize historical figures. Hindi naman siya malicious. They're humans after all and politics is intrinsically dirty and ugly. Quezon even correctly points out that Joven is a hypocrite for trying to cast stones. May false equivalence pa yung relative na under Trump daw tayo if Quezon didn't push for independence. Ah ewan. Basta gumana yung tradecraft nila na yan to get more butts in the seats. And on that note, I look forward to phase two with Magsaysay. If there's a Filipino "icon" that's most deserving of the Bayaniverse treatment, it's this guy. Second si Miriam, but Jerrold would probably be super old or (knocks on wood) dead by the time they get to that list.

Aside from pacing issues and a few tonally distracting melodramatic beats, I thought Quezon was a remarkable Philippine production that dared to confront the contradictions behind one of the country’s most celebrated leaders. "Quezon" is a historical epic and political tragedy about idealism corrupted by power and how the dream of nationhood becomes tangled in propaganda and ego.I think it is essential viewing for anyone interested in Philippine history.

Easily one of my most favorite films of all time, not because of my personal bias towards the Bayaniverse films nor because of my views and opinions on MLQ, but because of how much impact this could make in shaping conversations about our "heroes."Historical figures are all subject to the judgment of history. We cannot confine MLQ into being an exclusively great statesman, nor into a cunning chameleon of a politician. We've got to see the good, the bad, and the ugly.After all, his decisions are a product of the conditions of the Philippines during his time. Love him or hate him, MLQ made his mark in our history. Marks that should be studied and learned from, lest we repeat the mistakes of the past.Anyway, what really stood up to me in this film is the wide use of juxtaposition and contrast in its storytelling, in the conversations between Quezon and Osmeña, Quezon and Aguinaldo, Aguinaldo and Wood, Wood and Quezon, so on.This film made me want to re-read Nick Joaquin's 'A Question Of Heroes'. And of course, learn more about the man himself, Manuel Luis Quezon. Ironic lang na nauna ko pa ito mapanood before 'Quezon's Game'.Though it must be said. The "government run by hell by Filipinos" is pretty much Quezon's legacy, a legacy of ambition-driven politics fueled by patronage. The film kinda highlighted it splendidly.Pretty much a great film to watch. Informative? Yes. Devil's Advocate? Absolutely!

I finally watched Quezon with my family after we got the time to see it in the cinema. It is the final and third film released after Goyo which was shown seven years ago. This film took several years into production which made me think if ever this will be finished since it would take a lot of money to make it and possibly got delayed because of the pandemic as well.When the cast and more details were announced, I am glad that it still pushed through despite some delays in production. However, what raised some eyebrows is the announcement of Jericho Rosales as Manuel L. Quezon since there was another actor that was supposed to portray an older version of him. I was surprised because Quezon is a mestizo while Rosales is a moreno actor. While I think this must be a miscast, I was intrigued whether he can pull this off since he is also a good actor too and has played lead roles in the past. Watched the movie, I was impressed by Rosales's portrayal of Quezon as an ambitious yet charismatic senator who wants to liberate the Philippines from the Americans. I had my doubts at first that Jerrold Tarog would make Quezon a good person yet what he did in this film he made him a morally grey character. It based Quezon on several historical documents and articles. While it didn't cover much about everything, it is clear that Quezon is what we call in a politics a " trapo" where he uses people to his advantage and perception in winning the elections and attaining power. Watching the film made me realize that everything is still relevant to what is happening today. Same people but different faces. The movie depicts how politics is game for the politicians where the masses are still considered pawns and the rich and elite still dictate everything and control the society. In this film, I didn't root for either Quezon or Aguinaldo. There is neither black and white nor good and bad. Overall, the film is great and entertaining to watch. The veteran and rising cast is great. I also think that Quezon and Osmeña here have chemistry as rivals turned to running mates. It's also an eye-opener to everyone especially when some of the issues in this film are still relevant to our country. Joven and his family represent our struggle in facing the reality of our country. Corruption is a systemic problem in our country and the film makes us think whether we are truly free. Even if we are independent, imperialism still exists in our country especially with how first world countries interfere with our affairs and also control our economy in other ways. The political system is still same but worse and I can still see Quezon in some politicians in the news. With Quezon showing in cinemas, I hope that more people will learn to discern and choose leaders carefully and see them in a lens where they don't vote them just because they're popular or owe them everything. Quezon is not perfect in terms of production and pacing, but it's a fun watch and has served its purpose for the general public. I'm optimistic that if more people will watch this type of films we might get more genres like them in the future.PS: Stay for the mid-credit scenes.

Whether in a historical drama or in reality, it always pains me to keep seeing, over and over again, how people in power always fail to serve the country they swore to offer their lives for. It’s always about f* politics (getting in power) and never about the Filipino people.We are the Philippines—each and every one of us.Nakakapagod. Ngunit kapag mahal mo ang isang tao, o bagay, kahit ang bansa, gagawin mo ang lahat para dito. Walang sinasarili. Walang kapangyarihang ginagamit para sa sariling pakinabang.Minsang nga’y tayo pa ang nagbubulag-bulagan sa mga bagay na matagal nang nakikita ng iba. Nakakalungkot na tayo pa ang naghihilahan pababa sa bawa’t isa para lamang iangat ang ating sarili. Hindi bale na kung maaapektuhan ang iba, ang mahalaga ay tayo’y nasa tuktok at namumuhay ng ‘mapayapa’. Sabi nila nakakain daw ang indepensiya kaya’t ito ay inaasam-asam. Oo, marami ang gutom. Gutom sa mabuting pamumuno at maayos na pamamalakad sa inang bayan.Oh, how we cry for the lives of Filipinos who yearn not just for good governance, but for a life worthy of the freedom we keep celebrating.Tayo ba ay tunay na malaya na? Ano na nga ba ang indepensiya?

jericho delivered a layered performance so i’ll deliver a layered reviewat first, I thought the choice to tell the story from That POV was just a gimmicky choice, like form over substance, but as the film continued it felt like a very relevant meta commentary (idk for sure if that’s the intention). (For added context for the succeeding parts of this review, Quezon’s grandson crashed out during a press tour as he claims there are gross inaccuracies in the film.)The way this film dealt about propaganda stuck with me. Choosing to tell the story in that POV further drives the point for me. Quezon’s grandson crashed out because of inaccuracies, but this film isn’t supposed to be seen as an historical account (as well as the previous films in this trilogy for that matter). Telling the story from the perspective of the film reels for me feels like the director’s way of telling us that these films shouldn’t be read as historical accounts because they are just not. In fact it could even be interpreted as propaganda by some. But that is what the film means to me at least. When TJ Trinidad was recast, I was hesitant, mainly because TJ looked like a modern Manuel Quezon. But after seeing Jericho’s performance as the titular character, no one could’ve done a better job. The voice, the mannerisms, the small details, it’s so layered and I could watch it for hours on end. Everyone else in the cast did a fantastic job as well. (Fuck the CongTV cameo tho)I was shocked by how much they grounded Manuel Quezon back to reality and deconstructed the person. Quezon is one of my favorite presidents, but this made me look at him at a less fanatic perspective. Quezon was one smart mf, but that was also his flaw. He may be the our country’s best example of what a Machiavellian is. He played the cards he was dealt with yes, but he did so knowing the game was rigged while still benefiting from it, and even contributing to the rot. The way imperialism and independence is dealt with here has me conflicted, I still have no cohesive thoughts about how they discussed it, maybe on a rewatch. Politics is a game to those in power even if it shouldn’t be because our lives depend on it. ALSO the tension built in the Bagac Bataan scene IS SO!!!!!!also i geeked tf out when they mentioned Murnau like hellooo (felt like the director just wanna flex his knowledge about filmmaking but still appreciated lol)anyways, I need to see it again

Gagging from start to finish (for all the right and wrong reasons). Trigger Warning: CongTV

Quezon is a somewhat tacky drama that reduces the life and career of former Philippines president Manuel L. Quezon to a series of trite political battles. All the characters have shallow personalities. The dialogue and acting are often cringeworthy.

If Tarog’s goal was to make history feel alive again, then he has succeeded—sometimes to the point of discomfort. As cinema, “Quezon” is impressive. As history, it’s provocative. And as myth, it’s necessary.
